SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate records its sincere regret at the death on 6 October 1981 of President Mohamed Anwar El Sadat and expresses to the people of the Arab Republic of Egypt profound regret and tenders its deep sympathy to his widow and family in their bereavement.

Honourable senators will be aware that the Commonwealth heads of government in Melbourne jointly extended their deep sympathy to Madam Sadat and to the Government and people of Egypt and expressed their horror at the act of outrage which took President Sadat's life. The Governor-General has also expressed his deep sadness and distress at President Sadat's death. As I mentioned earlier, the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, represented this nation at the funeral.

The loss of a world leader of President Sadat's stature is indeed a tragedy. Honourable senators will recall that he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1978, jointly with the Prime Minister of Israel, for his efforts in bringing about the peace with Israel and the stability which has ensued. This is perhaps President Sadat's greatest monument, but his other achievements are not less significant. He took the view that the basic security of Egypt and the Middle East lay in distancing the region from wider global power struggles and to this end he sought to diminish the impact of the Soviet Union by restricting its influence within Egypt and the area as a whole. His pursuit of constructive and realistic domestic and foreign policies brought to both himself and Egypt a reputation for moderation, balance and constraint in the non-aligned world.

His death is a great loss for Egypt, the Middle East and the world, not least because of the senseless and brutal violence which brought it about. Since 1970 he had led his country both as an outstanding patriot and as a man of vision in relations between nations, and although this process involved an acceptance of substantial risks, both domestic and international, his capacity to devote his energies singlemindedly to this task was itself a tribute to his greatness.

In 1977, after 30 years of continual warfare in the Middle East, President Sadat made his historic and courageous visit to Jerusalem to address the Knesset, and thus opened the path to negotiation in the quest for peace. Then, in 1979, the Egyptian-Israeli Peace Treaty was signed. We all hope that President Sadat's achievements will be sustained and that his vision of a lasting and comprehensive peace settlement will be realised. Such a result would be a fitting tribute and memorial to him. The world has lost a great leader, a courageous man. We all mourn his death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate the Opposition with the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick). I think the assassination of President Sadat is a clear reminder to all of us of the rapidity with which change occurs in the Middle East which is still the most troubled part of the world and the area most likely to be the flashpoint for a future world war.

SPEECH.PARA: President Sadat was a man of humble origins who rose to the highest office in his country and became an international statesman. We all admire his courage in breaking the emotional ties with the rest of the Arab world to seek an understanding with Israel. That was an act of bravery perhaps unequalled in recent history. Perhaps that act should have alerted us to the fact that at some time President Sadat would be at risk at the hands of an assassin. It seems that it was not so much his relationship with the Israelis that caused his untimely death but internal policies which created hostility amongst Islamic fundamentalists. I think we can all mourn his death as much for its influence on future events as for the contribution he made to seeking a new way of peace in the Middle East. On the shoulders of his successor, Mr Mubarak, falls a heavy burden.

Egypt's treaty with Israel in March 1979 has not brought a demonstrated peace. Economic problems have become more severe in Egypt and it will need all the help it can get from the Western world to sustain its people and ward off threats from hostile neighbours such as Libya. It will be a tragedy for Egypt if it is to be further plunged into chaos by becoming too closely associated in a military sense with the United States of America. Already it is clear that President Reagan would like to use Egypt as the springboard for his new rapid deployment force in the Middle East. That would further compromise Egypt's relationship with the rest of the Arab world and heighten tensions, already strained, with the Soviet Union.

It is not perhaps a time to dwell on the implications of all these things; it is a time to mourn the death of a brave statesman. It is a sobering thought to review policies in the Middle East and the implications which arise from the tragic death of the President of Egypt. Accordingly, I associate the Opposition with the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Country Party I support the motion of sympathy on the occasion of the tragic death of President Sadat of Egypt. I offer the sincere sympathy of myself and of the National Country Party to the Egyptian people and also to the close relatives and friends of the late President Sadat.

SPEECH.PARA: President Sadat was, as I understand it, a man of peasant origin, and a great nationalist in his own Egyptian land. Indeed, he spent many years determined to divorce his country from the imperialist dominance of former years. He was a man of great dedication and concern, and he desperately and practically sought peace with Israel as a prelude to a wider and more peaceful atmosphere in the troubled Middle Eastern theatre. He sought those things with a very great measure of success. The withdrawal, continuing, from the Sinai, and the Camp David Accords are some of the fruits of the efforts of this man. It is to be fervently hoped that the initiatives that he has started will continue and that the terrorist-type assault that has caused not only the President's death but also the death of and injuries to many other people will cease and will be, in fact, banished from this world. I again offer the sympathy of my party to the Egyptian people and to the close relatives and friends of President Sadat. We have all suffered the loss of a great promoter and champion of the cause of peace in a troubled world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I associate the Australian Democrats with this motion of condolence which perhaps is one of the most important and significant condolence motions to have been moved in the Senate for some time. Mohamed Anwar Sadat became President of Egypt in 1970 at the age of 51. When he took over, on the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser, Egypt was still reeling from the effects of the 1967 war-in a low state of national morale and, under Nasser, a fairly high state of repression. Anwar Sadat was able to revive Egypt with the release of thousands of political prisoners, the expulsion of Soviet military advisers and the overhaul of the political system. In 1973 he crossed the Suez Canal to defeat Israel and indeed, whatever the rights and wrongs of that conflict, he restored Egypt's pride in itself. In 1977 he went to Jerusalem to make peace with the Israelis, a gesture which appeared to be overwhelmingly approved by the people of Egypt. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) has said, President Sadat was awarded, in association with Mr Begin, the Nobel Peace Prize for that tremendous initiative. When Anwar Sadat became President of Egypt in 1970 he was lightly regarded but he soon demonstrated to the world that he was a statesman of the first order. I fear that events yet to come may show us just how much he will be missed.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, we as a legally elected and constituted House of Parliament can only, I suggest, consider with abhorrence the killing by violent means of a man dedicated to peace. That kind of violence, assassination, invasion and occupation of small nations and the like, I am sure all honourable senators would agree, must be resisted by all people of good will, and by all free parliaments, as often as possible and in every possible way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The meeting in Jerusalem between Prime Minister Begin and President Sadat a few years ago was a high point. For many people it was a moment of hope in an area where there had been no peace for many years. I know I speak for part of the Australian community when I say that for the Jewish community it was a moment of high hope and Mr Sadat stood very high among the Jews of the world who for many years had been involved in war in the Middle East. I would just like to say that the death last week of President Sadat shocked the Australian Jewish community very deeply. Last Thursday was Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement. It was announced during the services at my synagogue that on the Friday night at the normal sabbath service there would in fact be a memorial service for President Sadat. I ask the Senate to consider that such an event might have been almost unthinkable 10 or even five years ago. I think that is a measure of what the man was and what he contributed to world peace.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF HONOURABLE P. J. KENNELLY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on 12 October of the Honourable Patrick John Kennelly, a Senator for the State of Victoria from 1953 to 1971, and a Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate from 1956 to 1967, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his widow and family in their bereavement.

Pat Kennelly gave a lifetime of association to the Labor movement. He served for some 14 years in the Victorian Legislative Council. In the State Parliament he served as honorary Minister, Commissioner of Public Works and Minister in charge of Electrical Undertakings. He was elected to the Senate in 1953 and served for 18 years, retiring on 30 June 1971. He served on various committees including the Committee of Disputed Returns and Qualifications and the Joint Committee on Constitutional Review. He was Temporary Chairman of Committees from September 1968 and Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate from February 1956 to February 1967. He was a trustee of the Parliamentary Retiring Allowances Trust from March 1967 until his retirement. He was a member of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association delegation in 1959 and a member of the Inter-Parliamentary Union delegation in 1964. He leaves a widow, a son and a daughter.

I was not privileged to serve in the chamber with Pat Kennelly but I came to know him over the years. I came to know him as a man of total dedication to his political cause, a man who brought a skill, shrewdness of judgment and professionalism to his cause. He was a man who, with that very attractive stutter or stammer-which one dared to imitate, and one could almost hear it in this chamber-was nevertheless entirely articulate. No one was left in any doubt at all about what Pat Kennelly meant. He was a doughty opponent and yet a good friend. He was able to separate issues from personalities. He fought a very tough fight. There were few more professional in this profession of politics than Pat Kennelly. He was the very proof of the saying that all history is biography. He was very much the biography and the history of the Australian Labor Party and the Labor movement of his day. I think the Australian people have lost a good servant. I commend the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick). The career of Pat Kennelly in politics spanned more than 40 years. As the Leader of the Government has pointed out, Pat Kennelly attained a degree of articulateness in spite of a stammer which became perhaps his most notable characteristic. He joined the Australian Labor Party at the age of 15 in 1915. In 1924 at the age of 24 he tried to enter the State Parliament in Victoria but lost. He became Secretary of the Victorian branch of the Labor Party in 1930 and held that job for 16 years. In 1938 he was elected to the Victorian upper House. As the Leader of the Government said, Pat Kennelly was a Minister in the Cain Government. He was again State Secretary of the Victorian Labor Party from 1946, Federal Secretary of the Labor Party from 1946 and its full time Secretary from 1950. In 1952 he lost his preselection for the safe upper House seat of Melbourne West as a result of bitter internal squabbles in the Labor Party which were to lead to the split of 1955. However, in 1953 he was elected to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned earlier that in spite of the stammer which has become famous he was a very effective and articulate speaker. In fact, Senator Carrick did not say so but there have been occasions in this Senate, which I believe some people will recall, when he used that stammer to excellent, if doubtful, advantage. Pat Kennelly lived all of his life in the suburb of South Melbourne. He died there and is survived by his wife and two children. I think it is fair to say that Kennelly perhaps will be one of the great legendary figures of Labor politics and possibly party politics. He is famous for such injunctions as: 'It is nice to have the logic but I prefer to have the numbers'. I recall many similar famous and colourful phrases that I heard him use. One was that, as Chairman of the Albert Park Trust, if he ever wanted any publicity in the Melbourne Herald, he would arrange to cut down a tree in the park.

One point that should be made about Kennelly is his very real political influence over great Labor leaders. He was extremely influential in the political life of the former Premier of Victoria, John Cain, and, in a strange way, was also something of a mentor and influence in the life of the next Labor Premier of that State, John Cain Jnr. There was a long association between those two families.

I believe that he was also very influential in the life of the Chifley Labor Government. I recall his telling me that on one occasion Ben Chifley was very opposed to a course on which the Labor Party seemed intent upon embarking, and he walked around the gardens of Parliament House for two hours arguing with Ben Chifley about what ought to be done. Finally he said to Chifley: 'Ben, if you do not do this Reg Pollard will lose the seat of Ballaarat'. Chifley stamped his foot on the ground and said: 'All right Pat, we will do it, but I am not going to announce it'. That, in a sense, was a mark of Kennelly's influence over the Chifley Government and indeed the whole of Labor politics at that time.

Finally, he was a man who had a passionate loyalty-a loyalty which perhaps only people of Celtic origin might understand-to all those things in which he believed and which he valued. They included his family, his church, his political party, the Richmond Football Club, and a variety of very close friendships with particular people in politics. For my own part, I always regarded Pat Kennelly as in many ways a guiding star, a personal mentor and a friend. I strongly associate myself with the message of deep sympathy from this Senate to his wife, his daughter Joan and his son Ron. I have pleasure in commending the motion to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate the National Country Party with the remarks of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) in offering sympathy to the wife and children of the late Senator Kennelly. In my first few months in this chamber, in 1970, I had the pleasure of knowing Senator Kennelly, although admittedly only briefly. I became aware of his contribution, of his earnestness and of his great ability to promote the things in which he believed. I am aware now, on looking back, of his very long service in his particular political field, in an organisational capacity and as a member of both the upper House of his own State and, for no less than 18 years, of this chamber, the Senate. The late Senator Kennelly was well known for his humour, his dedication, his professionalism, and indeed, as I understand it, his great worldly knowledge and capacity to assess realities. I wish to associate my party with the expression of sincere sympathy to his widow and children.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The time in this place of the late Senator Kennelly and that of the Australian Democrats are, of course, widely separated. None of us was able to know him in this place. However, I would like briefly to associate the Australian Democrats with the motion of condolence to his wife and family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Pat Kennelly was a member of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party and a member of the Senate from 1953 to 1971, a term of some 18 years. For nine of those years, namely from 1962 until his retirement in 1971, I had the honour of being one of his party and parliamentary colleagues. Senator Kennelly was a graduate of the university of hard knocks. He was a realist. He was a man with a sardonic sense of humour, a man who was completely dedicated to the Labor movement. He rose to the top of the party's echelons and was responsible for so many others making it also.

SPEECH.PARA: In the great days of the Chifley Labor Government, Pat Kennelly was the General Secretary of the Australian Labor Party. He was regarded by all and sundry as the king maker. He was the old-type Labor man who had a great understanding of and a great belief in ordinary people. He believed in getting things done. According to him, in politics the way in which things could be done was for the party to get into government. That was always at the top of the mast as far as he was concerned. Pat Kennelly could never understand modern economics. He once said to me: 'My mother taught me the economics of earning a quid and spending only 19s 9d. Do that and you are always well out in front'. In his last words to the Senate on 12 May 1971 he had this to say:

I have enjoyed the lifetime I have had. When one has been a member of a political party for more than 56 years, as I will have been next August, one becomes part of that party. I never wanted to come to Canberra. I could have come earlier than I did-possibly in my heyday in the Labor Party-but I did not want to come. A set of circumstances which some people in this chamber may recall forced my entry into the Commonwealth Parliament. But that is all part of the game. I defeated many, and some defeated me. I wish to thank one person who is not here; that is my wife. Without her I could not have done what I have done. Very few men succeed in life without the help and encouragement of a partner in life such as I had. I thank her for it.

I must say that in the years which I have had in public life I have never known a more devoted couple than Pat and Jessie Kennelly. Senator Kennelly always referred to Mrs Kennelly not with the possessive term, 'my wife', but as Mrs Kennelly. Long after he left the Senate he continued to maintain a great interest in the affairs of the Parliament, the Senate in particular, and of the people who make up the parliamentary life of this country. Quite often Pat and Mrs Kennelly could be seen in the lobbies of this Parliament. He was particularly keen to be here during the time of the Whitlam Labor Government from 1972 to 1975.

As Senator Button has said, Pat Kennelly was a legendary figure. He will be immortalised in the folklore of the Labor movement. His life was a full life. He was a tremendous parliamentarian and a great Australian. Mr President, I am honoured that you have asked me to represent you and the Senate at his funeral on Thursday. I join the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) in the condolence motion that has been moved. I extend my personal sympathy to his widow and to the members of his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues in this well deserved tribute to the memory of former Senator Kennelly. I notice that my leader, Senator Button, referred to Pat Kennelly's loyalty to the Richmond Football Club. That loyalty caused him to extend his influence well beyond the State of Victoria. With the advent of poker machines New South Wales Australian rules football clubs were able to go into the market and obtain the better class Victorian players. Pat Kennelly had an assignment which he dished out to many New South Wales members. It was to get the reports and balance sheets of those clubs so that when it came to negotiations, particularly if a Richmond player was involved, behind the scenes they knew how much to negotiate to make sure that they got a reasonable signing-on fee. I do not think he worried so much if it was a Collingwood player, but if it was a Richmond player he would telephone people to make sure that the chap was getting a fair go. That was typical of the man. He found small matters in relation to which he would prevent any injustices occurring.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter is a little different. We had what I would describe as a rort involving the Wentworth Park dog track in Sydney and its use on Sundays for soccer. A first division club had the tender. The week the club was playing away it would sublet the field at 300 per cent profit. Eventually this was detected. I pointed this out to Pat Kennelly. He said that it would not happen at Albert Park. But such is human frailty, whether it be in Victoria or New South Wales, that it had happened. He telephoned me a month later and said: 'Brother, I fixed that up. They have had to give back every bloody dollar to the third division team'. It had been paying 300 per cent more in some subletting arrangement which Pat Kennelly and the trust had been unaware of. The nicest part was that later he told me that the club that benefited was a Maltese club. When he went to mass they said: 'Mr Kennelly, we are lighting candles for you. We think you are a wonderful man'. He said: 'When you get to my age, with all the enemies I have made and all the difficulties I have had, it is good to have that support'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself with this condolence motion. I extend sincere sympathy to the widow and children of the late Senator Pat Kennelly. If Pat were here he would probably laugh heartily if he knew what I was going to say. I am probably the only member of this chamber who likes to think that he had the logic in 1955. What Pat said is dead right: We did not have the numbers. That is all I would like to say. It just seems to me that he would laugh if he were here and heard me say such a thing. All I can say is that I certainly mourn him. There were occasions in the last couple of years when we exchanged words. He always had a fatherly interest in what I was doing, even if it was from a long distance. I will certainly remember him and I will certainly pray for the eternal repose of his soul.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to contribute briefly to the debate. I join with those who have spoken previously in paying their tributes to the late Pat Kennelly. He was the Deputy Leader when I came into this chamber. Perhaps I got to know him better in the hurly-burly of outside politics when I filled the role of national president of my party over a period of years. Pat was the type of bloke with whom I could have an argument and five minutes later-he was a non-drinker-he would be prepared to have a cup of tea with me. We would laugh and talk about the discussion that had taken place. He was one of the great characters of this country and probably one of the most colourful ever to have walked the political stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that somewhere, some time, someone writes his memoirs in order to tell us precisely the inside things which Pat knew and which he shared with very few people. He had a tendency to share his memories and experiences in a piecemeal sort of way. He would talk to one person and recall a particular incident and would probably talk to half a dozen other people about half a dozen other incidents. It will be very difficult to get all that data together. He was a bit of a bower bird. One hopes that his papers will not be destroyed and that, like Dr Evatt's, eventually they will be put together. I hope that eventually the true story of the great problems Pat Kennelly faced in the early part and then the middle part of his political career will get the publicity which is warranted. I join with those who have spoken earlier in expressing sympathy to his widow, his son and his daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret the passing of Pat Kennelly. I was surprised to hear of his death. I thought Pat Kennelly would live forever; he was that sort of a person. He seemed to be timeless in what he did and what he had to say. I remember him in particular because he often came to my defence. He was not one who believed in my political attitudes; nevertheless, he protected me when I was in trouble in this place-which was more often than not. I remember sitting on the far side of the Senate; Pat used to be at the back. When the President gave a ruling which suppressed me Pat Kennelly found a suitable way around that ruling. I was grateful for that, as were many people who were young and new members of the Opposition at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: With Pat Kennelly's passing passes a substantial part of the lives of the people who knew him, because he represented the Australian Labor Party in a particular way. He defended the Labor Party at his own cost. The cost was antagonism by the church to which he was most loyal. I do not doubt now that that church understands how right Pat Kennelly was and how wrong it was during that period. In spite of that oppression he never at any time relaxed in his loyalty, either to his religion or to the party to which he belonged. For that reason I want to place on record my feelings and my expression of sympathy to his family.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Senators in the Parliament assembled. This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The proposal to introduce fees for higher and second degrees will mean that access to post-graduate and recurrent education will be limited to the rich. Australian research and ability to cope with technological change will suffer; this proposal must be seen as a step in the direction of the introduction of fees for all tertiary students.

2. The proposed introduction of a loans scheme for students will mean graduating with a heavy debt or being denied a tertiary education if loans are refused because a student is seen as a 'poor risk' (particularly affecting women and those doing non-vocational courses); only the rich will be able to get a tertiary education without course restrictions and the burden of indebtedness.

3. In regard to the proposal to restrict eligibility for TEAS and the foreshadowing of reviewing TEAS levels only in the light of the availability of loans; it should be noted that any further downgrading of TEAS, which is already inadequate, can only further limit access to education.

4. The proposed restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance to those needing qualifications for employment will severely restrict access to a full high school education and necessary bridging education to tertiary education for those who left school early.

5. The proposal not to fund 30 Colleges of Advanced Education if they are not rationalised is an attack on teacher education. This attack will create teacher shortages in the mid 1980s, restrict access to education now and endanger the future quality of teaching available to Australian children.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(i) post-secondary tuition fees not be introduced for any courses or for any category of students;
(ii) that the TEAS scheme be extended so as to more fully meet the real financial needs of students;
(iii) that a comprehensive loans scheme not be introduced;
(iv) that there be no restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance;
(v) that the proposal not to fund 30 CAEs unless they are rationalised be rescinded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Expenses: Tax Deductibility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becomming more polarised-that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer, profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing. Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
(1) All pensions and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the National Average Male Earnings seasonally adjusted.
(2) Removal of the means/income test on the Pensioner Health Benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973.
Reintroduction of Medibank in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

(3) To alleviate Australia's shortage of housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government immediately inject $200 million into State Housing Authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to the fact that over the last few years it has become customary for Ministers in the Fraser Government to justify the economic policies of the Government by referring to the number of new jobs created. Is it a fact that recent figures indicate that the number of jobs being generated by the Australian economy has declined sharply in recent months and that on present indications the growth of the labour force is far outstripping job creation, causing a sharp rise in unemployment? If increased job generation was an indicator of the success of the Government's economic policies before the 1980 election, is decreased job generation now an indicator of the failure of the Government's economic policies in 1981?

—The figures over quite a number of months showed some very encouraging trends indeed. They showed that there was a growth of jobs in excess of the numbers of people coming on to the job market, and I think all Australians were very happy that this was so. In particular, there has been a trend, and it has continued until now, of a decline in unemployment amongst juveniles. In the latter months the trend has shown some alterations in that it appears, for whatever reason, in the short term that this trend is not continuing at its more optimistic peak. A number of adjustments would have to be made, and I am not in a position to give them here. Incidentally, one factor was the very high incidence of industrial unrest in that period-
—Oh, come on!
—The trend has been on for three months. Cut it out.

—According to the Statistician and not the interjectors, that affected the figures. The fact is that the Government does believe that a main task in Australia is to so encourage resource development and national development generally as to create more jobs and more job opportunities for Australians. We are very eager that we should reduce the rate of unemployment. It is true that by comparison we are doing conspicuously better than other countries. For example, the average level of unemployment among European countries is 7 to 8 per cent.
—What? Six per cent.

—We are not good enough and we are aiming to work to see that we can develop further. The fact is that according to the indicators, as, for example, the Premier of New South Wales has suggested, as the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party has suggested in his statements-and that, I think, is important; and I do not note interjections-the trend of the development of resources in Australia will be such that substantially more jobs will be created well ahead of the growth of numbers in the months and years ahead.
—You know that is not true. That is a lot of rubbish.

—I refer those who query that, including the questioner, to the various statements of the Federal President of the Labor Party, who believes that the policies which are developing resources in this country will provide many more jobs in the future. Indeed, in some of his publications he talks of between 50,000 and 100,000 new jobs in his own State.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Defence to recent newspaper articles which report the removal by private collectors and aircraft restorers of two Bristol Beaufighter fuselages from Kalumburu airfield, previously known as Drysdale airfield, to Sydney. As I understand the position, the aircraft were badly damaged during the Second World War and were converted to components, which means essentially that they have been stripped of useful parts and abandoned in that remote and almost totally inaccessible part of Western Australia since 1945. I further understand that it is the intention of the group which has recovered the aircraft to restore one for static display and that it is hopeful, using other parts it has, of restoring the other to flying condition. If that is the case it will be only the second Beaufighter aircraft in the world flying today. I ask the Minister: Firstly, to whom do the aircraft belong and by what criteria do they claim legal ownership? Secondly, will the Government consider vesting ownership of the aircraft in the restoration group which has recovered them, provided they are made available on display to the Australian people?

—I do not know whether I can answer the specific questions that were asked at the end of Senator Crichton-Browne's question. However, I have some background information which may be of some interest. I will refer the specific questions to the Minister. The Beaufighter parts which are the subject of the question and of recent Press coverage are fuselage sections from wrecked Mark IX and Mark XI Beaufighters of United Kingdom manufacture. Their presence at Kalumburu has been known since World War II, as has the location of many other wrecks around Australia. In November 1980 Air Force Office asked the Royal Australian Air Force Darwin to undertake a survey of the wrecks at Kalumburu and to recommend which could be suitable for restoration. That survey was conducted in September 1981. The parts were removed from Kalumburu by Mr Baxter, after asking permission from the mission and the local Aborigines, and brought back to Sydney. They are currently stored near the Richmond RAAF base. Air Force Office was in contact with Mr Baxter before the media developed the story and is negotiating an agreement aimed at ensuring that after eventual restoration a Beaufighter is preserved for posterity. The RAAF will continue to offer whatever assistance it can for the restoration project, although this is likely to be limited to technical advice and the possible transport of parts on a space-available basis. However, the RAAF is certainly pleased to support this worthwhile project of restoration and hopes that there will be some mutual benefits in it. As I said, I will refer the specific questions, as to who owns the aircraft and so on, to the Minister for further answer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES INSTALLATIONS AT NORTH WEST CAPE AND PINE GAP

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware of an article in the West Australian dated 5 October 1981 informing Australians that booklets describing the activities and significance of the United States installations at North West Cape and Pine Gap can be purchased in America for the sum of 10c? Is the Minister also aware that, while these booklets are readily available in the United States, there is a prohibition on the publication and distribution of them in Australia? If these are facts, how do they square with the Government's freedom of information legislation and the Government's alleged philosophy of the people's right to know?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of such booklets at all, nor am I aware of the advertisement in the newspaper. If Senator McIntosh lets me have that information I will pursue the matter. I am not aware that information on American defence installations in Australia which is published in America freely and accurately is not published here. If there can be evidence of that I will have it examined and responded to. My understanding was that the preservation of the actual defence secrecy of such installations was at least bipartisan. My understanding is that the Leader of the Australian Labor Party has been informed as to the nature of these installations, that he has a full understanding of their importance and that, like all good Australians, he has an understanding that one preserves the secrecy of important defence installations against the fact that the enemy can, in breach of that secrecy, weaken the defence of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of freedom of information, there is, as in all defence matters, a significant qualification. I would not have thought that the Labor Party would have quarrelled with it. If there were evidence to show that accurate information is being distributed in America and not allowed here I would be very happy to put it under study and have it commented upon.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to the recent arrival of the so-called refugee vessel VT383 in Darwin Harbour with 146 occupants who have, it appears, purchased their passage and are reported to have come from countries other than Vietnam in the guise of refugees. As Australia has long been recognised as a country sympathetic to genuine refugees and migrants making their future home here, will the Government take action to expel these VT383 people immediately if they are proven to be illegal immigrants, indicating to all that illegal migration to Australia will not be tolerated and ensuring that the possibility of a passive invasion of Australia from other countries will neither be contemplated nor encouraged?
—He doesn't need an answer to the question. He asked the question and answered it himself.

—I will be the judge of that, if the honourable senator does not mind. The investigations of the persons who arrived at Darwin on the vessel VT383 referred to by Senator Kilgariff are still continuing and are likely to take several more days. However, the results so far indicate that most, quite possibly all, of the persons who were on board came from Taiwan or Hong Kong and not directly from Vietnam. More information, however, is required before the Government will be in a position to decide finally on these matters and on the future of these people. However, I agree with the concern expressed by Senator Kilgariff. The Government certainly will not tolerate any overseas schemes designed to bring people into Australia illegally or indeed those who seek to come in illegally themselves.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs: Did a meeting of 600 people in Melbourne last week representing all political parties, other than the National Country Party, and many other areas of Australian society reaffirm a determination to support the people of East Timor in their stand against the Indonesian invasion and occupation of that territory? Since it is now almost six years since that invasion took place and the East Timorese people are still resisting the Indonesians, how can the Australian Government persist with the fiction that the occupation is acceptable to the East Timorese people? I ask the Minister: Does Indonesia have any historic, geographic, ethnic, cultural or indeed any other claim to East Timor? Why should East Timor not be a free and independent society able to control its own affairs? Will the Government hold, as soon as possible, a public inquiry into those aspects of Australian-Indonesian relations from 1975 onwards relating to East Timor, with a special reference to determining why Australia seems to have been committed to a policy which is rightly perceived by Indonesia as craven, abject, quivering weakness and appeasement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason has suggested that there be some sort of public inquiry into the matters raised in his question relating to East Timor. I will refer it to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see whether he has any feeling that there ought to be some inquiry into these matters. Australia accepts that East Timor is part of Indonesia and that matters relating to East Timor, whether they be matters of security or any other matters, are the responsibility of the Indonesian Government. At the same time I think it should be said that the position of the Australian Government regarding internationally accepted standards of human rights is well known to the Indonesian Government and to the people in Australia as well. I think the matter raised by Senator Mason is one that continually is raised. Many statements have been made in the past on the relationship between East Timor and Indonesia. However, as he has requested that a public inquiry be held into the matters that he has raised, I will seek the reaction of the Minister to that request.

—I ask the Minister a supplementary question. I ask the Minister, with respect, whether she could, if possible, answer this question: How can the Australian Government persist with the fiction that the occupation is acceptable to the East Timorese people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I have said, Australia accepts that East Timor is part of Indonesia and I am not going to enter into that further question that is raised at this time by Senator Mason. It concerns something that occurred a very long time ago and much has been said about it. Australia does accept that East Timor is part of Indonesia.

—Has the Minister for Social Security seen a recent Press comment that suggests that the Government might abandon the introduction of legislation to prevent the circumvention of income tests? Will the Minister indicate to the Senate the present position in regard to the introduction of the proposed legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen recent Press comment and in fact within the last week I have responded to some Press inquiries on this subject. The Government has today decided that there will be some delay in introducing the legislation which I was proposing but I stress that it is delay only because the Government does wish to strengthen the provisions of the social security legislation against schemes contrived to circumvent the income test. That means that the legislation will not be introduced in the current parliamentary session but I hope to introduce it in the next parliamentary sitting, the autumn sitting. The delay is occasioned quite simply because the preparation of the legislation has proved to be more complex than I had expected and the Government naturally is concerned to have clear legislation which will be comprehensible to pensioners but which at the same time will prevent artificial schemes and not need wide discretionary powers. The Government's intention to prevent artificial schemes designed to qualify people for social security benefits to which they are not otherwise entitled should be understood. The Government, however, does not wish to inhibit normal domestic financial arrangements or investment practices.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have indicated to the Senate before, the need for this sort of legislation is simply to ensure that we can meet our objective to provide more adequately for those in the community who do not have sufficient to provide for themselves. In fact, many cases are drawn to my attention of very substantial schemes being entered into to achieve the benefit of social security benefits, and that is a matter to which I am giving continuing attention. It is a matter of regret to me that the requirements of the legislation do not permit me to introduce it in this session but I will be proceeding with the development of the legislation as early as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, follows the question asked by Senator Walters. I ask the Minister: Is he aware of the advertisements appearing in the Press and on radio by insurance companies and finance companies in this country urging pensioners to invest their money in what are described as safe tax free and income test free investments to avoid the legislation which these companies say was to be introduced by Senator Chaney by 1 November? If he is aware of these schemes and the urgings of people to join these artificial schemes, is there to be any provision in the new legislation to take into account schemes which are operating now or which will be instituted before he introduces his legislation next autumn to avoid having a situation where there are two classes of pensioners in this country-one class of people who were able to join before the Minister and the Government were able to make up their minds on what they were going to do and another group who will be caught up in the new legislation after the autumn session?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that there are advertisements for schemes to enable people to avoid the operation of the income test. As I have made it clear on prior occasions, that was precisely why the Government wished to see the test strengthened. I suppose our failure to move over a matter of months in this area can be compared fairly favourably to the failure of the previous Labor Government to move at all in the field of tax avoidance, notwithstanding that there were many well known schemes in that area. It is one of the great curiosities that the previous government failed to do anything in this area, as against the present Government's frequent measures which are aimed to prevent that sort of thing occurring.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the matters for which I am responsible, I simply point out to the Senate that the way that people can organise their affairs is, of course, almost endless in its variety. It is a matter of having legislation which will catch the artificial and yet at the same time leave untouched the normal domestic arrangements of the great mass of pensioners who do not enter into such schemes. Until I have legislation which I am satisfied will not be in any sense punitive to those pensioners who are simply carrying on their normal domestic affairs and who are not entering into artificial and contrived schemes, I would not propose to introduce such legislation into this Parliament. I have a very strong view that it is desirable that these schemes should be stopped but anyone with any experience would know that, as against having that intention, having the legislation in the precise form which can ensure it is not avoided is a slightly more difficult task. I have just indicated to the Senate that that task is one which I will not have completed within these current sittings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question: Is it not a fact that these contrived schemes have been in existence since his Government introduced the new incomes only test in 1976? Why has the Government not proceeded in the past almost five years to do something about them? I add that this is a period which is longer than the three years of the previous Labor Government which he apparently is complaining about in regard to tax evasion.

—I think it is quite clear that the use of these schemes has intensified over recent months. Indeed, most of the major financial institutions in Australia seem to be taking an interest in getting a slice of the action so it is something which is expanding and which warrants further attention.

—Is the Minister for National Development and Energy aware of a Press statement published today in the Adelaide Advertiser by Mr Bannon, the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia, stating that Mr Wran has now given an undertaking that his Government is prepared to support the extension of the function of the River Murray Commission to include control over water quality? Is it a fact that there will be a meeting in Melbourne on Friday, as I understand it, of Premiers and relevant Ministers with the Prime Minister to discuss this matter and to move to make this overdue alteration to the River Murray Waters Agreement? Following ratification of the amendments to the Agreement, I hope on Friday, when would the Minister expect to introduce the legislation necessary to give effect to the new agreement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the item in the Adelaide Advertiser of this morning. Indeed, I will be very interested to see it. It is fair to say that at very regular intervals over recent months I have had my officers contact the Wran Government urging that an agreement be reached because the only thing that has stood in the way of the new agreement has been in fact the Wran Government's decision on whether to accept the question of water quality. I can only hope that that is so. I believe that such an agreement, when ratified, will be a major step forward in bringing about proper control of the River Murray, both qualitatively and quantitively. It is true that next Friday there will be in Melbourne a meeting attended by the Prime Minister, the relevant Premiers and myself to discuss this matter. I would be delighted if it could reach agreement on the subject.

ANSWER.PARA: A lot is happening in regard to the River Murray. Nature itself, as a result of the abundant rainfall and the snow melt that is to come, is doing a great deal about the question of salinity, and the Government is also doing a considerable amount by way of public works. I cannot give an exact timetable. I can say only that when an agreement is reached we will implement it legislatively as soon as possible. I take it that an agreement, once reached, would be capable of implementation straight away, in the sense that the Commission ought to be able to go ahead and plan, both qualitatively and quantitatively, at once. I hope that such agreement will be achieved next Friday.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General: Is it the case that in the month immediately preceding 11 a.m. on 7 September last, when the warrant in question was lifted, every interstate, overseas and local telegram or telex message sent to anyone at all living or holidaying in, or passing through, the Coolangatta area of Queensland was intercepted, recorded and scrutinised by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation or the Australian Federal Police? Is it the case further that this is merely one example of the continuing practice, the existence of which was reported in general terms in the National Times of 27 September last, whereby every time a warrant is issued for the interception of a particular individual's telegram or telex messages, and that interception is made at the Brisbane Central Telephone Exchange, a recording is made and scrutiny undertaken by ASIO or the Australian Federal Police of every single telegram or telex message that is directed to the whole postal area in which the individual, the subject of the warrant, resides? Does the Attorney-General acknowledge that this practice involves a clear breach of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979? Does he nonetheless defend it? If he does not, what does he propose to do about it?
—I will take note of the honourable senator's question and give him a considered reply.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EAST TIMOR: SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Pursuant to Standing Order 98A, I put a question without notice to Senator Scott, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, relating to the activities of that Committee. I ask the Chairman whether he is aware of recent reports from church sources in East Timor which allege that a further military offensive is being conducted by Indonesian occupying forces against nationalist guerrillas in East Timor, involving the removal of a great number of able-bodied Timorese from their villages and from crop planting, thereby creating the threat of a further famine in East Timor? Is he also aware of allegations of murder, torture and other brutalities, and the imprisonment of thousands of East Timorese, as well as confirmation of these activities in a recent report by the pro-Indonesian Assembly of East Timor to the Indonesian Government? Also, is the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence aware of complaints of delays in effecting the reunion of Timorese families in Australia by the return of family members from Portugal and Timor and of substantial allegations of corruption which have obstructed the departure of Timorese migrants from Jakarta to Australia? In view of these reports and the deep concern expressed within Australia by groups such as the Australian Council for Overseas Aid about the denial of self-determination to the Timorese people, I ask the honourable senator whether his Committee will undertake an urgent investigation of, and report to the Senate about: (1) The recent allegations in respect to East Timor; and (2) the Government's program and actions in respect to East Timor, including Australia's obligations to secure the reunion of East Timorese families.
—Before referring the question to Senator Scott, I ask the honourable senator whether such a reference is before the Committee of which he is Chairman. If not, the question is misdirected.
—This specific reference is not.
—But is it covered by another reference?
— It is not before the Committee.
—I raise a point of order. I am not suggesting that there is a reference. My question was whether the honourable senator's Committee will undertake an investigation of this nature.

—The usual procedure is to give notice of one's intention to move that the Senate refer a matter to a particular committee. I question whether it is in order to raise the matter in this way at Question Time. As Senator Scott is now aware of what Senator Missen has in mind, perhaps Senator Missen should consider giving notice tomorrow that he will move that such a reference be given to the Committee. But I question whether, under Standing Orders, he can direct a question to a chairman of a committee when the committee does not have before it a reference concerning the matter to which the question relates.

—With respect, Mr President, I sought leave to ask the question. Of course, I could proceed by giving a notice of motion, but because of the urgency of the allegations which arose during the recess of the Parliament, I sought leave of the Senate, and obtained leave, to ask my question. I gave Senator Scott foreknowledge of the general nature of my inquiry, though not of the wording of my question. Therefore, Senator Scott is in possession of all the documents that I am in possession of in relation to this matter. I suggest that he is in no way taken by surprise by this question.

—I will look closely both at the question and at any references which Senator Scott's committee may have before it. I will let the honourable senator have a decision at a later hour of the day. I feel that Standing Orders may be infringed if I allow the question at this stage.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Prior to or since the Government decision to appoint a royal commission of inquiry into the Builders Labourers Federation, was a legal opinion sought from him or his Department on the possible effect of that decision on the deregistration proceedings which had already been initiated?

—The legal position in relation to deregistration proceedings and a royal commission into the activities of the BLF certainly was a matter for consideration by me. A report was made to the Government and a discussion took place. I do not propose to indicate what opinions I give or what discussions take place in Cabinet on these matters.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. In view of the fact that Trans Australia Airlines has indicated that it will be forced to opt out of its F27 services to western Queensland after April of next year for economic reasons, and following discussions held in western Queensland last week, can the Minister advise what subsidy arrangements are being made to ensure that the people of the more remote areas of Queensland are to continue to be serviced with adequate air transport?

—At present there are no arrangements for any Commonwealth subsidy in respect of TAA operating in western Queensland. However, I understand that the Minister will be participating in discussions between the Queensland Government, TAA and representatives of the local government organisations in western Queensland, in the not too distant future, to explore further the whole question of the nature of services in that area as well as TAA's expected withdrawal. The possibility of the Commonwealth providing some financial assistance to those services will be considered as a result of those discussions.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, relates to prawn trawlers operating in our northern waters and falls into four parts. How many licences have been issued since the introduction of the moratorium in 1977? How many of the trawlers operating are owned independently? Does the 27 1/2 per cent boat building subsidy apply to the construction of prawn trawlers? Are independent fishermen forced to sell their catch through major companies which have organised a buying cartel?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter, which falls within the responsibilities of the Minister for Primary Industry, is one on which I do not have all the information sought by the honourable senator. I can give him some information on it and I will seek the balance of the reply from the Minister responsible. The Northern Prawn Fishery has had limited entry since 1 January 1977. My information is that at present 292 boats are entitled to operate in that fishery. I do not know how many of those have actually obtained a licence since the limitation was imposed. That is a matter on which I will seek clarification.

ANSWER.PARA: The industry is undergoing some change because, as the honourable senator would know better than most, the Northern Prawn Fishery is in a very remote area and operating conditions are not easy. The economic factors are such that operators are tending to replace small boats with modern boats approximately 21 metres in length. The cost of these boats is such that they are out of reach financially of some, if not all, of the independent operators. The company ownership of boats is therefore increasing. Apparently about half of the current fleet is company-owned. The advice I have is that there is no evidence that companies have colluded on the price of products and that all the available evidence suggests that there is active competition between companies for the product from fishermen. The suggestion in the question asked by the honourable senator was that there is a cartel. If he has some information or evidence to the contrary the Minister would no doubt be interested to hear about it. He might care to provide the Minister with any information he has. I think there are one or two elements-in particular the question asking how many licences have recently been issued-about which I will have to seek further information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of a poll reported in the Age of 28 September 1981 which brought to light the fact that 62 per cent of the sample supported protection to preserve employment in the domestic economy? Will the Government consider this expression of opinion when making decisions on the protection levels applicable to major sections of our domestic manufacturing industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I sometimes wish we could govern by opinion poll. I think life would be a great deal simpler. I ran out of any illusions about that when I saw polls which showed that, I think, 60 per cent of people favoured less taxes and 60 per cent of people favoured more government expenditure. Therefore, I realise that it is a little difficult always to follow whatever the opinion poll might indicate. With respect to the matter on which this opinion poll was taken, this is an area of very great importance and also considerable sensitivity. I did not see the poll which said that 62 per cent of the people polled support protection of the domestic economy. I think the honourable senator would be aware that one of the very important factors which the Government takes into account when considering questions of tariff protection is that of employment. I can assure the honourable senator that that consideration, which may well be in the minds of some of those people who are concerned about the issue of protection, is certainly very prominent in the Government's mind when it is considering these matters.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst in a democracy the Government is always concerned to know what the electorate wants because, in the end, the electorate is the body which determines whether the Government continues, it is not possible simply to make these decisions on the basis of some sampling of opinion at a particular time because such samplings are, of necessity, imperfect. In any event, the Government also has a leadership role in this and other areas. Its obligation is to get all the relevant facts, to make a decision which is in the national interest and then to convince the electorate that that decision was taken in the national interest. That applies in the field of protection no less than in other fields.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. As I understand it, deregulation of interest rates was for the purpose of increasing competition and so reducing interest rates. Is it not a fact that interest rates have increased and are continuing to increase? As that policy has failed, does the Government intend to reregulate interest rates? Is not the Minister aware that too many financial institutions are seeking funds and that this is pressing up interest rates and will continue to do so unless they are regulated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I can state only that the Government has no proposal before it to reintroduce regulation of interest rates. I think it is accepted that there is a market reaction to the interest rates that do apply but at this stage there is no proposal in the mind of the Government or under consideration that would do as was suggested in the second part of Senator Georges's question.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that an increase in interest rates destabilises the stock markets and that this is a risk the Government cannot continue to take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I really have nothing further to add to what I said earlier with regard to the market effect on the economy, on the interest rates. There is no proposal before the Government to change the present methods of dealing with these matters.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: USE OF HOBART BY JAPANESE FISHING VESSELS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I preface the question by referring to the negotiations that are now under way in regard to Japanese long-line tuna vessel fishing licences. Is the Minister aware that over the past 16 years these vessels have visited Hobart for stores and repairs? Is he aware that about 150 such vessels a year use Hobart and that that is worth approximately $3m each year to the city? Is it true that the Federal Government is considering restricting entry of tuna vessels below 30 degrees south, which of course would preclude Hobart and cause an obvious economic loss? Will the Minister ask the Minister for Primary Industry to ensure that the renewal of the fishing agreement does not disadvantage Tasmania?

—The Minister for Primary Industry has just returned from an overseas visit. While in Japan he spoke with the Japanese Minister for Agriculture, Mr Kameoka. I understand that one of the matters which he discussed with that Minister was the Japanese fishing industry in Australian waters. I am not familiar with the detail of those discussions and whether they impimged on the area raised by the honourable senator in his question; nor am I familiar with whether restrictions are to be imposed in the manner he has suggested. I will seek that information from the Minister for Primary Industry and let the honourable senator have a reply.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: Is the Treasurer aware that in acting to remove a long-standing anomaly concerning the sales tax on chocolate biscuits the Taxation Office has created a worse anomaly? As a result of the 1981-82 Budget the flour content in some biscuits which are sales tax exempt is greater than in some that are now taxed. Previously the flour content was used as a basis for determining sales tax exemption. Will the Treasurer review completely the arbitrary distinction now drawn and treat all chocolate-covered confectionery and biscuits in the same way for sales tax purposes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I think was implied in the question, it was thought that with the introduction of the changes in this Budget an anomaly was removed in the distinction of chocolate confectionery and chocolate biscuits. If specific problems have arisen, as was suggested in the question of Senator Siddons, and if some details could be given to me-or to the Treasurer-I could seek an opinion from the Commissioner of Taxation as to the treatment that would be applied in particular instances. The proposal in the Budget is to remove an anomaly, to place like things on the same basis. If there is some special problem certainly I will seek some advice on the problem concerned.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the paper published on 1 October by Mr Clifford, the director of the Australian Institute of Criminology, which stated that the Aboriginal arrest and conviction rate was 726 per 100,000 head of population as against the white Australian rate of 60 per 100,000. In the light of this information, is the Government willing to reconsider the request from Aboriginal legal services for funds for a national secretariat to co-ordinate efforts to exchange information and draw on common experience to formulate policies for the future? Will the Government consider providing funds so that Aboriginal legal services can meet again on a national basis to discuss common experiences, exchange ideas, and formulate policies to enable them to ensure that they are better equipped to fight for and secure justice for Aboriginal people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no real relationship between the existence of a national secretariat and the kinds of outcomes which are needed for Aboriginal people to obtain equality before the law. In speeches I gave earlier this year and in speeches which my predecessors have given, attention has been drawn to the kind of disadvantage to which Aboriginals are subjected in terms of their legal experience. Nothing that Mr Clifford said in his address is news to us. It is because of that kind of experience and that situation that we have been involved in a number of initiatives. In fact, I think we encouraged the Institute of Criminology to take a greater interest in Aboriginal experiences before the law in the hope that it could make constructive suggestions.

ANSWER.PARA: It is because of that kind of experience that we have steadily increased our commitment. For example, this financial year the commitment to Aboriginal legal services goes up 20 per cent. The Government is aware of the problem and is aware of the need for Aboriginals to have legal services which are accessible to them and to which they feel they can respond. We have been involved in a major way in funding legal services. Last year 75,000 cases were dealt with through Aboriginal legal services. They operate 11 legal services out of 42 offices across Australia. I just wish that Senator Ryan would draw attention to that network when she asks this kind of question. Of course we are aware of the figures and of course that is why the Government responds in the active way that it does.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources to the latest survey of the economy undertaken by the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research economists which suggests that an increasing proportion of retail sales is drawing on imports. Will the Minister indicate specifically how much of private final demand is being met from imports rather than from current domestic production? Is the Minister aware that if this trend continues it will prohibit growth of Australian manufacturing industries and prevent thousands of Australians from obtaining jobs? Is the Government deliberately turning a blind eye to this trend in order to satisfy the whims of the farmers, who desperately want to see a devaluation of the Australian dollar?

—As to the latter part of the question, the Government could scarcely have turned a blind eye since the movement of the Australian dollar over recent months and years has been upwards and not by way of devaluation. That part of the question needs no reply. The first part of the question requires specific statistical information which I do not have. I am not aware of the specific volume of the inflow of commodities for retail trade. I will seek out the information and let the honourable senator have a response. It is the Government's desire, consistent with maintaining a downward pressure on inflation, to maintain-as we have-our position as a trading nation in the world and to ensure that there is a growth in employment-making opportunities in Australia. We will proceed to do that.

I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to two recent media reports which have dealt with the further pacification of East Timorese by the arrival of another 8,000 Indonesian troops. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that the Minister for Foreign Affairs is aware of reports of what does appear to be a relatively extensive security operation in East Timor. Some reports also claim that this operation will result in a famine in East Timor owing to disruption to crop planting prior to the rainy season. Fretelin guerrilla remnants are reported to be still hostile towards the authorities in East Timor. As Senator Kilgariff mentioned, the chairman of a Senate committee was asked a question on this matter. ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government, of course, has very high standards with regard to human rights. I think our standards are well known internationally and to the Indonesian Government. He is not in a position to comment on the authenticity of that report. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September last Senator Bonner asked me a question on an article which appeared in the Australian Financial Review relating to a report by the Bank of America on energy in Australia. I indicated in my response that I would get some supplementary information. I have a brief amount of supplementary information which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: As foreshadowed in my comments to the Senate, the report is generally bullish about Australia's energy prospects and comments on a number of energy policy issues. However, the report misinterprets the Australian position on a number of policy matters, and is deficient in that it appears to disregard almost totally the rights and roles of the States in the formulation and administration of resource development and energy policies. The Press article referred to by Senator Bonner appears to misquote at least some of the views expressed in the Bank of America report. Specifically the Financial Review states that the report said 'Australia's adoption of import parity pricing for oil will lead only to a misallocation of resources unless corrected'. I would point out to the Senate that what the Bank of America report actually said was that import parity pricing for oil only would result in a misallocation of resources, i.e., 'world' prices for oil but low domestic prices for gas and electricity would result in excess demand for, and a rapid depletion of reserves of, other energy resources especially natural gas.

Australian crude oil prices are set at import parity prices so as to reflect the real value of that resource and to avoid the wasteful use of the resource. The benefits of the policy have been spelled out at length, and are generally recognised. If other energy resources were priced too low relative to oil then there could be 'excessive' substitution. I have said on earlier occasions that gas prices should be low enough to encourage substitution away from oil but high enough to encourage new exploration and development. Generally, new gas contracts are being written at prices which conform to that broad principle. As senators would be aware, that pricing issue is one for the States and for the private sector. Similarly, the issue of electricity pricing is mainly a matter for the States.

The report suggests a need for a comprehensive energy plan. This ignores the fact that Australia has a 'free market' economy. Fundamental to the Government's energy policy is the use of the market framework. As has been stated on many occasions, we do not consider that it is the Government's role to dictate the precise future path along which energy producers and consumers should move. The Commonwealth does, of course, have a comprehensive energy policy as distinct from an 'energy plan'-which is both well known and which has been well received. As a result of that policy, first spelled out fully in 1979, Australia now has the prospect of continued high levels of self-sufficiency in liquid fuels for at least the rest of the decade and hopefully beyond that. The policy has also given impetus and support to the general development of Australia's energy resources whether for domestic use or for the export market.

The question related to the suspension of export operations of independent boning rooms in Victoria and the stand down of employees and possible loss of wages. I have received an answer from the Minister for Primary Industry as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I suspended the registration of these establishments subsequent to a further finding of horsemeat in product shipped from Establishment No. 622, Jason Meats Pty Ltd of the Melbourne suburb of Abbotsford. This action was necessary to assure meat importing countries that the situation in Victoria-were the problem seemed to be centred-was under control. It was necessary to demonstrate that action was adequate to ensure substitution was no longer possible.

The way was open, by compliance with the new controls, for resumption of export activities with minimum delay. In fact 28 of the establishments affected have already done so and had their suspension notices removed.
The security and control conditions which applied initially to the Victorian independent boning rooms were rapidly imposed on all other independent boning rooms through Australia.

Without the prompt and firm action taken by the Government, it is certain that a far more serious reaction against Australian meat exports generally would have resulted. This would in turn have had extremely serious repercussions for the meat industry and on employment throughout Australia.
