DEBATE.TITLE: PUBLIC INQUIRIES INTO TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND POSTAL SERVICES IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) in the House of Representatives two or three weeks ago made a statement announcing inquiries into telecommunications and postal services in Australia. The first matter was a result of the so-called razor gang report. In the course of that report the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced that a major review would be undertaken of the activities of the Australian Telecommunications Commission to determine the extent to which the services it offered might be more effectively provided by the private sector. There was also at the time of the so-called Review of Commonwealth Functions a decision to conduct a review into the services of Australia Post and particularly to examine the scope, as it was put, for reducing or eliminating the monopoly powers of the Australian Postal Commission. Both of these inquiries are under way. The terms of reference have been announced. The terms of reference are consistent with the statements made at the time of the so-called razor gang report. In the statement we are now dealing with the Minister put it in these terms:

An issue to be considered is the extent to which private enterprise involvement in those areas of Telecom's activities now protected from competition could result in a more efficient and economic service to the public.

I want to deal first with the question of the proposed inquiry into Telecom because in the Minister's words it is concerned with seeing how it can be made a more efficient and economic service to the public. The solution, adopted as a matter of ideological preference by the Government, is one of deciding that Telecom could be made more efficient and provide a more economic service to the public as a result of the intrusion of private enterprise into areas of Telecom's traditional work. Of course in ideological terms the whole case for involvement of private enterprise in telecommunications work in Australia has been orchestrated for some time both by the hardliners in the Government, the Frasers as distinct from the Peacock type faction. As I have said, that philosophy has been long articulated and the whole scene has been orchestrated by this Government in relation to the proposal for this inquiry. The Government says that it is concerned and believes that private enterprise can provide better services in a variety of areas than can public enterprises. The Government says that the way to cure alleged deficiencies in Telecom is to provide private enterprise competition in its most profitable areas.
In the course of my remarks I wish to examine whether this Government is fair dinkum or a phoney in its expressed concern for the efficiency of the telecommunications system in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder on which side you will come down.

—Senator Lewis might wonder on which side I will come down. If the honourable senator interrupts me I will come right down on him. This is the person who wanders around Victoria answering questions about delays in telephone services and the person who describes himself, if you please, as the Government representative-the Government representative in Ballarat; the Government representative in Bendigo. I am surprised Senator Lewis does not wear dark glasses when he goes to these places and talks about himself in that vein. I take it that Senator Lewis, as a backwoodsman of the Liberal Party, one of those who came into this place on the coat-tails of the Prime Minister and one of those who will go out on the same coat-tails when the revolution in the Liberal Party is finally consummated, is one of those people who are concerned about, in the Minister's words, the efficient and economic services of Telecom.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing which happened and which illustrates that there is concern about the efficient and economic services of Telecom was the presentation to the Minister for Communications in June last year of a report by the McKinsey organisation on the Capital and Policy Requirements for the 1980s of Telecom Australia. That report is very concerned about the efficiency of Telecom. In essence, if I may summarise, that report says that by international standards Telecom is an efficient provider of telecommunications services. But it says-presumably the Government wanted the organisation to say this-that those communications services could be provided by Telecom better than they have been provided in the past. The report was not uncritical of Telecom, of its attitude to the provision of new services and of its attitude to indicating the services which it makes available to the public.

I will move on to the thrust of the report. Senator Lewis has now lost interest. He has a great distaste for taking medicine as distinct from taking lumps of sugar handed out to him in the division of Wannon. I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) whether he would be good enough to have a look at the McKinsey report on the capital and planning requirements for Telecom which I now table. I recommend this document for careful reading by those Government senators who, unlike Senator Lewis, might be described as literate. If someone would care to read it to him he would find that the McKinsey organisation recommends an 8 per cent increase in capital moneys available for investment by Telecom in new equipment and so on so that by the year 1990 the increase in the capital available to Telecom will be some $75m.

That is the basic recommendation which the McKinsey report makes. The words which recur again and again in the McKinsey report are the same words as the Minister for Communications used in his statement-efficiency and productivity. What that report is saying is that at a time when there was the greatest backlog in the last two decades in meeting the needs of applicants for new telephone services in Australia with delays of up to 12 months when in fact there was the lowest demand for new telephone services this Government has adopted a policy towards Telecom which has led to inefficiency insofar as Telecom can be described as inefficient in the words of the McKinsey report-I emphasise for the benefit of Senator Lewis that that is in the words of the McKinsey report-and has resulted in a decline in efficiency and productivity in Telecom. Those are the findings of a report commissioned by this Government in conjunction with Telecom and made available to the Government in June last year.

Telecom, as honourable senators will know, I think, is the largest employer in Australia, a capital intensive funded organisation, with a considerable profit level, and a very large enterprise by any standards. I would have thought that it was an organisation to which the Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, might have applied the words which he used in his address when speaking at the National Press Club two years ago. The Prime Minister made the point that the Liberal Party believes in public debate about issues of public importance and he said there can be no real public debate unless information is available. So the Liberal Party under Malcolm Fraser believes in the publication of information about great national instrumentalities such as Telecom. But it does not believe that when it comes to this report. The words of the Prime Minister remind me of these words in Hamlet:
My words fly up, my thoughts remain below. Words without thoughts never to heaven go.

I remind Senator Lewis that the words of the Prime Minister are words without thoughts because when it comes to the hard thoughts about publishing a report which is critical of this Government for the miserly policies which it has adopted towards Telecom and which have led to inefficiency and a comparative lack of productivity, the Government is strangely reticent about it. Of course, the point is that since the report was given to the Government-no action has been taken on it-the capital requirements of Telecom have increased and the capital available to Telecom has declined. There has been a 16 per cent decline in capital available to Telecom since this Government came to power. This is quite contrary to the recommendations of the McKinsey report. Every time any Liberal member of this Senate answers a letter from a constituent as to why he cannot get a new phone service, if that honourable senator has read the McKinsey report and answers that question honestly, he will say: 'There is the biggest delay in the provision of new phone services in Australia in two decades because of this Government's policies; the policies of the Government to which I belong'. That is how Government senators will answer letters from constituents asking why phone services have been delayed. That is the essence of what the McKinsey report is saying.

Just look at what has happened since the McKinsey report was made available to this Government which believes, as it says, in public discussion about important national issues. The interest rate paid by Telecom on existing loans has been raised. Telecom's borrowing capacity has been more strictly limited than ever. As I said earlier, the delays in connecting new telephone services have grown steadily. At the end of this financial year 112,000 Australians will be waiting for phone installations-15,000 more than last year, although there is a projected drop in demand. Some people are now waiting a year for telephone installations. If Senator Lewis likes to study the figures when he goes to Ballarat he will know that many people are waiting for telephones there. I wonder what answer he gives them there. I know what answer he gives them in the Ballarat Courier. Perhaps he can dress it up a bit after he has read the McKinsey report.

There are long delays in people getting calls through, especially in Queensland and northern New South Wales. Often people have to wait hours just to get a dial tone on the telephone services in those areas. Last financial year Telecom was able to satisfy only 82 per cent of applicants for new phones. Next year it is estimated that the figure will fall to 79 per cent. Telecom has made it clear that government interference with its policies actually caused the Telecom price rises earlier this year. Look what else happened to Telecom, a great national enterprise, at the hands of a government which allegedly believes in business efficiency and which, sticking on its ideological blinkers, says that private enterprise is inherently more efficient than public enterprise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—'Hear, hear' bleats Senator Martyr from Western Australia. We are talking about telephones basically and not sheep dips or something which excites the honourable senator's attention. Let us look at what has happened to Telecom at the hands of this Government which says it believes in business efficiency. Telecom is the largest business in Australia. The term of the last Chairman of Telecom, Mr Bob Somervaille, expired some 15 months ago. Mr Somervaille, the Chairman of Telecom, a corporate lawyer from Sydney, was not reappointed and no replacement has been appointed to the chairmanship of Telecom at the hands of this Government for 15 months. There have been all sorts of rumours striking terror into the hearts of anybody engaged in telecommunications in Australia, such as the story that Mr Staley might be appointed chairman. But no appointment has been made for 15 months.

SPEECH.PARA: The General Manager of Australia's largest business, Mr Jack Curtis, retired after the Government's crude handling of the pay negotiations with Telecom employees a few months ago. Mr Curtis, the General Manager, has not been replaced by this Government. On 29 June, after the announcement that there would be a public inquiry into Telecom but before the appointment of the committee, the Minister for Communications announced that parts of the main communications network might be sold. This pre-empted the inquiry, which is the third inquiry into Telecom since 1979. So much for the Government of all efficiencies. Of course, sale of the profitable parts of Telecom will mean the end of its cross-subsidisation policy, a policy which I would have thought would bring joy to the hearts of Senator Lewis's rural constituents. Under this policy Telecom has used its high profits from eastern seaboard traffic to subsidise country services, last year amounting to $230m. The end of this could mean that country subscribers pay an extra $200 a year rental merely for having a phone on. I remind the Senate of the cost of new phone connections in remote areas.

The other important thing to remember about Telecom is that it is a great supporter of Australian manufacturing industry. As a matter of policy 80 per cent of Telecom equipment is Australian made. This is a policy which this Government decided a month ago to do away with. So much for its concern about Australian manufacturing industry. In an answer, which I got today, to a question to the Minister for Communications he said that last year Telecom purchased 90 per cent of its equipment from Australian manufacturing industry. It is not just the employees of Telecom and the thousands of subscribers, or potential subscribers who are waiting for new telephone services throughout Australia, who are concerned about this issue; it is a substantial section of Australian manufacturing industry in the electronic area which supplies Telecom with equipment. These are the matters which have to be faced up to in looking at the continuation of services provided by great public enterprises such as Telecom.

There is no point in considering the future of Telecom if the Government, in a craven and cowardly way, is going to hide the findings of a report such as the McKinsey, as it has done for 15 months, and if it is going to act quite contrary to the recommendations of that report so that less efficiency and less productivity results. Of course, what we have here are grounds for suspicion that in order to fulfil its bizarre and neanderthal ideological commitments to private enterprise at any price, this Government has embarked on a deliberate course of weakening the efficiency and productivity of Telecom, weakening its capacity to carry on its services. It has done this deliberately in order to encourage public dissatisfaction with the telecommunications system in this country so that the powerful donors to the Liberal Party, associated with certain companies can gain Telecom's more profitable work. It has done that as part of a deliberate course of action. There are only two choices. Either it is a deliberate course of action to damage Telecom because of the circumstances I have suggested or it is an example of gross incompetence by a government which says it has a commitment to efficiency. They are the only two options. There are no other options available to the Fraser Government in terms of explaining the course of conduct upon which it has embarked in relation to Telecom and its attitude to the publication of the McKinsey report.

This is a very serious indictment of this Government. It is a matter which has not been debated in this Parliament. It will be debated but it has not been debated in this Parliament to date, as I said, because of the secrecy of the Government and its forked tongue about its commitment to free information and free exchange of ideas and yet its total secrecy in relation to the affairs of a great public enterprise such as Telecom. Those are matters with which this Senate has to be concerned. We are, of course, not opposed to the establishment of such inquiries, insofar as one cannot oppose legitimate inquiries. We are opposed to the assumptions which underlie these inquiries, assumptions which have fallen glibly from the mouth of the Minister concerned in relation to both matters and also, of course, from that collection of chartered accountants and drop-outs from small business which constituted the so-called razor gang or ministerial inquiry into Commonwealth Government functions.

The glib ideology which has fallen from those people is the basis upon which these inquiries have been set up. A government which sets up inquiries of this kind, when it has failed to act on the report of the last important inquiry, the McKinsey inquiry into Telecom, is one which is governing by inquiry rather than by action, which is condoning inefficiency, and which is encouraging lack of productivity in its own enterprises and, indeed, in the largest enterprise this country has.

We will be happy to debate these issues in the Senate if anyone on the Government side wants us to do so, but I do not believe that many Government supporters understand the issues. That is a tragedy for Australia and for this Parliament. That is why I have moved that the Senate take note of this paper.

I commend this statement by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) to all Queenslanders for early reading. A statement that one would have expected would lead to an explanation and solution of the problems that Queenslanders, especially those who reside in Brisbane, now face, proves to be nothing more than an explanation without a solution. Because of a shortage of air traffic controllers, the Brisbane Airport is now closed at 9 p.m. That curfew has been imposed because, in a major airport of Australia in one of the major cities of Australia, there are not sufficient air traffic controllers to allow the continuation of air traffic until 10.30 p.m. or 11 p.m.

Notwithstanding what the Minister has said in his statement, considerable chaos exists for those who travel from the south to Brisbane on any night of the week. The airlines, in an attempt to have their craft land before 9 o'clock, have to reschedule flights to Sydney. It is a considerable inconvenience to people in Sydney to find that some flights have been cancelled and that they must wait to be re-booked on other flights in order to conform with the curfew.

The statement exposes the fact that the Department of Transport has been negligent. On a brief reading of the statement no other conclusion can be reached than that, for a period, the Department of Transport did not anticipate the needs of Australian aviation and in particular those of the Brisbane Airport. That problem has been before the Estimates committees on two occasions that I can recall in the last couple of years. Why the shortage? Why was not the Department able to anticipate the growth in aviation in Australia and make the necessary arrangements to train air traffic controllers? Apparently, because of the shortage of air traffic controllers in Australia, the conditions under which they worked became too strenuous and difficult. Long hours had to be worked and, as the statement reveals, there was an increase in resignations and in the scarcity of controllers because of the problem of ill health. The Minister's statement uses those two factors as an excuse but, in fact, they were caused by the failure of the Department of Transport to train sufficient personnel. The shortage led to unduly harsh conditions-to the risk of air travellers generally. Those harsh conditions, in turn, led to resignations by controllers seeking overseas posts and to resignations due to ill health. The reasons given for the shortage of air traffic controllers do not read well. According to the Minister, since the early 1970s the total number of air traffic controllers in Australia has increased from just over 1,000 to the present level of 1,156. He says that although we have a shortage we have more air traffic controllers than we had in the past. That is a absurd position to face. We have had an increase of 100 in numbers, but we still have a shortage. I repeat: That shortage results from the fact that, for some reason or another, over a period no additional air traffic controllers were trained. That failure is not properly explained in the statement. For a whole two years, if I read the paper correctly, no air traffic controllers were trained.

The wastage in Queensland was 8 per cent and that throughout Australia was 3.5 per cent. The higher figure in Queensland resulted from the Department of Transport's refusal to recognise the problem that existed. Despite constant complaints by aircraft controllers in the Brisbane area no action was taken. In turn, a shortage which was bad became one that led to the closure of the airport at 9 p.m. According to the Minister's statement, it will be almost two years before the situation is corrected. That is appalling, when considered from the point of view of an air traveller, expecially one proceeding to Brisbane. Possibly for two years we will suffer a shortage of controllers which will lead to the curtailment of services into Brisbane. The only saving grace is that Queensland, because of one of the many quaint positions taken by the Queensland Premier, does not propose to fall into line with other States in regard to daylight saving.

TALK.START.PARA: —Daylight saving makes the curtains fade.

—It also fades the paint on houses and disturbs the cows because, apparently, the sun gets up either too late or too early-I am not quite certain which-but I should not permit myself to be diverted. This is the only instance in which the absence of daylight saving will be of benefit to Queenslanders. During the period of daylight saving elsewhere there will not be a need for a curfew because all planes will arrive in Queensland one hour earlier. In that way, they can escape the 9 o'clock curfew. Thus, for six months the Department of Transport will get a reprieve, but when that period is over we will be back to the position we are in at present.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is to be a shortage of air traffic controllers in Australia the impact of that shortage should be spread across every State. It seems to me to be very unreasonable that Brisbane should be selected as the one place to suffer. I thought it would be possible to transfer personnel to the Brisbane area. One also has to look a little more closely at the conditions which have applied to controllers. I do not think that is the reason that there is a shortage. The reason is that the Department of Transport has failed to train any personnel whatsoever for two years. The Department and the Minister have to answer for that. Why did they fail to train people during that period? Why did they fail to anticipate the growth of the aviation industry? The airline companies could have told them of their expectations and what the growth pattern would be. The explanation should not just be accepted and passed to one side.

The Minister and the Department should be brought under close scrutiny as to why this situation developed and why it will take so long to recover. There has been an appalling lack of effort and initiative. At a time of high unemployment in this country and when youngsters, both male and female, have been finding it difficult to obtain work, here is one department which has failed to carry out a training program. One would have to ask the Department, if there is a shortage of personnel, why it has not investigated the possibility of training and employing women in this area. I cannot for the life of me accept or understand how a department could fail to train people when so many are seeking this sort of work. It is reasonably skilled work but it would not be beyond the capacity of many youngsters, both male and female, who are seeking work.

I hope that the Department can overcome the problem that it faces. It seems to be that it has not anticipated the rapid growth of the industry. The statement indicates that there has been an increase in training and a greater intake of personnel. Nevertheless, one cannot escape from the fear that the industry will grow faster than even these innovations. For that reason, I will seek leave to continue my remarks later but suggest that close attention be paid to the statement and that from time to time questions be asked of the Minister as to what progress is being made to correct what I consider to be a disgraceful situation. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

Whilst the report from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is welcomed by the Opposition, in that it does document some programs which are being funded by the Federal Government to improve the situation of Aboriginal Australians, it is an unsatisfactory document to the extent that it does not give the Australian public an overall idea of the circumstances facing Aboriginal Australians today. It presents a catalogue of Government programs and of the money spent on Aboriginals in the last financial year. It presents a rosy picture of Government action to improve the lot of Aboriginal Australians. It fails to give a comprehensive review of the problems still facing the Aboriginal community in Australia. Because of that it is impossible to derive from the report any idea of the real progress that is being made to solve those problems. For example, whilst details are provided of all housing programs which benefit Aboriginals, we are given no indication of how many houses remain to be provided before all Australian Aboriginals have acceptable standards of housing. The Government has been insisting lately that we present a balanced picture of what is happening with regard to Aboriginal affairs. If we are to have a balanced understanding of the progress that is being made towards providing housing for Australian Aboriginals, then we really need to know how many are still without housing as well as how many have been assisted in gaining housing in the last financial year.

There are some developments described in the report on which I would like to comment briefly. The first relates to the establishment of the Aboriginal Development Commission. The Federal Australian Labor Party is, in general, supportive of the establishment of the Aboriginal Development Commission because it is established according to the principle of independence and self-management for Aboriginal people. However, I must sound a note of warning here that the Aboriginal Development Commission has taken on a huge task. It has taken on the task of providing assistance to all the Aboriginal enterprises throughout Australia and of providing special Aboriginal housing loans to a large number of eligible people. In both cases-we must be frank about this-the Commission has inherited many problems.

We would like to see the Commission succeed. We would like to see it as a statutory body which has the confidence of Aboriginal people in both its policies and its administration. Unless the Government is prepared to provide the Commission with adequate resources to carry out its charter it will not gain the confidence of its Aboriginal clients and it will, I believe, become overwhelmed by the administrative problem of trying to make too small a cake go too far. We would like to see a more realistic allocation of resources to the Aboriginal Development Commission if it is to carry out its charter. Of course, we agree with the charter.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—I do not think that it is very helpful of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to call out by way of interjection: 'How much?' Obviously, the occasion of commenting on an annual report is not an occasion for us to put up our alternative budget for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. We will do that in due course. We will certainly do it before the next Federal election. I look forward to hearing the Minister's comments at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: The report also documents the transferral of State grants for Aboriginal housing from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to the Department of Housing and Construction and the transferral of local government and municipal type functions for the Northern Territory Aboriginal settlements from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to the Northern Territory Government as of 1 July 1980. These developments reflect the fact that departmental functions are being eroded. If the functions are to go to Aboriginal organisations, such as the Aboriginal Development Commission or the National Aboriginal Conference, it is, in principle, a good thing. But if functions are being transferred from the Federal Department to unsympathetic State or Territory governments it will be a backward step for Aboriginal advancement and self-determination. I say quite directly that transferring functions to the Northern Territory Administration is transferring functions to a less sympathetic and, in respect of some activities, quite hostile administration and is not, therefore, in the interests of Aboriginal people.

The report comments on settlement of land claims. It points out that title deeds to Warlpiri, Alyawarra and Uluru land claim areas have been issued and that a title deed to the Borroloola Common has been prepared for issue. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) has also announced that he will accept the recommendations of the Aboriginal Land Commissioner to grant title deed to Aborigines for Utopia and Willowra pastoral leases. I remind the Senate that the Rowlands report was tabled in Parliament on 18 November 1980. According to page 6 of the annual report discussions have taken place with land councils and the Northern Territory Government 'about possible means of overcoming a number of practical difficulties in the operation of the Northern Territory Land Rights Act'. The report fails to mention that the Northern Territory Government is hostile to many provisions of the Land Rights Act and has attacked the operation of the Land Rights Act in a hostile fashion. The report fails to address itself to the serious situation regarding Aboriginal land in Queensland and in the case of Western Australia restricts itself to a sketchy outline of the Noonkanbah incident. I must comment that this is hardly an adequate coverage of what is the most important issue facing Aborigines in Australia today.

With regard to the makarrata or the concept of a proposed treaty between the Australian Government and Aboriginal people, the report states that the National Aboriginal Conference completed an initial round of consultations with Aboriginal and Islander communities and published an interim report on 2 July 1980. Discussions and consultations on the makarrata will continue. I must point out that an enormous task of consultation and negotiation is ahead of any government which is really serious about, firstly, developing the machinery to establish a treaty between the Australian Government and the Aboriginal people and, secondly, negotiating the terms of such a treaty. The Government has taken on no small exercise.

Again I sound a note of warning that if the Government thinks that this is something the NAC can do in its spare time and that some treaty or agreement can be quickly arrived at which will solve the problem of the injustice done to the Aboriginal people when Australia was colonised by the British, the Government is seriously mistaken. If the Government is serious about evolving machinery for a treaty and negotiating the terms of a treaty, it will have to be prepared to put a lot of time and resources into this exercise. In relation to broadcasting, the report documents assistance given to the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association and assistance given to public broadcasting stations which provide for regular Aboriginal programs. In both of these developments I am happy to say that the Opposition is in agreement with the Government.

In the case of employment, the report does give some indication of the unacceptably high levels of unemployment amongst Aborigines. It estimates that 36 per cent of the estimated Aboriginal work force is unemployed, and I think this is a conservative estimate. Certainly, in this area we do not know the full extent of the problem and it is an area in which there is scope for government action to increase Aboriginal employment. In particular I have put forward in this place on a number of occasions the view that the Government should have an active policy of providing for Aboriginal employment within the public sector. During the recent Estimates committee discussions in the Senate I regularly questioned officers from various departments on their policies regarding the employment of Aboriginal people. At this stage I can say only that there is very little by way of a genuine assertive policy to encourage departments to place and train Aboriginal people within their staff establishments. Until the Government is determined that it will provide employment opportunities for Aboriginal people I think these very high rates of Aboriginal unemployment which are documented in the Department's annual report will continue and, in the present employment situation, will grow worse.

In the area of housing the report documents the implementation of government programs. It fails to document the need which still exists in this area. For instance, the report of the World Council of Churches documents a survey taken in Queensland in 1979 which showed that 64 per cent of Aboriginal housing was totally unacceptable, that 34 per cent of Aboriginal housing was acceptable but in urgent need of repair and that 3 per cent only of Aboriginal housing was on a par with normal white Australian standards. That is the sort of picture I think we must have if we are to make a realistic assessment of the work being done by the Department. I do not wish to denigrate the good work being done by the Department and by the many dedicated officers within the Department, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal. However, in the areas on which I have commented and in other areas, such as health and welfare, on which I will not comment because of time limitations, I think it would be more helpful and more conducive to the development of a truly bipartisan approach to Aboriginal issues if the annual reports of the Department gave the full picture and not simply the statistics about things that have been done. If we are going to set long term policy objectives and long term program objectives I think we need more information than that which is currently presented in the report of the Department.

The 1980-81 annual report of the Department of Housing and Construction is, if nothing else, a rather extraordinary document. On the one hand it refers constantly to the value of the construction and housing industries in the Australian economy generally. On the other hand it frequently reports the fact that the Department of Housing and Construction is having to change its operations to accommodate changing government policy. From the tone of the report it seems that it is not exactly happy to be forced into that position. A reading of this annual report induced at least in me a sense of overwhelming frustration which must have been felt by the Department as it was forced into curtailing activities it sees as being very influential and beneficial to the Australian economy. The language the report uses is considerably restrained but this serves merely to add to that sense of frustration. For instance, page 10 of the report, under the heading 'Looking ahead' states:

The Department looks back on a year of efficient administration of the Government's housing policy and programs and a multi-million dollar construction program which involved many varied and complex public works.
In the year ahead the Department faces a period of change and consolidation as it continues with its record of achievement and service to the Government and people of Australia.

I get the distinct impression that, if the author of this document were not being restrained, the last sentence rather would read: ' . . . the Department faces a period of change and consolidation as it continues to try to maintain its record of achievement and service to the Government and people of Australia'. The rest of this report clearly indicates the Department is not likely to succeed in that attempt. One wonders how the Government can reconcile some of its stated aims, as quoted in this report, with its actions which are also described in this document. I refer in particular to page 21 and the chapter headed 'Housing policy'. According to the report the Government aims to do the following:
ensure that every family in Australia is able to obtain adequate housing within its capacity to pay
encourage home ownership across the widest possible range of income groups, . . .
maintain and improve housing styles . . .
ensure that there are economic conditions within which a stable and adequate building industry can assist us to achieve our social goals.

One wonders how it does this when it continually cuts funding to the public housing sector, as it did this year, from something like $286m in 1980-81 to $262m in 1981-82 and limits through the razor gang recommendations various housing and construction functions including, as is pointed out on page 8, the monitoring of the building industry, housing costs and housing policy advice. How a government expects to be able to maintain an intelligent policy in regard to the building and construction industry when its very department is limited in offering it advice is beyond my comprehension. Furthermore, one wonders how the Government equates statements such as that on page 11 of the report with the present slump in the construction industry. Page 11 is the first page in the chapter entitled 'The industry and the economy'. It begins by making the following point:

The construction industry . . . makes a valuable contribution to the community through provision of physical facilities such as housing, schools, water supply, roads, aerodromes, shops, office buildings and factories. To this end very substantial resources of land, capital and labour are employed in the construction of the nation's physical infrastructure.

I pause at this point to ask whether the cover of this report is not somehow indicative of the disappearing part that the building and construction industry is playing in the Australian economy. Having made that first point, the report continues:

As almost all its inputs are domestically supplied, it has strong linkages to other sectors of the economy. Changes in activity levels in the industry can therefore have considerable significance for the economy as a whole.
That sentence bears repeating. Following straight on from that comes this statement:
The industry, in turn, is sensitive to change in general economic conditions and to the types of policies used by the Government to achieve its overall economic objectives . . .
Some paragraphs later the report adds this further rider:

Instability in the industry adds to costs as well as further destabilising other sectors of the economy. Rapid changes in the availability of housing finance also cause considerable welfare losses to the many homeowners seeking to change their dwelling as well as those who are hoping to buy their first home. The health, efficiency and stability of the dwelling construction sector is a major determinant of the extent to which people's housing needs are met.

One wonders how the Government equates these comments with the serious instability in the market presently induced by the Government's fiscal policies, in particular those relating to interest rates. Since interest rates are a predominant factor in people's accessibility to finance and hence their ability to purchase or to build a home, the problems which are besetting the banking community and the community generally are bound to cause problems in this, an extremely highly labour intensive area. The point is, of course, that the Government cannot equate these conflicting statements. As I said, the situation is exacerbated, too, by the ensuing damage that its conflicting attitudes to the building and construction market are inflicting on the labour market. Page 13 of the document makes this point:

According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics the construction industry directly employs about half a million people, some 8 per cent of the total employment in Australia. It is estimated that the jobs of a further 8 to 10 per cent are indirectly dependent upon the industry, being engaged in producing materials, parts, business, professional and transport services and so on. Altogether, more than one million workers (almost one in every six of those in employment) are dependent on the industry.

There is a higher component of self-employment in the industry than in many others. This reflects the prevalence of small sub-contracting firms in the industry, particularly among special trades in the housing sector.

The report goes on to tabulate those trades and skills which are employed in the industry. They range from professional and administrative people through to tradesmen. When one reads this report one must ask how on earth the Government can hope to engender fuller employment in Australia if it actively restrains the development of such a high employment industry. If this report does nothing else, it points out in appalling clarity the mess that this Government is getting itself into through ill thought out contradictory policies.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
