TALK.START.PARA: —(South Australia)-On behalf of the Publications Committee, I present its 7th report.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE FAMILY LAW ACT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-A joint select committee of the Parliament was appointed in September 1978 to inquire into, and report on, the provisions and operation of the Family Law Act 1975 and it presented its report to the Parliament on 28 August 1980. The comprehensive nature of the report bears witness to the hard work of the Committee and I would like, on behalf of the Government, to pay tribute to its efforts and to the very careful consideration it gave to the very important issues involved. There were dissenting reports, either in toto or related to specific matters, by certain members of the Committee and consideration has been given to the views expressed in them. Naturally attention has mainly been directed to the majority report.

SPEECH.PARA: Bearing that in mind, I think it is fair to say that the report gives clear support to the basic philosophy of the Family Law Act as it stands at present. The main thrust of the 72 recommendations in the report is to strengthen and extend the main features of the Act. For example, I note that the report does not recommend any retreat from the most fundamental change made by the Family Law Act. I refer to the abolition by the Act of the concept of 'matrimonial offences' as grounds for divorce, and their replacement by a single ground of divorce based on irretrievable breakdown of marriage as evidenced by 12 months separation. In this regard, I draw attention particularly to the Committee's conclusion that 'there is no necessary coincidence between the number of marriages that have broken down and the number of divorces'. The Committee went on to say that 'the effect of easier availability of divorce has the effect of closing the gap between the number of marriages that have been broken down in fact and those that are dissolved at law'.

Family law has traditionally been a non-party area in respect of which members of this Parliament have exercised individual judgments according to their consciences. The Government considers that this traditional approach should continue to be followed. For this reason, it is not appropriate that there should be an official Government response to the report's recommendations, other than those that impinge upon some area of general Government policy, such as those having implications for Government expenditure. Accordingly, the responses that are set out in the schedule that I will be seeking leave to have incorporated in Hansard at the conclusion of my statement are to be taken as expressing my own views, unless a particular response is so expressed as to indicate that it has been, or will be, the subject of a Government decision.

In dealing with the report's recommendations, I have divided them into two main categories-those involving legislation and those involving administrative or other mainly non-legislative action of some kind. I would like now specifically to mention some of the more important individual matters in those categories. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the detailed parts of this statement as I have just indicated them, and then I will read the conclusion.
Leave granted.
The statement continued-
RECOMMENDATIONS THAT WOULD INVOLVE LEGISLATION

Honourable Senators will recall that on 11 December 1980 I announced that the preparation of substantial amendments to the Family Law Act, the major purpose of which were to implement 24 of the Report's recommendations, had commenced. In fact, as a result of further consideration, the Family Law Amendment Bill 1981, will implement 27 of those recommendations. As I also announced in December 1980, in accordance with the non-party approach I have already referred to, Government members will exercise a free vote on the Bill.

I will canvass in detail those recommendations with which the Bill deals when I come to introduce it, but I would mention that, as will be seen from the Schedule, the great majority of the important legislative changes proposed by the Committee will be dealt with in the Bill, and accordingly it will constitute by far the most extensive reform of the Family Law Act since its enactment. The recommendations that will be dealt with in the Bill are numbers-2, 3, 10, 11, 18, 21, 25, 31 (g), 33, 34 (part), 35, 39, 40, 48, 50, 51, 52, 54, 59, 60, 61, 62, 63, 65, 66, 67, and 69.
I turn now to the small number of legislative recommendations that it has been decided, after due consideration, could not or should not be implemented in the Bill.
Recommendation 12-Finality of Custody Orders

Recommendation 12 proposes the insertion of a new provision in the Family Law Act requiring a court, in proceedings with respect to the custody or guardianship of a child of a marriage, as far as practicable to make such an order as would avoid further proceedings. All the available evidence suggests that, at the present time, courts, as a matter of common sense, make every attempt to make orders of the kind referred to in the recommendation. However, it is worth noting that custody orders, by their nature, have entirely future operation and therefore may be rendered inappropriate by future events. The Family Law Council, after considering this matter, has recommended against implementing the Committee's proposal, on the grounds that application to vary a custody order must always be allowed if circumstances warrant and the present requirement of significant change has not given rise to excessive litigation. Accordingly, it seemed to me that a provision of the kind proposed in the recommendation would probably serve little useful purpose and might, in fact, cause difficulty by introducing some rigidity in an area in which flexibility is more desirable. In any event, the problem with which the Committee appeared most concerned, namely, the repeated changing of custody as a result of reversals of decisions on appeal, is not solved by the recommendation, and it is difficult to see how this could be overcome except by an unacceptable limitation on rights of appeal.
Recommendation 13-Criteria for Custody Decisions

In recommendation 13, the Committee set out detailed criteria which it considered should be inserted in the Act and which a court would thus be required to take into account in deciding child custody cases. The Family Law Council has since examined this proposal in depth and has recommended against it on the ground that any regulation of courts' discretion in custody cases was undesirable. I have therefore concluded it is preferrable that the wide discretion of courts in this area should be retained.
Recommendation 22-Redraft of s.72

In recommendation 22 the Committee recommended a redraft of s.72 of the Family Law Act to eliminate what it saw as an 'ambiguity' in the existing provision. Examination of the issue by both the Family Law Council and my Department has led to the conclusion, that the ambiguity perceived by the Committee does not exist and that, accordingly, the proposed change is not necessary.
Recommendation 26-Redraft of s.75 (2) (1)

The apparent intention of the redraft of s.75 (2) (1) proposed in recommendation 26 was to improve the existing provision to make it clear that the frustration of the applicant's expectation of continuing to be a wife and/or mother is to be taken into account in maintenance proceedings. Examination of this, particularly by the Family Law Council, has led to the conclusion that the redraft proposed by the Committee does not achieve that result. Further, any other possible redraft would be likely to create as many problems as might be solved. It is also worth noting that the existing provision has not caused any particular problems in practice as far as I am aware.
Recommendation 27-Redraft of s.75 (2) (o)

The redraft of s.75 (2) (o) proposed in recommendation 27 would make the applicant's matrimonial conduct in general-not just such conduct having direct economic consequences-relevant in maintenance proceedings. Sensing that this recommendation had doubtless generated strong feelings amongst Committee members, other Honourable Senators and the public generally, I gave careful consideration to the matter and consulted at some length with both the Family Law Council and the Chief Judge of the Family Court before reaching a view.

It is basic to the philosophy of the Family Law Act that the concept of matrimonial conduct as such-as distinct from conduct relevant to particular issues-is no longer relevant in matrimonial proceedings. Implementation of this recommendation would amount to a pointed reintroduction of the examination of matrimonial conduct at large, and would undoubtedly be seen as an invitation in maintenance proceedings to bring up all alleged misconduct of the applicant however long ago and however irrelevant to the issues of maintenance. Any amendment having that result would to a substantial extent reopen the flood-gates to recrimination and counter-recrimination. This would lead to more protracted and costly proceedings, and to a consequent greater strain on limited Court and legal aid resources. It would also reintroduce the rejected notion that maintenance-or the witholding of it-might be used to punish the party 'guilty' of misconduct.

As far as conduct affecting the issue of maintenance is concerned, recent court decisions have clearly established that the conduct of one of the parties to maintenance proceedings that affected the economic circumstances of the other party can, in fact, be taken into account under the present provision. I believe that this is the limit of the extent to which conduct should be relevant. In reaching this decision, I have regard to the minority opposition of the recommendation within the Committee itself.
Recommendation 32-Redraft of s. 79A

The effect of the redraft of s. 79A proposed by recommendation 32 would be to widen substantially the grounds on which a property settlement order previously made by the court could subsequently be varied or set aside so as to enable this to be done wherever the court considered that there was 'just cause' for so doing. The present policy of the Act, as reflected in both the existing ss. 79AA and 81 is that, in the interests of the parties, property orders should be final and should be able to be varied or set aside only where the original order had been obtained by fraud, duress, false evidence or there had otherwise been a miscarriage of justice. The recommendation envisages a clear departure from this basic policy and would, I believe, be likely to encourage continuing relitigation of property disputes. In my view this would be against the interests of all concerned.

The Family Law Council made a recommendation to me for amendment of s. 79A which would allow property orders to be set aside or varied on grounds that are somewhat wider than at present, but which would be much more limited than that proposed in the Committee's recommendation. The additional grounds would relate to specific circumstances, for example, default of the respondent or substantial hardship to a child of the former marriage. Amendments based on the Family Law Council's recommendation are being considered for inclusion in the Family Law Amendment Bill.
Recommendation 34-Abatement of maintenance and property orders by death

Recommendation 34 calls for the Act to be amended to prevent the abatement of maintenance and property settlement proceedings by the death of the respondent. I accept that it is appropriate that property proceedings should survive the death of the respondent and an amendment to this effect will be included in the Family Law Amendment Bill. However, this is not appropriate in maintenance proceedings because the continuing nature of maintenance directly conflicts with the fact that there is no longer a continuing source of income. The Family Law Council has recommended to me that where the respondent dies the applicants' maintenance claims are more appropriately catered for under State or Territory legislation dealing with testators' family maintenance and I understand that in most, if not all, cases this is so.
Recommendation 38-Injunctions to protect property rights

The effect of recommendation 38 is that the Act should be amended to affirm the court's power to order an injunction in respect of matrimonial property prior to the entitlement of the party to seek a property settlement. In accordance with the spirit of recommendation 3, the Family Law Amendment Bill will provide for an extension of the Family Court's jurisdiction to enable it to deal with property settlement proceedings prior to proceedings for principal relief and thus the amendment proposed by this recommendation will not be necessary.
Recommendation 58-State courts of summary jurisdiction

In recommendation 58, the Committee proposed that the Act should be amended to provide for the exercise of federal family law jurisdiction in State courts of summary jurisdiction only by selected magistrates specifically appointed for the purpose by the Governor-General. Quite apart from the difficult question whether it would be constitutionally possible to do this by Commonwealth legislative action, it would amount to a serious unilateral interference with State court systems and thus would have complex practical problems. The Government has therefore decided that implementation of this recommendation would be very difficult and would, in any event, not be appropriate.
Recommendation 65-Power to award costs
Recommendation 65 calls for the giving to the Family Court of a ''wider discretion to order costs in proceedings under the Family Law Act.''

The basic principle of s.117 of the Act is that, in proceedings under the Act, each party should bear his or her own costs, subject to a discretion given to the court to make a costs order. In the recent decision in Penfold v Penfold, the High Court held that the discretion given to the court under s.117 to award costs is wider than hitherto was thought, and the Family Law Council has expressed the view that the Act should be amended to put this beyond doubt. Accordingly, I propose that the Family Law Amendment Bill should include an amendment to this effect. It may be that this is as far as the recommendation intended the Act should be amended. If, however, it intended that the basic principle to which I have referred should be abolished, then I do not favour it to that extent.
I turn now to the remaining legislative recommendations to which a final response cannot be provided.
Recommendation 5-Consolidation of Marriage and Family Law Acts

In recommendation 5, the Committee proposed a consolidation of the Marriage and Family Law Acts into one piece of legislation. One of the Committee's reasons for this-that it would assist in alerting those considering marriage of their responsibilities and the consequences of breakdown-appears to some extent not to accord with the view expressed elsewhere by the Committee. I have in mind the view of the Committee that 'the provisions of the divorce law are not a significant factor influencing marriage breakdown'.

In addition, the Committee's view that a consolidated Act would be more clearly based on the 'marriage' power under the Constitution than at present is not supported by the fact that a succession of High Court decisions has left no doubt that substantial provisions of the existing Family Law Act are supported by that power.

It needed to be considered whether the disadvantages of consolidation, namely, the considerable printing expenses and the extra administrative burden of dealing with what would be a large, unwieldly piece of legislation, would be outweighed by the benefits seen by the Committee.

The Family Law Council has considered the matter and expressed the view that there are both pragmatic and philosophical grounds for consolidating the 2 Acts and that the principle should be accepted in family law for the future. The Council did not, however, see it as a matter requiring immediate action.

Accordingly, I have accepted in principle the desirability of implementing the recommendation when an appropriate opportunity arises in the future. Given the size and cost of that task, however, and the number of other matters deserving of immediate attention, I have decided not to proceed with it for the present.
Recommendations 9, 17 & 28-Wardship jurisdiction and reduction of judicial discretion re maintenance

Recommendations 9 and 17 concern the proposed conferral of a wardship jurisdiction on the Family Court with respect to children; this has a number of difficult legal problems associated with it that require careful examination.

An ad hoc committee established by the Family Law Council under the chairmanship of Mr Justice Watson of the Family Court and including several members of the practising profession has since early 1980 been examining the questions raised by these recommendations.

Recommendation 28 proposes that the Family Law Regulations made under the Act prescribe specific amounts, subject to automatic adjustment, to be payable in respect of the maintenance of children. This would introduce a degree of rigidity in relation to a court's discretion which does not exist at present and it is desirable that there be a careful examination of how it would be likely to operate in practice. Accordingly, recommendation 12 is currently under detailed examination by the Family Law Council itself.
A decision on these recommendations has therefore been deferred pending receipt of the results of the deliberations of the Council and the Watson Committee.
Recommendation 8-Definition of terms concerning children

Recommendation 8 proposes that the terms 'guardianship', 'custody' and 'care and control' be uniformly defined in all Commonwealth and State legislation. The legal and policy aspects of this proposal are also under consideration by the Watson Committee established by the Family Law Council. As envisaged by the Parliamentary Committee, there will also have to be consultation with both my colleague the Minister for Social Security and State Governments about this. All in all, by its very scope, this recommendation cannot be proceeded with until these consultation processes have been completed, and clearly they will inevitably occupy some little time.
Recommendation 20-Disclosure of Government information

Recommendation 20 envisages the enactment of a requirement that Commonwealth departments and agencies disclose information for the purposes of enforcement of orders with respect to the custody of children. It will be appreciated that this raises difficult issues regarding confidentiality and personal privacy in relation to Government records. It may be that the forthcoming Report of the Australian Law Reform Commission regarding privacy will have something to say that is relevant to these issues. Furthermore the Government has undertaken to review the secrecy provision in legislation within 3 years of the coming into force of the freedom of information legislation. The recommendation will be the subject of a Government decision following a proposed joint submission to Cabinet by the Minister for Social Security and myself in due course.
Recommendations 23, 24 and 30-Social Security benefits and maintenance assessment and enforcement

Recommendation 30, which concerns the proposed establishment of a maintenance enforcement agency administered by the Department of Social Security has, together with the amendments to the Social Services Act proposed by recommendations 23 and 24, significant implications that require careful consideration, particularly in relation to the provision of administrative resources. The recommendations will therefore be the subject of Government decision following a joint submission to Cabinet by the Minister for Social Security and myself to be made as soon as practicable.
Recommendation 31-Maintenance enforcement

Recommendation 31 contains a number of detailed proposals for improving the system for the enforcement of maintenance orders, including amendments to the Family Law Regulations and to the Family Law Act and the Bankruptcy Act. Consideration of the proposed amendments to the Family Law Regulations by my Department and by the combined Family Law Council/Family Court Regulations Committee is proceeding and I would expect that appropriate amendments will be made in due course. Other legislative amendments are either included in the Family Law Amendment Bill 1981 or are the subject of interdepartmental consultation now taking place between my Department and the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs.
Recommendation 54-Family law in ACT

This recommendation supports the conferring on the Family Court, when sitting in the ACT, of as broad a family jurisdiction as possible. I have received a comprehensive report from a committee chaired by Mr Justice Ellis on what legislative and other steps are necessary to cause a comprehensive family jurisdiction to be exercised by the Family Court in the ACT. Its implementation involves amendment of a number of ACT ordinances. But, as a first step in responding to that report, a necessary enabling amendment to s.31 of the Family Law Act, which confers jurisdiction on the Family Court, will be included in the Family Law Amendment Bill.
Recommendation 68-Filing fee on divorce/nullity applications

Recommendation 68 calls for a reduction in the filing fee on application for divorce and nullity of marriage. The fixing of the amount of the fee, which has not been changed since 1977, is a matter for decision by the Government in the context of its consideration of the annual budget. I can do no more than say that when court fees, including this fee, are next being reviewed, the Committee's recommendation will be kept in mind.

The recommendation also proposed broadening the circumstances in which exemption from paying the fee can be claimed. In fact, they were broadened by way of an amendment to the Family Law Regulations in 1979 that appears to meet the complaint that gave rise to this particular recommendation.
ADMINISTRATIVE AND OTHER MAINLY NON-LEGISLATIVE RECOMMENDATIONS

Although the precise situation with respect to each of the recommendations is set out in the Schedule to which I shall come shortly, I should like to make specific reference to the more important non-legislative recommendations and the action that has been, or is being, taken in respect of them.
Recommendation 1-Reference of powers

I welcome the support given by the Committee in recommendation 1 to the proposed reference from the States to the Commonwealth of powers over disputes concerning maintenance and custody of certain children and certain husband and wife property disputes in respect of which the Commonwealth does not have the legislative power under the Constitution at present. Agreement on this question has taken and is still taking much longer than I had hoped or expected. The Senate may be assured that I am as anxious as the Committee obviously was to see this matter resolved.
Recommendations 4 and 41-Dual judicial commissions

The possibility of certain State and Federal Judges holding dual commissions to enable the exercise of what the Committee referred to in recommendation 4 as a 'unified jurisdiction in family law matters throughout Australia' does involve a number of legal and administrative problems of substantial magnitude, particularly related to the differences between the terms and conditions of service of State and Federal Judges. I have been actively considering the matter and may need to consult at length with each of my State counterparts. But, to some extent, the need for this will hopefully be reduced by the proposed reference of powers to the Commonwealth to which I referred a moment ago.

I have had discussions over some years with the Attorney-General of Western Australia regarding the question of dual commissions for Judges of the Family Court of that State, as recommended in recommendation 41, and the matter is still under consideration because of the difficulties I mention.
Recommendation 7-Arrangements for welfare of children

In accordance with recommendation 7, I have asked the Institute of Family Studies to research and report on the question of court-approved arrangements regarding the welfare of children on the divorce of their parents and related matters.
Recommendation 19-Family Court Marshals and Deputy Marshals

In recommendation 19, the Committee proposed the appointment under s. 37 of the Act of a Marshal and Deputy Marshals of the Family Court in each State and registry of the Court respectively. At present, officers of the Australian Federal Police hold these appointments, and I am informed that members of that force provide, within the limits of their resources, a satisfactory and useful service to the Court in the performance of police-type tasks, such as the execution of warrants. If persons were appointed full-time to such positions, it is difficult to see what useful role they would perform without resources such as those at the command of the Australian Federal Police. Having regard to the Government's present program of Public Service staff reductions, the provision of back-up resources of the kind I have mentioned to replace the police is out of the question. I consider that it would be far more efficient to utilize the Court's available resources for more pressing purposes, such as additional counselling and registry facilities, than for the appointment of a full-time Marshal and Deputy Marshals. Accordingly, the Government has decided against implementing the recommendation.
Recommendation 14, 15, 16 and 45-Pre-trial procedures

Recommendations 14, 15, 16 and 45 all propose or relate to the mandatory use of pre-trial conferences and other related procedures in contested cases concerning children or property. The reduction of such cases going to fully-contested court hearings by the use of counselling and conferences has been one of the basic aims of the Family court since its inception and it has achieved, and is continuing to achieve, a great measure of success. These procedures are now used in the great majority of contested cases of the kind referred to. For instance, in the calendar year ending 31 December 1980, I am informed that 56,000 persons took advantage of the court counselling service. Accordingly, the spirit of the recommendations is continuing to be followed by the Family Court within the necessary constraints of the resources that can realistically be made available to it.

The Family Law Council has expressed opposition to these recommendations, insofar as they imply achieving the desired ends by legislation, on the grounds that these matters relate to the administration of the Court, and should be left to judicial policy and discretion. The Council also pointed out that the spirit of the recommendations is being achieved already by these means. In addition, I mention that the Council is currently undertaking a review of all pre-trial procedures.
Recommendation 46, 47 and 55-Family Court Resources

These recommendations all relate to the proposed provision of registry and counselling facilities in regional areas. The Government accepts this as a desirable aim and will continue to move towards the appropriate provision of Family Court facilities in areas that need them as resources permit. The Government regards the provision of counselling services in particular as being of priority importance in view of the undoubted success of the counselling service in achieving settlements by conciliation and a consequent significant reduction in the overall work of the Court, the cost to parties and savings for legal aid.

My Department and the Family Court is keeping under constant review the need for provision of resources to the Court, ways in which those resources can be most efficiently used and the most effective geographical spread of those resources. An example of this is provided by the severe problems that were being experienced by the volume of work being carried on in the Melbourne Registry of the Court. The provision of additional resources, particularly counsellors, to that registry together with praise-worthy efforts by the judges and the staff at the registry has achieved a dramatic turn around in the delays there.

As far as Darwin and Alice Springs are concerned, the Government accepts that it is ultimately desirable that registries of the Family Court be established in such centres and this will be kept in mind for the future. In the meantime, consistent with the emphasis on counselling, a full-time Family Court counsellor has been stationed in Darwin for some time now and that person also provides a regular service at Alice Springs.
Recommendation 57

This recommendation proposed the provision of Family Court type facilities such as counselling services to all courts of summary jurisdiction exercising jurisdiction under the Family Law Act. Again the Government accepts that the provision of such facilities in all courts doing family law work is ultimately desirable. But, given the number of courts of summary jurisdiction in the States and Territories that are involved in this work this will need to be a long term goal.

I mention that those persons who are involved in family law proceedings in courts of summary jurisdiction can, of course, avail themselves of the counselling facilities provided through the Family Court itself and are encouraged to do so.
Recommendation 29-Tax deductibility of maintenance payments
I have drawn the attention of the Treasurer to recommendation 29 which proposes that he arrange for an inter-departmental examination of the question of tax deductibility of maintenance payments.
Recommendation 36 and 37-Matrimonial property regime

I turn now to recommendation 36, in which the Committee proposed a full study of the implications of the introduction of a full matrimonial property regime in Australia, including a survey of community attitudes and an assessment of overseas experience. The Committee recommended that such a study should be carried out by the Australian Law Reform Commission.

Honourable Senators will be aware that the Law Reform Commission's resources are already stretched in coping with the several very important matters it currently has under reference. Furthermore, problems of family law have hitherto been the province of the Family Law Council rather than the Commission.

The Government acknowledges that the question of a matrimonial property regime, affecting as it would the property interests of most adults in the comeunity, is such an important matter as to warrant investigation by a body of unquestioned expertise in this field and with adequate resources for the task. Although the members of the Family Law Council are distinguished by their professional expertise in various aspects of family law, they are all part-time members, and the back-up resources of the Council would be quite unequal to servicing an enquiry such as is called for.

Accordingly, the Government has decided that the task will be undertaken by an ad hoc committee of enquiry which will be appointed specifically for the purpose, and which will consult with the Family Law Council. The committee is to consist of a full-time member with appropriate qualifications and expertise and 4 part-time members. It will be required to report within 2 years of its establishment. I expect to make an announcement about the membership of the committee and provide details of its terms of reference in the near future after I have consulted with State Attorneys-General. The proposal concerning ownership of the matrimonial home made in recommendation 37 will be subsumed by the inquiry.
Recommendations 42, 43 and 44-Migrants and the Family Court

Recommendation 44, which calls for more explanatory material on family law and related matters in appropriate foreign languages, has been accepted and a working party consisting of representatives of my Department, the Family Court, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Office of Women's Affairs of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment has been established to co-ordinate its implementation.

As regards recommendation 43, which proposes that the Family Court should recruit people with sensitivity and experience in working with ethnic communities, I understand that the Family Court is already doing this as far as possible, consistent with the need for the holders of positions in the Court to possess appropriate educational or professional qualifications. In relation to Recommendation 42, which deals with the provision of interpreter services in family law proceedings, I point out that under arrangements now in operation, properly accredited interpreters are available to any party who requires such services in the Family Court.
Recommendation 53-Parliamentary representations on Family Law Council

Recommendation 53 proposes that membership of the Family Law Council should include representation from the Parliament. After considering the matter, the Government has decided that it would not be appropriate for members of the Parliament to be appointed to the Council, which is essentially a specialist advisory body.

As regards the call by recommendation 53 for the appointment of a magistrate as a member of the Council, a magistrate, Mr E. J. Blythman S.M. of Brisbane, was in fact appointed to the Council on 25 May 1980.
Recommendation 70-Appeal Cost Fund

Finally, I briefly mention recommendation 70 which proposed the establishment of an Appeal Costs Fund for the purposes of proceedings in the Family Court. In this regard, Honourable Senators may recall that this matter is now covered by the recently enacted Federal Proceeding (Costs) Act 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Conclusion

We live in a period when the rate of divorce has significantly increased. Although that increase has not reached the worst fears of many people, and it certainly is not as great as in a number of other countries, it nevertheless represents a major social disruption for our community. I must say that I share the concerns which have been expressed by many people about this situation. The problems of dissolving a marriage are often greater and more enduring than those which are sought to be avoided. Nevertheless, the Government and the Parliament are obliged to deal with the problems of widespread breakdown of marriage, whether we like it or not. Both the Government and Parliament have done much in recent years to assist people to repair a marriage or reconcile after separation; for example, the grants to marriage counselling organisations. By amendments to the Marriage Act several years ago, the Parliament sought to encourage people to prepare for marriage. Perhaps more could be done in these areas. However, it is essentially a moral question which must be decided by each individual. Both the Government and Parliament have also done much in recent years to make the process of dissolution more humane, less traumatic, and as amicable as possible. The establishment of the Family Court of Australian has been a notable achievement in this regard.

I would would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Chief Judge and the judges of that court, and the Family Court of Western Australia on the work they have done. It is often referred to as 'a helping Court'. That is not an empty rhetorical phrase. The judges of that Court have been selected not only for their expertise in family law but also for their suitability as judges in the very sensitive area in which they work. It is regrettable that so many people seem to misunderstand and devalue that work. However, I am sure that the great majority of people who have been assisted by the Court have not taken that attitude. The Court is not only the judges. The counsellors who have been attached to it have also made a significant contribution. The policy of appointing deputy registrars to conduct pre-trial conferences has also been a remarkable success. The work of the counsellors and the registrars has significantly reduced the number of cases coming to trial and thereby shortened the delays, which would otherwise have been greater than they are today. I am gratified that the parliamentary Committee so clearly recognised all these features of the new Court which is, for Australia at least, a new and almost revolutionary concept for the judicial process.

I believe that the foregoing statement is a positive response to the report of the parliamentary Committee. The proposed Family Law Amendment Bill will provide further evidence of the attention that has been devoted to the Committee's recommendations. In terms of figures, when the recommendations to be dealt with in the Bill are added together with the other recommendations disposed of either by decisions against implementation or because no further action is required, some 58 of the 72 recommendations in the report will have effectively been disposed of when the Bill is introduced. I trust that this statement and the Bill will meet with a constructive response from the Parliament. In conclusion, I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard the schedule of the responses to each of the recommendations in the parliamentary Committee's report.
Leave granted.
The schedule read as follows-
Number 1

The proposed reference of powers from the States to the Commonwealth in the outstanding areas of children and property be proceeded with as a matter of urgency. The Commonwealth should proceed to enact legislation in this regard on the recommendation of a majority of States if agreement of all States proves impossible to procure.
Response
Consultation with 4 States for an appropriate reference of powers is continuing. It is unlikely that a reference will result in the near future.
Number 2

Independent of any reference of powers by the States, the Commonwealth move to amend the Family Law Act to exploit to the fullest extent its legislative powers with respect to children; the rights of third parties and re-introduction of the original definition of 'child of the marriage'.
Response
To be dealt with in the Family Law Amendment Bill 1981.
Number 3

The Commonwealth move to amend the Family Law Act by relating the jurisdiction in respect of matrimonial property disputes to the marriage power. It is proposed that the property jurisdiction be limited to require:
(i) The proceedings to be between the parties to the marriage;
(ii) That the dispute relates to the property or proprietary claims of either party;
(iii) That the claim arises out of the marital relationship, or arises by reason of the fact that the parties are married;
The Committee believes such legislation would survive testing of its validity in the High Court.
Response
To be dealt with in the Family Law Amendment Bill 1981.
Number 4

The Government of the States and the Commonwealth examine the possibility of issuing State commissions to federal Family Court Judges and Federal Commissions to selected State judges to enable the exercise of a unified jurisdiction in family law matters throughout Australia.
Response
It is proposed that this be raised individually with each of the State Governments. This proposal raises problems of great complexity.
Number 5

Those considering matrimony should be appraised of the responsibility involved in that state and the consequences that will result from marriage breakdown. As a means of highlighting this approach the Committee recommends that the Marriage Act and the present Family Law Act be consolidated.
Response

The Family Law Council has recommended that the principle of consolidating the two Acts should be accepted in family law for the future but did not see it as a matter requiring immediate action. Therefore given the size and cost of the task, it has been deferred for the time being.
Number 6
There should be no change to the provisions of the Act relating to grounds for divorce.
Response
This has been accepted and no action is necessary.
Number 7

The Institute of Family Studies should undertake research with a view both to assess the value of the procedures under s.63(1) of the Family Law Act, relating to the approval by the court of arrangements reached by the parties to a marriage regarding the welfare of children of the marriage and to examine alternative methods of supervising placement arrangements by couples upon separation. The study should make recommendations as to the extent of involvement of Commonwealth and State welfare departments, voluntary agencies and the court counselling services.
Response
The Institute of Family Studies has been requested to institute such a study.
Number 8

The Family Law Act and other legislation of the Commonwealth and the States should be examined by the appropriate authorities to ensure a consistent use of terms such as guardianship, care and control and custody. Where necessary, terms should be defined so that the nature of the relationship between a child and the person standing in a relationship towards the child are precisely expressed. The Commonwealth Attorney-General and the Minister for Social Security should take this matter up with their State counterparts with a view to achieving a uniform approach to the use of these terms. This Committee is of the view that the terms 'guardianship' and 'custody' and 'care and control' should be defined with some care in the Family Law Act itself and more particularly, that the terms 'guardianship' and 'care and control' should be carried through into other provisions and Part VII of the Act which are relevant e.g., s.61(4); s.64 sub-sections (2), (3), (4), (9), s.67(1), s.68, s.69, s.70.
Response

Action on this has been deferred, pending receipt of the views of the Family Law Council, which in early 1980 established an ad hoc committee of experts under the Chairmanship of Mr Justice Watson (the 'Watson Committee') to examine in detail this and related matters. It is proposed that the Council's views, when received, will be the subject of consultation with both the Minister for Social Security and the Governments of the States.
Number 9

The Family Law act be amended to insert into section 61 of the Act, a provision that would empower the Family Court to exercise the prerogative of declaring children within its jurisdiction to be wards of the court.
Response
Action on this has been deferred pending receipt of the views of the Family Law Council. It is among the matters being examined by the Watson Committee (see response to recommendation 8 above).
Number 10

The Family Law Act be amended to provide that the court may request a designated official (i.e., an officer responsible for administering child welfare laws in the State or Territory) to intervene in proceedings before the court where the court considers it appropriate so to request in relation to a child of a marriage whose welfare is under consideration in proceedings before the court.
Response
To be dealt with in the Family Law Amendment Bill 1981.
Number 11

In relation to the extent that the wishes of a child should be taken into account in custody proceedings that the specific reference to the age of 14 should be removed from the legislation and not replaced by any reference to a specific age.
Response
To be dealt with in the Family Law Amendment Bill 1981.
Number 12

In order to reduce as far as possible unnecessary bitter and prolonged custody and access proceedings, a new s. 70A should be inserted in the Act providing that in proceedings with respect to the custody and guardianship of a child of a marriage, the court shall, as far as practicable, make such orders as will avoid further proceedings.
Response

Courts having jurisdiction under the Family Law Act already make every attempt to make orders that will, as far as possible, not be susceptible to being changed. In addition, custody orders have entirely future operation and may thus often be rendered inappropriate by future events. It is also considered that the major problem with which the Committee was concerned, namely the changing of custody as a result of reversals of decisions on appeal, is not dealt with by the recommendation. The Family Law Council has concurred with this view.
Number 13
In order to facilitate the more immediate settlement of disputes over custody s. 64 (1) should be drafted to state criteria that the court must consider. It should be provided that:
(a) The Court shall regard the welfare of the child as the paramount consideration;
(b) The Court shall take the following matters into account:
(i) the relevant conduct, as parents, of the parents of the child;
(ii) the relevant conduct of any step-parents or persons sharing the care, control and guardianship of the child with the custodian;
(iii) the wishes of the child's parent or parents as to his custody;
(iv) the wishes of the child;
(v) the desirability of, and the effect of, any change in the present care and control of the child;
(vi) if there is more than one child under consideration the effect of the separation on the children;
(vii) the education and up-bringing of the child;
(viii) any other fact or circumstance which, in the opinion of the court, the justice of the case requires to be taken into account.
(c) Subject to paragraphs (a) and (b), the court may make such order in respect of those matters as it thinks proper, including an order until further order.
Response

It is considered that it would be undesirable to restrict or reduce a court's discretion in relation to proceedings concerning children by attempting to specify matters that it must consider. It is preferable that the wide discretion of courts in the area should be retained. The Family Law Council has so recommended.
Number 14

Except in cases of urgent necessity no custody case should be listed for determination by a judge until the parties have attempted to resolve the dispute in pre-trial conferences with court counsellors and registrars.
Response

This recommendation, together with related recommendation 15, is accepted in principle. Pre-trial procedures involving counselling, conferences and/or reports are now conducted in the great majority of contested custody proceedings in the Family Court of Australia, whether final or interim in nature, and progress towards the objectives proposed in the recommendations is continuing. In such proceedings, however, the procedures referred to are conducted by the counselling service of the Court rather than registrars and this is considered to be appropriate in cases involving children. The Family Law Council has recommended against implementing these recommendations by legislation, on the grounds that they are being achieved by administrative action.
Number 15

Except in cases of urgent necessity no court should entertain an application for interim custody before pre-trial conferences have been conducted. The application for such an interim order should not be made in the absence of a report from a registrar on the outcome of the pre-trial conference.
Response
See response to recommendation 14 above.
Number 16

Except in cases of urgent necessity (i) no interim custody order should be granted unless the other spouse has been served with notice of the proceedings, (ii) no court should grant such an order in the absence of a report from a court officer who has interviewed the respondent and advised that person of the implications of the order.
Response

This recommendation is accepted in principle. As far as part (i) is concerned, it is at present the case that ex parte orders are only granted in cases of urgent necessity. As to part (ii), action will be taken as far as possible to achieve this.
Number 17

Section 64 (4) of the Family Law Act be amended to provide that upon the death of a person awarded sole custody of a child, the child should become a ward of court pending the further order of the court. it is further recommended that the Act be amended to the fullest extent possible within the jurisdictional limits of the powers of the Commonwealth to ensure that the Family Court has jurisdiction in all matters affecting custody, guardianship and access to a child.
Response
Action on this has been deferred pending receipt of the views of the Family Law Council. It is among the matters being examined by the Watson Committee (see response to recommendation 8 above).
Number 18

Some means be employed to formalise the use of State police forces to assist in the enforcement of custody and access orders. The Committee therefore considers that steps should be taken for the necessary arrangements to be made with State police forces as envisaged by s. 112 of the Family Law Act.
Response
To be dealt with in the Family Law Amendment Bill 1981.
Number 19

A marshal of the court as provided for in s. 37 (4) should be appointed to the Family Court in each State to liaise with State and Commonwealth police. Deputy marshals should be appointed to registries in the States. Further, the Commonwealth should fund the States in respect of the cost of their police.
Response

The Government does not propose to appoint a full-time Marshal and full-time Deputy Marshals of the Family Court. It is considered that the present arrangement under which part-time appointments to those positions are held by members of the Australian Federal Police is working satisfactorily and that full-time Marshal and Deputy Marshals would be unlikely to be able to perform an effective role without resources such as are at the command of the Australian Federal Police. It is also considered that there is insufficient work to occupy full time holders of the positions. The recommendation amounts to a pointed reintroduction of matrimonial conduct at large and, accordingly, is contrary to the basic philosophy of the Family Law Act. It would lead to more protracted and costly proceedings, and thus to a greater drain on limited Court and legal aid resources. It would also necessarily reintroduce the notion that maintenance-or the witholding of it-may be used to punish the party 'guilty' of misconduct. The conduct of one of the parties to maintenance proceedings that has affected the economic circumstances of the other party can be taken into account under the existing provision, and it is considered that this is the only extent to which conduct should be relevant.
