TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion to take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no other area of the law which generates such heated controversy and impassioned opposition as the Family Law Act and the Family Court of Australia. That is true both in respect of decisions in individual cases, where it reflects the impossibility of satisfying all parties in an inherently antagonistic and unhappy situation, and also in respect of the structure of the Act and the demands for its reform. There are widely differing views within the community as to the kind of legislation which is appropriate and necessary for the resolution of disputes consequent upon a marriage breakdown, as to the scope and nature of the powers of the Family Court, as to the obligations which it is reasonable to impose upon parties to the marriage after the divorce, and as to the best mechanism for ensuring that the welfare of the children in particular is ensured.

SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the chamber readily acknowledge the high level of feeling within the community which has traditionally operated in this area and which does serve to underline further the need for continuing scrutiny of the operation of the Act. It is within that context that we welcomed the detailed report of the Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act when it was presented to the Federal Parliament in August 1980. It is in that context also that we on this side of the chamber deplore the inactivity-I hope just until today, although I never like to speak too soon in this respect-of the present Government in response to the very carefully presented recommendations of that Committee.

Although I acknowledge, like the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in his statement, that family law is traditionally a free vote area in this Parliament-certainly I do not purport in anything I say now to be in any way speaking on behalf of or binding my colleagues on this side of the chamber-I do nonetheless believe that I certainly speak for the great majority of my colleagues, perhaps all of them, when I say that we in the Opposition do not resile from the basic principles and intention of the Family Law Act. We regard the Act as landmark legislation which, by its removal of the concept of fault and the institution of single ground, no fault divorce, has obviously helped very considerably to reduce both the emotional aspect and the cost and complexity of many divorce proceedings. Equally obviously however, the Act does need reform in a number of areas. Our basic position, or that-again I qualify it-of undoubtedly the great majority of my colleagues, would be one of support, I believe, for the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee. It is not necessarily total support or support for every one of those recommendations, but certainly support for the vast majority of them, which I believe will greatly improve the functioning of the Act as it affects the people involved in a marriage breakdown.

Before I say a little about the Attorney's response, I want to comment, and again I do it this time I think very much not only on behalf of the Opposition but also on behalf of a great many other senators in this chamber and parliamentarians generally, on the disgraceful but regrettably all too typical tardiness of this Government and the Attorney-General in particular in producing amendments to the Act and, indeed, a response to the other recommendations of the Committee report. This Government has always been pathologically lethargic when it comes to law reform matters, but this time its sluggishness has, I believe, set new records. After all, it was in October 1978 that the Joint Select Committee was established. In July 1980 the Attorney-General, if I can put it politely, had the cheek to issue a Press release when explaining his reluctance at that stage to introduce any changes to the Act. He expressed his disappointment in these words:
I am disappointed that the Committee has twice sought an extension of its original deadline, and will not now be reporting until the end of next month.

That was in July 1980. It was in that month that the report was completed, and in the following month it was presented to the Parliament with its 72 recommendations. In December 1980, four months later, the Attorney-General made an announcement to the following effect:

. . . work has begun on drafting instructions to make significant amendments to the Family Law Act. The amending legislation will be introduced into the Parliament as soon as possible and I hope that the program of Government business will allow it to be introduced in the next sittings of Parliament.
Of course, that announcement specified 24 of the 72 recommendations in respect of which the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you like to have had some more business last session?

—Early in the session we could well have done with some more business while so many of the Government's Ministers were displaying again such pathological incapacity to make up their minds about the major pieces of legislation that were before them. There would have been ample opportunity to debate this kind of legislation in detail. I regret the opportunity then lapsed to bring forward some of the major and more urgent reforms that are contemplated in the legislation now, again, today, foreshadowed. That was in December 1980, and the situation is that it is only now, today, in October 1981 that we have another statement from the Attorney inching the matter forward, if I can so describe it, when again the statement is made that legislation will be introduced within a matter of days to legislate for those 24 recommendations, or such of them as have survived the Government's further scrutiny over the interim period, with another three or four added to that original list, I readily acknowledge. We are told today that of the 51 legislative recommendations -I am glad to see that the Attorney has to some extent reacted to my passion for arithmetic in these matters and incorporated some of his own in his statement-27 have been accepted. Ten have been rejected for reasons of varying validity which I will come to in a moment, but which I shall mainly leave to be debated when we debate the Bill and 12 of them are still outstanding.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension for dinner I was engaging in some mild and friendly laceration of the Attorney-General for his delay in bringing forward both the legislation to reform the Family Law Act and also, of course, this Government reaction. I confess that I am not entirely clear in which capacity the Attorney has been experiencing that laceration because, reflecting the rather odd character of family law legislation in this place as being, from at least one point of view, free-vote legislation, it did seem that the Attorney has wanted to present this reaction in something of a schizophrenic guise-on the one hand as reflecting his own personal viewpoint and yet on the other hand, and apparently for the most part simultaneously, as reflecting the Government's own reaction. I am not entirely clear whether the Bill he is foreshadowing is to be regarded from that point of view as a private member's Bill or whether it is in fact Government legislation. But whatever the capacity in which the Attorney was in fact producing this statement to which we are now responding, it is evident that some blame is due to him and his Government not only for the delays that have occurred so far but also it seems because of the delays that are still to be experienced before we are going to have a viable, effective and fully sane system of family law in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: On the one hand there are a number of recommendations of the Joint Select Committee still outstanding so far as the Government's, or at least the Attorney's, reaction is concerned. Some 12 really quite significant recommendations fall into that category and the language in which the Government's, or the Attorney's reaction is cast is such as to suggest we are going to be waiting for a long time yet before legislation is actually presented to this chamber to incorporate some of the further desirable changes that may well still be necessary. I refer in particular to recommendations such as Nos 20 and 30, No. 31 on the extraordinarily important and difficult subject of maintenance enforcement, and No. 54 relating to the passage of certain ordinances to reform the situation here in the Australian Capital Territory, the experience of reform in which when it comes to passing ordinances has been such as to give one very grave cause for alarm as to when the subordinate legislation in question will ever come forward.

The other part of the statement that still gives us cause for concern so far as its delay potential is concerned is the absence of any very precise timetable being proposed for the consideration of the amending Bill when it is introduced in a few days time. The Attorney has indicated that the Bill will be brought forward but there seems some reason to suppose that there is no great disposition on the Government's behalf at least for that Bill actually to be debated this session, and I think that would be a most unfortunate state of affairs given the long and sad history of delays in this whole area that I have already outlined. Of course it is a matter, particularly these days, for the Senate itself to determine its own legislative timetable. I hope that individual senators who are concerned to move forward the pace of necessary change to family law to remedy the perceived deficiencies in it will take heed of what I am saying so that it does in fact prove possible to advance the debate and, it is hoped, wind it up before this session is over. That still, of course, creates the difficulty of getting legislation on foot in the other House, and that is, of course, where the Government, however much it might pretend that this is free-vote legislation, has the trump card in the setting of the legislative program. I hope, and I do not belabour the point any more than that, this long overdue legislation will in fact get its proper parliamentary attention and that the changes that are necessary and vital to the successful operation of the legislation will in fact be enforced as soon as possible and, it is hoped, before Christmas.

I do not stop now to go into any great detail at all in relation to the legislative recommendations of the Committee or the Government's response to them for the obvious reason that there will be ample opportunity to do that in the context of the debate on the Bill. There will be ample opportunity also to move amendments in respect of that quite numerous range of matters in respect of which the Government or the Attorney has so far demonstrated no great disposition to accept the Committee's recommendation.

There are, however, a couple of quick and general points I would wish to make about the legislative recommendations. The first of those points is that I am pleased that the Government has demonstrated its willingness to legislate to a greater extent to explore the character and scope of its constitutional power with respect to marriage and matrimonial relations. There are a number of matters detailed in the joint select committee report which suggest themselves as candidates for this sort of more adventurous exploration of the Commonwealth's legislative power. I am inclined to think that there are other areas beyond those mentioned by the committee and by the Government in its response that deserve this sort of attention given the unlikelihood of getting referrals of power from the States or, in the short run, any expansion of the Commonwealth's family law jurisdiction in any other way. The particular matters that I think ought to be the subject of such adventurous extension of the actual terms of the Act by reliance on the existing heads of constitutional power are these: Property proceedings between parties to marriage otherwise than in the context of dissolution; proceedings involving a natural or adopted child or just one of the parties to the marriage; third party proceedings involving custody, guardianship or access to children; third party proceedings involving certain property that is owned or partially owned by the parties to the marriage. Beyond that I would also add the question of children and property proceedings in de facto marriages-that is, established non-formal relationships-which do, of course, raise acute practical problems requiring the attentions of any civilised system of family law. I am disappointed that the committee drew back from making explicit recommendations of this kind. I hope that that will be one of the matters that we in the Parliament could pay attention to as justifying again as adventurous exploration of the Commonwealth's marriage powers to see whether it might not extend to that area.

The other general point I wish to make about the legislative recommendations which are being accepted so far by the Government is this: I am pleased that the Government has shown itself not disposed to do anything that would seek fundamentally to undermine the concept of family law as it was introduced in 1974. We have all been, I suppose, to some extent under increased pressure to do so-not so much now with respect to the grounds of divorce themselves, although no doubt rear-guard actions will still continue to be fought by social reactionaries amply represented here in this chamber by my learned colleague Senator Martyr and my other colleague Senator Walters. But I am thinking more in terms of the pressure to wind back the operation of the Family Law Act in respect of the procedures and the formality of the jurisdiction in its basic role and perception of its role as being not of a forbidding court in the traditional majestic form to which we are accustomed but rather a helping court.

This is an argument, of course, which has been much kicked along in recent days by the intervention in the debate of Mr Trevor Nyman from the New South Wales Bar writing as he has in a much publicised way in that otherwise rather modest journal produced by the Law Council of Australia and called Law News. Mr Nyman has in fact made a number of suggestions about restoring all the awful in terrorem majesty of the court system in the family court area, about recreating that atmosphere of polished wood and judges sitting on high and, of course, recreating the atmosphere of the presence of bewigged and begowned lawyers, no doubt including Mr Nyman himself. Let us be clear about it: No one, human nature being what it is, will be too anxious to step into the inner sanctums of the legal process once again, unrepresented, when they are confronted with all this traditional, but no more familiar for that to the ordinary layman, panoply of the law. It is a concept which I personally reject, and which I would hope will be rejected not only as it appears to have been by the Committee in its recommendations and by the Government in accepting them in this respect but also by other members of this Parliament when this matter comes to be debated.

I do applaud one significant change in the practice and procedure of the court which has been recommended by the Committee, although not without some controversy within its own ranks, and which has been accepted by the Government. I refer, of course, to the reopening, to a limited extent anyway, of the Family Court to the public. Nobody wants a return to the bad old days of lurid divorce reporting and certainly, as has been recommended by the Committee and accepted again by the Government, the identity of the parties should not be a matter directly or indirectly for Press publication. But I certainly take the view, and I hope it would be the view taken by this Parliament, that secret justice is never satisfactory justice.

I am sure that in fact a great many of the charges of bias or insensitivity that have been made against certain Family Court judges will in fact simply evaporate when the court can be seen at work not only by those immediately engaged in a particular matter but also by people who perhaps have a case pending and want to get some familiarisation with the court and who also want to feel that the workings of the court are in fact exposed to the steely eye, or for the most part steely when it is not too blurred, of the Press. That is an improvement, I am sure, of the open court system and one much to be welcomed, although no doubt it is a change that will be much debated in this and the other chamber when it does come forward as a legislative proposition. I repeat that I would resist very strenuously the notion that there be any kind of return in any other significant way to the bewigged and begowned formality of this particular jurisdiction.

There will always, of course, be some who want their day in court. There will be some, always, who will not conciliate, who will not settle and who will want to extract the last half ounce of blood from the other party to the marriage. There will always be some people who are never satisfied by the determination of the proceedings in whatever form those proceedings take. Perhaps there is something to be said psychologically for having those people get their final stage of lack of satisfaction in a more formal atmosphere than occurs at the moment. But the situation is, and this emerges in the proceedings of the Standing Committee and the way in which they are reported by the Committee, that the overwhelming majority of litigants in this jurisdiction simply want speedy, expeditious justice in a non- intimidatory, helping, conciliatory and, so far as possible, co-operative atmosphere. The strain of undertaking any kind of marriage dissolution procedure-not that I have been through that myself, mercifully-is enough in itself, particularly so, of course, if there is the added human stress of having the custody of children at stake, without adding and multiplying to that strain by recreating for the parties to the litigation the forbidding traditional atmosphere of the wood panelled, stern, courtroom.

There is a way out for the problems of delay and dissatisfaction to the extent that they presently exist in the Family Court jurisdiction. I think essentially the elements of that way out, although I do not want to spend too much time debating them now, would involve more counsellors and deputy registrars being appointed to exercise in a more effective way even than is the case at the moment the conciliatory, helping, settlement assisting functions of the court. I also think that the delays in the court and the willingness of parties to settle their cases rather than fight them out to the last drop would be assisted by the Act containing more clear criteria that are likely to be employed by the judge in the final resolution of these contested matters, in particular in the area of custody, the notion being of course that the more criteria are articulated in the text of the legislation the more likely it is that one can predict the outcome of a given case and the more likely in turn it then being that the minds of the respective litigants will be concentrated on the task ahead. They will not get inflated or over- ambitious ideas of what is possible and will in fact be encouraged to settle their case. If respect of both of those matters-the provision of more counselling assistance and more deputy registrars and also the building into the text of the Act more clearly descriptive criteria-I am disappointed to note that the Government's reaction has in fact been negative. I will come back in a moment finally to the counselling question.

That leads me to comment even more briefly on the subject of the non-legislative recommendations of the Committee and the Government's response to them. Here the prospects of change for the better are much less rosy, if the Government's reaction is any guide, than seems to be the case by and large with respect to the legislative area. Let me mention just two or three of the rather long list of matters which are still outstanding or still unresolved in the Government's mind in this respect. The first such matter is the vexed question of the insufficiency of Commonwealth constitutional power to cover fully the family law field. It may be that a lot of the gaps in this respect can be filled, as I mentioned a few minutes ago, by more adventurous use of the Commonwealth's existing powers, particularly its marriage power. But it is obviously the case that if we are fully to cover the area of illegitimacy, certainly if we are to get adoption and proceedings of that kind under the auspices of the single family court system, we will need some powers transferred from the States to the Commonwealth.

The reality of the matter, as is acknowledged in the Government's response, is that although the Labor States have been willing from the very outset to refer such powers, regrettably all sorts of difficulties are being experienced elsewhere and there does not seem to be any real prospect in the immediate future of at least an across-the-board referral of powers. That is an unhappy state of affairs and one which seems not to concern Senator Durack especially, but it very much concerns me and those of us on this side. Let me make it clear that the Labor Party's attitude to this is very explicit and very clear cut. We will certainly support, of course, and continue to support so far as our State parties are concerned, the referral of powers to the Commonwealth to the extent that it is possible to grant them. We will also commit ourselves ultimately to the conduct of a referendum to expand the Commonwealth's constitutional powers in the event that they cannot be obtained rationally any other way.

The other side of the coin, so far as the Commonwealth's powers are concerned is, of course, the whole very difficult question of divided jurisdiction of the courts themselves in the family law area. Here again there seems to be simply no movement visible in either the negotiations that have been conducted so far by this Government or those that are likely to take place in the future. I simply say here that I do not underestimate the difficulty of the task of rationalising the exercise of family law jurisdiction particularly now that we have a well-established and functioning set of Federal family law courts. But at the same time I do not share Senator Durack's apparent hopelessness about this matter and I would hope that we can get some movement before too long not only on the question of resolving jurisdictional conflicts in the Family Court areas and their State counterparts but also on the larger question of establishing a single uniform national court system overall. That is a topic which it is inappropriate to develop further here, but I make the point that the Government's response in this respect is exceedingly empty and exceedingly depressing and is not unimportant.

Finally let me mention the subject of pre-trial procedures, which is the subject of another set of Committee recommendations in respect of which the Government's response is very disappointing indeed. The Committee recommends, for very well argued reasons, a substantial increase in the number of deputy registrars to conduct pre-trial conferences and of Family Court counsellors to assist in this conciliatory trial-avoiding process. But that recommendation has simply been greeted, for razor gang and other associated reasons, with nothing more constructive than hollow rhetoric from the Government and from Senator Durack in the response before us now. The opportunity for the Government to do something in this respect is basically now gone with the introduction of the Budget Bills. As we explored in detail in discussing this matter in Estimates Committee A and as is evident from looking at the Budget Papers themselves, this Government has made absolutely no commitment to and no provision whatsoever for any increase even of one body in the area of counsellors on the one hand or deputy registrars on the other. Let that perhaps be the epitaph for this statement now before us, a matter of windy rhetoric when dollars and cents are needed and profound lethargy when a legislative response is called for.

We do look forward to the introduction of the Bill, if indeed it is possible to believe there will at last be a Bill forthcoming, and we look forward to the opportunity that Bill will provide to explore further the strengths and weaknesses of the Government's response, or, if one prefers to put it another way, Senator Durack's response. We look forward to it so that we can between ourselves, as a parliament behaving rationally, sensibly and constructively and I hope unemotionally contribute something to this profoundly important-because it is so profoundly human in its implications-area of social legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Senate for very long. To me the statement of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) largely is a collection of cosmetic proposals which really do not do much to alter the fundamental badness of the legislation. My report was the only in toto dissenting report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. Naturally I am disappointed that the Government did not give attention-it did not give any attention it seems to me-to my dissenting report or to any of its recommendations. My dissent was based on, to me, the undeniable fact that sociology, not law, is still the basis of the so-called Family Law Act. I will certainly have more to say when a Bill based on the statement of the Attorney-General comes before the House. Suffice to say that one of the important functions of the law for many generations has been the trial system to establish guilt or innocence or, in other ways, fault or degree of fault. The so-called Family Law Act wiped out all of that to the detriment of, I believe, the institution of marriage which it very severely affected. I think plenty of evidence was put forward to the inquiry which backs up that point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: I have taken the opportunity tonight to reiterate my view because I believe it is necessary to remind the Senate of the very many people who feel the same way as I do and who feel that their upholding of the traditional permanence of marriage has been undermined by the almost trivial and only ground for the dissolution of marriage of just 12 months separation which still remains the basis of the Family Law Act. I think that sums up the most basic ground of my dissent and it is still the reason why I cannot support what the Attorney-General has put down and why, as I have said, I will have some very strong opposition again to the amendments when they come forward in the form of a Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My being a deputy chairman of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act for a time I feel necessitates my saying something. I am a little concerned at the earlier remarks of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) that he was disturbed that the Committee had asked for two extensions of time. Perhaps it is worth noting at this stage that there were 504 written submissions to that Committee and that even though we extended the closing date for submissions we were still being requested to receive additional material while the Committee was meeting. We had to consider also the additional reports that were coming up as a result of seminars that were organised by the Committee in relation to specific matters mentioned in the terms of reference. While the Attorney-General expresses his concern at the delay caused by the Committee I express my concern at the delay of the Government in responding to the report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee met in all States of Australia. We had inspections of family law courts, meetings with judges and with the Chief Judge of the Family Court. We had, as I mentioned, seminars relating to specific areas of the terms of reference of the Committee. We had a large committee of some 15 members from both the House of Representatives and the Senate. I am sure that those of us who have served on Senate standing and Senate select committees will appreciate the difficulty in getting from such a large number a quorum to enable the Committee to meet or to travel and meet in the various capitals. Hundreds of individuals and organisations made submissions to the Committee on a personal basis but of course the Committee could not deal with them because basically we were concerned with an overall view of the matters that were relevant.

I think the staff of the Committee deserve particular mention, especially the secretary, Mr Donald Nairn, who was an untiring worker for the duration of the meetings of the Committee and certainly up to and including the presentation of the report. I think as a deputy chairman for part of the time the Committee met it is my duty to record an expression of appreciation to the staff and particularly to the secretary, Donald Nairn.

It is not my intention to keep the Senate very long at this stage because of the opportunity that we hope will arise with the introduction of the Bill which I understand will take place on Tuesday or Wednesday of next week. But I think it is important that I make mention of the concern expressed by my colleague Senator Evans that perhaps the Bill may not be debated properly at that time. I would not like to think that there will not be a full and complete debate in this chamber and in the House of Representatives prior to the rising of this Parliament.

There were some matters that were under consideration by the Committee which I must admit caused me some heartburn, not the least of which was the subject of open family law courts. Members of the Senate may be aware that the Family Court of Western Australia is an open court, and that system has not been abused. But I do not want to see a return to the situation in which dramatic and sensational headlines were available in most areas of the Press throughout Australia when people were named as having appeared in a divorce court. I still have some apprehension about the recommendation-the Government's response to it indicates that it is accepting this recommendation-that the courts be open courts. I still have some reservations because I believe it will not be impossible for an astute journalist, particularly when dealing with a mildly sensational divorce involving parties who live in a small town or even a small suburb, to write the story in such a way that the people involved could be fairly readily identified, and that causes me more than a little concern. I think divorce, as with marriage and with a marriage partnership, should be a matter of privacy. I did not submit a minority report on that matter because I was convinced by members of the Committee and witnesses who appeared before the Committee that this was not likely to happen. I do not know that I have as much faith in the media in Australia as other members of the Committee who have said that that sensationalism will not arise again. If it did occur I would be most apprehensive that perhaps the courts would not have the necessary power to take action against the people who did identify participants in family court proceedings.

Senator Evans spoke about the attitude being expressed by one judge that perhaps we should return to the pomp and panoply of the past where people are confronted by a judge bewigged and gowned. Of course my attitude on such matters is that there is already enough fear when people go into any court of law; whether they go in as witnesses or participants in the proceedings is not important. There is that fear of the bureaucracy and of the judiciary sitting there and determining an attitude perhaps on something that one says.

One of the items selected by the Government for a positive response relates to the age of children. At the moment the Family Law Act determines that the wishes of children from the age of 14 years are taken into consideration where custody matters are being discussed. The Committee's recommendation that there should not be an age limit set is one that I heartily agreed with. I do not believe that there is such similarity between children that one can say that only children at the age of 14 years are adult enough or mature enough to determine with which parent they wish to live or with which parent they have an affinity. I believe all children are able to do that at some age. No two children are alike. No two babies are alike as no two adults are alike in everthing they do. Some children, perhaps as young as six or seven years, can determine immediately that they have an affinity with their male or female parent and want to spend their lives with that parent rather than with the other parent. Their wishes should be paramount because they are the ones who will spend the rest of their lives living with the consequences of the determination that they make. I think that is their right and responsibility.

As I said, I am not going to take the Senate's time tonight to debate these matters but I would like an assurance from the Minister that in actual fact we will have a full and proper debate on this matter coming to a conclusion with a debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill when it is introduced into this House prior to the rising of the Senate and the House of Representatives in the current sitting. It is an extremely important piece of legislation and whilst all the recommendations of the Committee have not been accepted there is opportunity in a full debate for amendments to be moved, and perhaps accepted by a majority of the Senate, which are of paramount importance to the majority of people in the community who have to avail themselves of the services of the Family Court, and from that the Family Law Act. I add that with the free vote of Government and Opposition members we could find ourselves in some rather unusual alliances in this chamber. Similarly, I imagine that in the House of Representatives there would be a number of occasions, with amendments being put forward, when there would be alliances between the Government and the Opposition which might surprise a number of people in both chambers. I will leave the balance of my contribution to the debate for the time when the Bill actually reaches this chamber. I hope that in fact it will be a full and complete debate at that time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill makes a number of unrelated amendments to the Defence Act 1903 and consequential amendments to the Defence (Visiting Forces) Act 1963.

The most pressing of the amendments are those made by clause 6 of the Bill which are intended to provide a means of protecting the livelihood of Defence Force reservists who suffer long term total incapacity for work as a result of compensable injuries received during reserve service.

Publicity was given some time ago to the fact that some reserve units were taking out commercial insurance policies, at their own expense, to meet this situation. The Government takes the view that it is not appropriate that reservists should have to pay their own premiums to protect themselves against events occurring outside their normal civilian occupations, when these events are related to voluntary national defence training in their spare time.

The Government accordingly decided, as the Minister for Defence announced on 30 June 1981, that legislation should be brought down to amend the Defence Act to bring the entitlements of totally incapacitated reservists more into line with those of totally incapacitated regular servicemen.

Under the Compensation (Australian Government Employees) Act 1971, employees totally incapacitated through their employment receive normal weekly earnings for up to 26 weeks and then statutory weekly payments not exceeding a prescribed amount per week, with extra amounts for dependants.

In the case of regular servicemen, their normal military salary and relevant allowances continue while they remain members. If such a member's service is terminated and his incapacity is assessed as more than 60 per cent in relation to civil employment he becomes entitled to a class ''A'' DFRDB invalidity pension of 76.5 per cent of his normal military salary.

Section 58B of the Defence Act empowers the Minister for Defence to determine financial conditions of service for members of the Defence Force. Clause 6 of the Bill amends section 58B to empower the Minister for Defence to determine the payment of additional compensation to reservists to whom compensation is payable under the Compensation Act.

It is intended that a determination be made entitling a totally incapacitated reservist, after the first 26 weeks of incapacity, to an addition to the amount payable under the Compensation Act to bring his total weekly entitlement to 76.5 per cent of his average civilian weekly earnings or, if he was previously unemployed or a student, to 76.5 per cent of his reserve military salary.

This determination will, in common with all other section 58B determinations, be subject to tabling in, and disallowance by, the Parliament, and will be drafted in such a way as to give the reservist a right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against decisions made under the determination concerning the amount of additional compensation payable.

Clause 9 of the Bill marks an interesting new development, namely, the necessity to legislate regarding control over members of the public using defence lands for recreational purposes where general access for that purpose is permitted.

There is an increasing use by the public of defence property for recreational purposes where this is compatible with defence requirements. This is a matter of interest to State authorities from at least four aspects, namely, the availability of such areas for use by their citizens; the development in such areas of recreational facilities such as barbeques and camping areas; the conservation of such areas; and the maintenance of law and order in such areas.
The authorities of the States concerned have been most co-operative in this matter. However the States lack the power to make the legislation required to provide the necessary controls.

Adequate power to control the activities of members of the public on defence property is normally provided by the Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Act 1971, the Crimes Act 1914, the Defence Act 1903 and state criminal law.

However these powers and common law powers are not very suitable where persons are permitted to enter for recreational purposes, particularly where large areas are involved necessitating the employment of rangers.

Where the ecology of the area is fragile, as at Garden Island in Western Australia, it is essential that there be practical powers of control over such matters as camping, the lighting of fires, the use of off-road vehicles and the removal of plants.

The nature and extent of the problem will be appreciated when I mention that some of the defence properties are quite large. Garden Island in Western Australia is about 1,200 hectares in extent, of which the public is allowed access to an area of about 950 hectares. Beecroft Peninsula at Jervis Bay is even larger, comprising about 4,600 hectares.

We are faced, in effect, with a situation similar in a number of respects to that presented by the control of national parks, and the solution adopted is to pass legislation based, to the extent appropriate, on the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 of the Commonwealth.

Clause 9 accordingly inserts a new Part IXB into the Defence Act which provides for such matters as the declaration of the relevant parts of defence lands as public areas; the appointment of rangers; their powers of arrest and search; and offences such as personating or assaulting rangers. The legislation also empowers the Minister for Defence to make by-laws relating to the control and management of public areas.
All by-laws will be subject to tabling in, and disallowance by, the Parliament.
Provision is also made permitting the continued operation of State and territory laws. This will permit the operation of laws such as those relating to the declaration of high fire danger.

On this question of defence lands, I mention finally the Naval Establishments (Public Areas) Regulations. These were made at the end of 1980 as an interim arrangement pending the preparation and passing of the Bill now before the House. The regulations are necessarily limited in their scope. They cannot apply to all defence lands but only to those which fall within the definition of ''naval establishment'' in the Naval Defence Act 1910, nor can they encompass all the matters dealt with in the new Part IXB of the Defence Act. The regulations will be repealed in due course.
The remaining provisions of the Bill may be dealt with more briefly.

Clause 8, taken in conjunction with Part III of the Bill (which amends the Defence (Visiting Forces) Act 1963), in effect transfers certain provisions from the latter Act to the Defence Act. The operation of these provisions is not restricted to visiting forces and their inclusion in the Defence (Visiting Forces) Act 1963 was done as a matter of expediency, as the Senate was informed at the time.

The provisions in question relate to attachments of personnel between the Australian Defence Force and the armed forces of other countries, mutual powers of command between such forces and the arrest and disposal of illegal absentees from the armed forces of other countries.
In the main, the differences between the new provisions and the existing provisions are of a drafting or clarifying nature.

Significant changes are the provision of additional safeguards where illegal absentees from the forces of other countries are held in custody by the Australian authorities. The Bill requires the person who has custody of the illegal absentee to cause an authorised officer to be informed and to ensure that the person in custody understands his right to request his release.

The power of an authorised officer (who is appointed by a chief of staff) to hand the arrested person over to the authorities of his own country is abolished and this power is to be vested in the Minister for Defence.

One other significant change has been made where an officer of the armed forces of another country is given command over Australian forces. The Chief of Defence Force Staff is empowered by the Bill to limit the scope of the powers of command and discipline that may be exercised.
The remaining amendments of any consequence are made to the regulation-making powers in the Defence Act. These clarify the power to make regulations on four matters.

Firstly, in addition to providing for the forfeiture of salary and allowances of members of the Defence Force who are absent without leave, etc., provision may be made for the suspension of the payment of salary etc.

Secondly, in addition to providing for the establishment and operation of service canteens and messes, provision may be made subjecting them to Commonwealth, State and territory taxes (other than income tax).

Thirdly, provision may be made for compensation by the Commonwealth for loss, injury or damage by reason of anything done under the Defence Act as, for example, the exercise of control over building heights in the vicinity of defence airfields.

Fourthly, in addition to providing for the appointment and procedures of service courts and boards of inquiry, provision may be made under which a witness may be compelled to answer a question although the answer may be self-incriminating, and a witness may be provided with protection against the use of the answer in proceedings against him before a service tribunal or a civil court.
This last matter calls for further explanation.

Boards of inquiry are held, not infrequently, to investigate such matters as the loss of an aircraft, a fatal accident involving the use of service weapons or equipment, the grounding of a ship or a failure in the operation of a ship's navigational or propulsion equipment, as well as deficiencies in, or loss of or damage to, stores.

The primary purpose of a board of inquiry, particularly if there has been a serious or fatal accident, is to ascertain as quickly as possible what, if anything, went wrong and to prevent a recurrence.

It may be that the board of inquiry's investigation will reveal some dereliction of duty and result in subsequent disciplinary action, but this must not be allowed to negate the primary purpose of the inquiry.

In order that the truth be established without delay, it is essential that witnesses give their evidence frankly. In the case of possible equipment failure, for example, which could result in (say) the grounding of aircraft, a witness who is provided with adequate protection against self-incrimination would probably be more ready to admit that the failure was caused by error on his part and not by any inherent defect in design.
The law relating to boards of accident inquiry under the Air Navigation Act 1920 and to royal commissions, contains similar provisions.

Finally, I should mention that I will be introducing in the Committee stage of the Bill several amendments which arose from suggestions put to the Minister in another place by the Opposition during the Committee stage of the debate in that place.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN APPLE AND PEAR CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1981APPLE AND PEAR LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1981APPLE AND PEAR EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 August, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take advantage of the Senate Standing Orders to speak on the first reading of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981 and associated Bills on a matter concerning the so-called Greek conspiracy case, which of course has not been raised in speeches in this Parliament for some time. In particular tonight I wish to raise the mistreatment and neglect of a small and almost forgotten group, the Greek Australian pensioners who lost their invalid pensions in Greece in 1978. The case at the time caused some controversy. The then Minister for Social Security, Senator Guilfoyle-who is at the table-sometimes made, not from any cause of her own, statements about the situation of these people which were misleading at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting also to note that two other major figures involved in the events of the alleged social security conspiracy case, Mr Lanigan, the then Director-General of the Department of Social Security, and Mr Thomas, the then Chief Detective Inspector with the Commonwealth Police at the time this case was first raised, are no longer with us. They have both fled the scene. Both are practising lawyers, Mr Thomas having been invalided out of the Australian Federal Police and Mr Lanigan having taken the opportunity of retiring early from the Department of Social Security. Of course, Mr Rofe, another distinguished member in the case, is at present prosecuting in the court case which continues in Sydney. Up until now he has received $430,000 for the prosecution of this case. One may suspect that this is ample reward for his role in the famous Sankey case, the notorious Sankey case, which occurred in Canberra and which involved leading members of the last Labor Government.

As background I remind the Senate that at the time of the dawn raids in Sydney between 31 March and 21 April 1978 183 persons were arrested in Sydney on conspiracy charges. Over 170 of them were Greek-born and Greek-speaking invalid pensioners and sickness beneficiaries. The others were five doctors, of whom three were Greek-speaking, a psychologist and persons who allegedly had acted as agents or go-betweens. At the time Detective Inspector Thomas announced to the Press that more than 1,000 people would be charged and that he and his officers would be responsible for getting those more than 1,000 people. At the moment, after $7m has been spent, 20 people remain charged and there are also nine people charged in Athens under Greek law. We will have something to say about that at another time. About 700 pensions and benefits of people who were of Greek origin and had consulted the accused doctors, were cancelled.

At the same time, in April 1978, and on the same grounds-that they had attended the accused doctors; I repeat accused, not convicted, then or now-138 invalid pensioners in Greece, all of whom had at some time worked in Australia, where they had qualified for an individual pension, on income, medical and residential grounds, were asked to attend the Australian Embassy in Athens for medical reviews. They had received their last payments on 16 March 1978. Most of them, in fact, would never receive another Australian Government payment. The first medical reviews, so-called, were conducted by a Dr Ivil and 135 persons attended, of whom 105 lost their pension. These medical examinations, according to Greek pensioners and their relatives who have returned to Australia or whose stories have been told in Greece and transmitted to Australia through the Greek-Australian Pensioners' Association in Greece, were closer to the proceedings of a kangaroo court. Although at the time the Minister told me that the average time of examination was not recorded, there is general agreement that it took Dr Ivil only five minutes to decide that a pensioner was ineligible and to remove entirely his family's financial security.

In reply to questions that I asked of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle about who gave the order to terminate the pensions, when the order was given and when it took effect-questions to which I have never received a full answer-I was told on 30 May 1979:
The Director-General advises me that the reviews which took place were properly conducted.

The Director-General at the time, Mr Lanigan, may have been satisfied and so may the Minister, but the evidence strongly suggests that the reviews were perfunctory and that justice was neither done nor seen to be done. Mr Morgan, the Social Security Department's Director in Europe, wrote to the pensioners requesting their attendance at the Embassy in Athens with letters from local doctors showing the medication that they had taken previously. Pensions were all stopped until after these reviews took place-for one reason only, guilt by association, as they had been patients of doctors in Australia who had been charged with conspiracy. Apparently the five minute reviews took the form of questions, which were mainly: 'Who were your doctors in Sydney? How much money do you have?' The doctor did not have complete medical histories and decided not to examine at all one man whom he had seen a few months earlier. Patients claimed that medical certificates were ignored. In fact, most of the patients had such certificates from their doctors in Greece.

The 105 rejected pensioners were sent letters stating that no further payments could be made because, on the medical evidence available, they were not considered to be 85 per cent incapacitated. They were told that they could appeal. In one case, which is typical of the documentary evidence that I have, the last pension payment was made on 16 March 1978. The letter directing attendance for medical examination was sent on 5 April 1978. Notification of cancellation of the pension was given on 16 May 1978. An appeal was lodged on 26 June 1978 and the letter for the appellant to attend the medical appeal was sent on 4 January 1979-a period of almost 10 months between loss of income and advice of appeal.

There were at the time, and there have been since, examples of misinformation given to this Parliament by the then Minister for Social Security, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, about the situation of some of the overseas pensioners. On 3 May 1978, the Minister told the Senate:
There has not been and there will not be any interference with payments to persons who have been granted benefits on the basis of medical evidence which is not under challenge.

This was simply not true. A large number, probably the majority, of pensioners who lost their pensions here or in Greece had corroborating medical assessments from doctors in Australia who had not been charged or challenged. Hospitals and doctors in Greece had confirmed incapacity, but pensions were still taken from pensioners in Athens on the basis of a list supplied from Canberra and Dr Ivil's brief interview.

On 3 May 1978, the Minister told the Senate that about 70 per cent of overseas pensioners had been found ineligible following medical examination; that the others were qualifying for age pension. It was later admitted by the same Minister that not 30 per cent, but in fact none, was being paid the age pension. On 24 November 1978, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said that many of the invalid pensioners in Greece had had their pensions cancelled because they had not passed the income test. Six months later she had to admit that this too was false information. Not one, let alone many, had had the pension cancelled on income grounds. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said that the overseas Greek pensioners would have medical examinations before the next pension pay day. They did not and they could not. The facility was not made available to them on anything like the next pension pay day.

On 5 April 1978, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle said that any pensioner who was dissatisfied with departmental rulings had the right of appeal. In fact, families in Greece had to beg or borrow money because the Government decided that it was in no hurry to provide the mechanism for appealing. Mr Lanigan told the Senate Estimates Committee in October 1978, in adopting a rather cynical approach:
We will in due course have to set up some form of medical tribunal-
He was referring to appeals--
. . . but we have not done this as yet.
The Australian Government had meanwhile discarded responsibility for those ill and disabled pensioners. As Mr Lanigan said at the same time:

. . . once it is established that they are not eligible for an Australian pension . . . then it becomes the responsibility of the Greek Government, not the Australian Government, to support them when they are in Greece.

This, of course, was fast work-cable across a list of names, give the people on the list a brief interview, followed by cancellation notices, and they no longer exist as far as the Australian Government is concerned.

The Government medical team-two Government doctors-eventually, in January 1979, went to Athens with instructions, I am told, not to take the availability of suitable work into consideration. They saw 64 pensioners, restored three pensions and left 61 pensioners who had appealed and 40 who had not with only two alternatives-to stay in Greece and depend on relatives, or borrow money to return to Australia and try to get their pensions back after seeing new doctors. At least one pensioner died in the interim, with stress caused by losing the pension considered to be a major factor.

According to the Minister, the Government doctors went to Greece 'assisted by an advice, the terms of which were settled by the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department'-advice that this Parliament, I might say, has not seen. Mr Lanigan, in a famous memorandum called Control of Invalid Pensions issued in May 1979, said that these instructions were in line with the Government's actions and stated:
The European cases are not typical because they were former patients of doctors who have since been charged with criminal offences . . .

That is, he believed the doctors guilty and the pensioners fraudulent and took action to punish the pensioners well ahead of any court hearings-hearings which have not yet been completed. As is now well known, and as many honourable senators will well remember, this memorandum led to a tightening of the criteria by which eligibility for all invalid pensions in this country were assessed. Mr Lanigan, I remind honourable senators, had stressed that the same criteria applied in Greece as applied in Australia. All were to be judged on medical disability alone, with no other circumstances being taken into account.

The result of this memorandum and of these new policies was a considerable questioning of the Government's actions, a considerable campaign in this country to have the situation reversed. More than a year later, the criteria were relaxed to the pre-April 1978 guidelines because they had been manifestly inhumane and unworkable and many people were being harshly treated. But they applied only to those individual pensioners who were in Australia. Those who were stranded overseas, in Greece, were left without the benefit of these new criteria.

My last information from Senator Chaney, the present Minister for Social Security, is that in fact 60 pensioners have returned from Greece. Of these, two are known to be at work, 14 are on sickness benefits and six are on other benefits. Some 20 have had the invalid pension restored, presumably for the same reason as it was granted in the first place-that they fulfilled the eligibility criteria that were in vogue before April 1978. I believe, as do many who have been involved with these cases, especially social workers and members of the Australian-Greek Pensioners' Association, that all of these people have been treated very shabbily. Senator Chaney was not the Minister during the earlier disgraceful episode, but he is now the responsible Minister. I believe he should exercise his powers to redress, where he can, the injustice that has been done to those pensioners in Greece whose pensions were axed in 1978.

I wish to make three suggestions in this respect. Firstly, all those pensioners who have had their pensions restored on the same basis on which they were originally granted should be paid arrears from the time the pensions were stopped. Only two of those 20 pensioners have received full back pay. I believe all of them have a valid case for claiming entitlement to that pension in the intervening period. Secondly, I believe all those pensioners who have returned from Greece to try to establish their pension entitlements should be given reimbursements for their fares. Their medical reviews in Greece were inadequate. They had been judged ineligible because they had been associated with certain doctors and not on the basis of their illnesses. The only way they could have claims properly assessed was to reapply in Australia with a new and non-suspect set of doctors. They had to return because of Australian Government actions. I believe the Australian Government has some responsibility to pay their fares. Thirdly, I believe all remaining pensioners in Greece whose pensions were stopped in March 1978 should be re-examined in Greece by an independent medical team under the criteria which currently exist for the granting of invalid pensions-that is, those which take other factors, such as work availability, into account.

I have asked Senator Chaney to look at the right of appeal of pensioners from Greece. During the hearings of Senate Estimates committees he promised to do so. I believe it is a disgrace to the social security system that the presumption of guilt by association deprived of their invalid pensions so many people who had spent their working lives in Australia-a reason which, incidentally, precludes them from qualifying for contributory pensions in Greece. The fact that so many pensioners here have had their pensions reinstated is proof of the inadequacy of the medical examinations which were conducted in Athens. In spite of the efforts of the Government and Mr Lanigan in particular to dismiss these people from Australia's responsibility and the Australian consciousness, the ill and the penniless ex-pensioners in Greece remain with their problems.

This whole affair has been remarkable for the Government's silence. The Government has made no statements about what is going on. Only by raising the matter in Parliament, asking questions and taking note of the representations from Greek social workers and doctors, have we been able to piece together some pattern of what happened to those 138 people in Greece who were caught up in what might well be considered a racist purge. I have no doubt at all that racial prejudice strongly affected the actions of some of those Government principals in the affair. The media at the time blasted 'Greek cheats'. This was orchestrated by the Commonwealth Police and some sections of the Department of Social Security which, in fact, invited sections of the Press to accompany them in their dawn raids. There is no way that the Australian Government would have acted at long distance as judge, jury and executioner to remove the only incomes from 138 people if those people had been Anglo-Saxon overseas pensioners and families. The New Year's message that year from the then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs was a remarkable statement and a remarkable example of hypocritical insensitivity. He said:
My special thoughts go to the Australian Greek community in Sydney, which has felt badly let down through the publicity given to certain social security matters.

As one of Australia's oldest and proudest communities you have, I know, been deeply hurt. I ask you, however, to continue to walk with pride in yourselves in an innate sense of fair play which is one of the contributions of your new homeland.

I suggest that that fair play was missing when the capricious mass cancellation of pensions took place in Greece and Australia. These people lost their only means of livelihood and also shared the cloud which hung over all those members of the Greek community who were suspect because they were ill, had attended some of the accused Greek-speaking doctors, had needed pensions and were of Greek origin. The matter has now been sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) by the Greek-Australian Pensioners Association in Greece. I ask Senator Chaney to discuss this continuing injustice with the Prime Minister and to prove his determination of which he spoke in the Senate two weeks ago when he spoke of his determination to have the Department of Social Security deal with all Australians on an equal basis. Many of these people are Australian citizens. I will give some examples of their experiences. The examples are all documented and will be made available.

The first case relates to a man with Australian citizenship who, after 13 years work in Australia, suffered deteriorating health and in 1968 was recommended-by non-accused doctors included-for an invalid pension. He left for Greece, as he was entitled to do under our law, having been assured that his pension would not be affected. His pension was stopped in March 1978. He had two medical interviews in Athens, but not examinations. He borrowed money from his wife's family to support his immediate family. He returned to Australia in 1979 and his pension was restored on medical grounds. He has asked for but has not received a reimbursement of fares so that he can pay back his wife's family.

The second case involves an Australian citizen who worked for 11 years in the building industry. When he became ill he saw several doctors, only two of whom were the accused doctors, and was granted an invalid pension. He took his family back to Greece in 1976. When his pension was cancelled in 1978 he borrowed money to support his family, returned to Australia, and was put on special benefit while he applied for an invalid pension. He cannot return to Greece with special benefit and is trying to borrow money to bring his family here again.

The third case involves an Australian citizen who came to Australia in 1954 and lived here for almost 25 years. He was given a pension on orthopaedic grounds in 1976; the pension was confirmed in 1977, but cancelled in 1978. His nephews have given him something to live on. He has returned to Australia, where three doctors have found him qualified for an invalid pension but, under the tougher pension guidelines, the Commonwealth Medical Officer found him ineligible. One doctor, who has never been accused of any conspiracy, has told Senator Chaney that it was one of the most tragic cases he had come across for some time. He said:

How any psychiatrist, whether they be Government or otherwise could possibly say that this man is fit to work would be beyond me . . . I feel that if this man's plight was to become known by the public there would be a general outcry against it.

Those were the words of the psychiatrist who examined the man. The fourth case relates to a man who, with his wife and two children, is still in Greece. He worked from 1960 to 1970, when he sustained a spinal injury. He could not get work because of his condition and eventually was given an invalid pension in 1974, which was confirmed in 1976, when he returned to Greece with his family. He was arrested in May 1980, imprisoned for a month and then transferred to the psychiatric section of the prison. His wife managed to raise bail but his condition has deteriorated and he depends on the charity of his relatives. Cases such as this are repeated on the records of the Greek-Australian Pensioners Association and on the records of Greek social workers in this country. I know there are members of the Government parties who take the view that we should not have portability of pensions. But the fact remains that portability is the law of this country. I certainly am in favour of it. I note that people who oppose portability of pensions only oppose it for migrants and do not oppose it for retired Governors-General or retired members of parliament who may choose to live in the Greek Islands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or London.

—Or London or wherever they may like to live. As I have said in this chamber many times, I believe this whole conspiracy case is a disgrace. It is a blot on Australia's social security laws. It is a blot on our system of justice and it is a blot on our treatment of migrants generally. I think it is worth recalling that in the first days of the case those who were involved-both of them are now in very comfortable, private legal practices having obtained pensions from the Federal Government-made the claim that over 1,000 people would be found guilty. Only 20 people remain charged.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that over several months, almost a year, a series of accusations were made by people in the Greek community. Questions resulting from those accusations were raised in this Parliament by me and others. Accusations were made such as that the people had their photographs taken with the word 'Greece' appearing underneath them, et cetera. All those accusations were initially denied. All those accusations were eventually found to be true and were demonstrated in this place to be true. We now have the same situation arising with these unfortunate invalid pensioners in Greece. A large proportion of those who have managed to get back to this country by borrowing money from relatives, friends or the Greek-Australian Pensioners Association in Athens have had their invalid pensions restored when they have come back to this country. Those who are left in Greece and who cannot afford to do this have no means open for appeal. I am at least thankful that the Minister for Social Security has said that he will reconsider whether appeals should be made available to these people.

In the meantime we must ensure that justice is done and that justice is seen to be done. We must ensure that Ministers do not come into this Parliament misled by stories from their public servants or from the Australian Federal Police. In the meantime those who it is obvious have not received justice should receive justice by having their pensions back-paid. Those who have come back to Australia and those who are trying to get back here to appeal-they certainly have good grounds for appeal on the evidence of the Greek medical practitioners-should be assisted to appeal or, at the very least, an independent medical tribunal and others should go to Greece to assist these people. Until this is done the $7m that has been spent on this case and the hundreds of thousands of dollars which have been given to people like Mr Rofe in payment for their previous services will remain a blot on the system of justice and on this Parliament. Until that sort of recompense is made I and others in this place will be putting the case of these unfortunate people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I acknowledge that it is now quite some time since you took up your position as Deputy President. This is the first occasion on which I have been able to wish you all the very best in this prestigious position. I know you will carry out your duties with great dignity, accuracy and compassion. After all, you have had a great deal of experience within the Parliament and as a Minister of the Crown. I wish you well in that capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak on the motion for the first reading of three Bills affecting the apple and pear industry. I do this because it gives me a far wider opportunity to discuss all the ramifications associated with fruit growers, not only in Tasmania but also throughout the whole of Australia. On 10 March in this chamber we were discussing matters affecting the dried fruits industry and the Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill. I recall that on that occasion my colleague on the other side of the chamber, Senator McLaren, put forth the view that there was a need for his own State of South Australia and for Queensland to have representatives on the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation. One of the Bills now before us, the Apple and Pear Corporation Amendment Bill, actually seeks to do this. It increases the number of members from four to six. I think that change was requested by members of the apple and pear growers association. The other Bill deals with changes to the rates of levy which are set by regulation.

The third Bill, the Apple and Pear Export Charge Amendment Bill, deals with three matters: It increases the maximum rate of the export charge per box. It also uses the weight factor to convert fruit not packed in boxes to a box equivalent and makes modifications in that regard. The third part affects regulations. I refer to an article appearing in the Age of Monday, 12 October under the heading 'Fruitgrowers hit by canning crisis'. Almost daily in the Tasmanian Press we read of the crises faced by the Tasmanian apple and pear growers. From reading the Age we notice that the fruit growers in the State of Victoria are having an equally disastrous time. Paul Chadwick's article states:
Australian fruitgrowers plan to destroy 30,000 tonnes of produce and almost 2,000 hectares of orchards because the canning industry is facing economic strife.
These are quite horrendous sorts of figures. The article goes on to state:
Up to 100 of Victoria's 600 growers could be ruined, and one of the State's three canneries would be in 'diabolical trouble' . . .

Two reasons are put forward. One is the worsening of the export market which has been affected by actions of the European Economic Community. The other is the revaluation of the Australian dollar relative to the currencies of many West European countries. In terms of employment opportunities, in Victoria this situation will deprive a large number of seasonal workers of employment. Paul Chadwick states:
A large proportion of the industry's 8,000 to 10,000 seasonal jobs and 2,000 permanent jobs could be lost, . . .

This is indeed a tragedy for Victoria and also for Tasmania. I mentioned earlier that one of the amendments seeks to increase the membership of the Apple and Pear Corporation from four members to six members. My initial reaction to this change was that it was not and should never be the purpose of the Corporation to be a gathering of States. I believe the Corporation was designed to help apple and pear growers. Previously the States of Queensland and South Australia did not have a member on the Corporation. Through very intense lobbying this legislation has now been put forward whereby these States, which are small producers, can now have a place on the Apple and Pear Corporation.

I remind honourable senators also that my own State of Tasmania exports 67 per cent of apples to what are known as the at-risk markets. Accordingly, the apple industry makes a pretty important contribution to the Tasmanian economy, particularly to areas such as the Huon Valley where the apple and pear industry is particularly significant. I was rather concerned some time ago when the Bureau of Transport Economics came down with some recommendations in relation to the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme. The changes it recommended could have jeopardised the marketing opportunity of some of the Huon Valley orchardists to send fruit to Sydney. I hope that the Government will not take up those recommendations of the Bureau of Transport Economics because that would certainly worsen the plight of those Huon orchardists. On the other hand, the Bureau's recommendations could possibly assist northern growers in marketing their fruit on the mainland.

One of the problems faced by the apple and pear growers is the exchange rate movements that have occurred. Bearing in mind that we are dealing with traditional markets in western Europe, I shall refer to some of these exchange movements. In the last 12 months the exchange rate has moved up about 34 per cent, revalued, in relation to the West German mark, about 26 per cent to 27 per cent in relation to the pound sterling and 39 per cent in relation to the French franc. It is no wonder that the apple producers who send their fruit in advance to these at-risk markets suddenly find themselves in a dilemma when the Australian dollar appreciates or revalues to the extent of the figures I have just mentioned. It is no wonder that the French have cut back their purchases, certainly of sheepskins, because of the 39 per cent revaluation. It has not only cut out the profit but also has extended into a large element of the cost.

I believe if our Government wishes to encourage people to move into exports there must be some recognition of or some compensation for these extreme upward price movements. However, the cynics may well ask whether, on the other hand, Australians are benefiting from the cheaper goods that should come in from these countries. Let us look at the facts. Have the prices of Mercedes-Benz cars cheapened in Australia? No, these companies charge what the market will bear. This is one of the problems we will face if we dismantle the Australian car industry. I give another example. Australia carries out no assembly or manufacture of motorcycles. On a comparative basis the prices of motorcycles in the United States are hundreds of dollars less than they are in Australia. That indicates that these overseas conglomerates tend to charge what the local market will bear.

I come back to the European situation. One might say we could get in goods a lot cheaper from Europe. Perhaps we could if they were bought off the shelf but if any extensive manufacture or time lag is required these overseas suppliers become rather hesitant because when there are such movements there is a fear that the exchange rate might move back again and they too will get caught. So violent movements in exchange rates are not helping either the exporters from Australia or the importers overseas unless the items can be purchased readily off the shelf. I mention countries such as Germany, the traditional export markets to which we send fruit, because we are not exporting to markets which are known to be highly volatile, such as some of the countries of South America where governments come and go with great rapidity, inflation is rampant and exchange movements are rife.

I come back to the point: If our Government wishes to encourage people to move into exports it will have to do something dramatic soon because I think there will be a trade deficit-that is, imports will exceed exports-of something in the order of $6.5 billion. Some people-apart from the traditional miners and sheep, cattle and wool producers-are moving out of exports in a fairly big way. Many who are in an area such as the exporting of fruit play a significant part in the overall export scheme of things. If these sorts of people are seen to be losing all along the line they will rapidly move out of the exporting field. The culmination of all these sorts of decisions will result in further problems in our overall export performance. So the exchange rate movement is significant and I contend the Government must take some responsibility in the setting of its policy to look at exchange rate movements and somehow to take up these severe losses, because they are quite substantial and can wipe out an industry.

Let us look back into history at the funding of the Apple and Pear Growers Association. This has now become quite a vexed question for growers. For example, when the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation was set up in 1975 the then Minister for Primary Industry-a Tasmanian, Senator Wriedt-asked the Association for support in introducing the changes. The old board, as it then existed in 1975, was purely for exports and was funded by a levy on exports. Honourable senators will notice that the new Corporation has six major functions; the first three are related to export and the others are related to domestic matters. The new Corporation, which was to cover exports and domestic matters as well as processing, was to be funded by a levy on all apples and pears produced-the emphasis being on the word 'produced'. The Minister indicated that the Association must be a strong and active mouthpiece of the industry with direct access to all Australian growers. I am emphasising the growers' point of view. The Association is made up of six members-from the Growers Association or its equivalent in each State- and is administered by an executive comprising the President and one executive member from each State. Membership fees are set at $1,250 per annum, which pays for executive sitting fees for five two-day meetings per annum. When the Corporation was set up the Federal Government instructed the Corporation to allocate $53m for the Association to set up its own office and its own secretariat. However, with the change of government the Association was told that funding from the Corporation levy would be reduced. The growers then found themselves in a dilemma. The present Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) has instructed the Association that funding must finish in the near future.

It is true that Association members have looked to many alternative schemes of income.
