They have looked at operating an insurance scheme but State grower bodies are already doing this and it would cut across their incomes. They have looked at increasing the membership fees to, say, $7,000 per State and they have also looked at voluntary grower contributions. It would not be practical to collect such contributions in the current climate of the apple industry. The Corporation and the State grower bodies all support full funding coming from the Corporation levy. The growers know of no grower anywhere in Australia who has publicly opposed that principle. There is some concern because the Minister is looking to the growers to become self-sufficient. I have taken up this matter with the Minister and although he has indicated this general intention, he has said there is no time limit within which this self-sufficiency is to be achieved. There is no Budget allocation for the 1982 calendar year and of course this is a matter of concern to the growers. Funding is generally considered at the time of the Budget and according to the Minister there is no specific suggestion that funding will be discontinued in the present year. I think in the present uncertainty of the apple industry there is a need for the Minister to provide some assurance to the Growers Association in relation to its own funding problems.

There are two distinct and difficult areas in Tasmania. One is the interstate market and the other is the export market. If growers en masse move out of exports their produce must inevitably flood onto the Australian market, which will hurt growers in the rest of Australia. I think we have to recognise that there should be a limit to the number of bushels that can be sent interstate. It is well recognised that mainland crops vary significantly, and Tasmania's traditional role is to maintain sufficient production to fill the gap in the Australian market.

Turning to the export market, because the domestic market is limited the surplus must be exported. Generally, more exports are generated in years when the domestic market is flooded. At the moment there is an anticipated loss to the Tasmanian Apple and Pear Marketing Authority, and this is before taking into account government stabilisation assistance of a Commonwealth and State nature of about $21,000 for each grower. When we take into account all the Federal and State subsidies, TAMA is still $2,800,000 in arrears, or $8,000 per grower. This is a substantial amount, and it will be debited to next year's growers' account. I take the opportunity of quoting from a letter to growers by Mr E. A. N. Beaumont, the Chairman of the Tasmanian Apple and Pear Marketing Authority. He said:

We have recently completed an estimated net F.O.B. return by variety for fruits sold at risk to the United Kingdom, the Continent and Scandinavia and also estimated the return of other exporting States, which indicates that after Government Stabilisation, Underwriting and Supplementary Assistance there will still be a debit balance in TAMA books amounting to about $2,800,000, or on average approximately $1.80 per carton. That is to say TAMA calculates that export realisations together with Government subvention payments will not cover the Advances made to growers by TAMA to the tune of about $2,800,000.
He went on to say:
As things stand at present this is a debt against growers accounts.

Growers have reacted in this manner. Some are prepared to test their legal arm and pull out of TAMA. Others believe that the State Government and the Federal Government should offer some support. It is well known that the State Government guarantees TAMA and as things stand TAMA must look in some way to recovering this money. The growers are naturally very unhappy about the situation and the extent of the loss. There is the further problem that Tasmanian growers are now seeking a poll in an attempt to review what is known as the compulsory crop insurance scheme, because of the lack of cash flow and because of their high costs and the difficulties that have occurred in the export market.

I remind honourable senators that on 10 March, when we were discussing the previous amending Bills, I expressed concern at the underwriting scheme which provided a maximum of 95 per cent over a four-year average. I also expressed concern about the problem of introducing this type of underwriting scheme into the apple industry because of the long time it takes to bring crops into production. I suggested that there should be indexation of about 10 per cent, 15 per cent or 20 per cent. I notice from the large number of letters I have received from growers that they supported that concept, but they would have preferred to stick with the old stabilisation scheme. The Government actually moved in relation to this legislation by largely adopting the Industries Assistance Commission recommendations, which cut right across the wishes of the growers and of the Apple and Pear Corporation. I thought that was a disastrous situation.

On the other hand, after representations to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), to his credit he said that he would review, or look at-that might be a better way of putting it-the operations of the new scheme, but he wanted time to see how it worked out. He has had time. The results have been quite disastrous and there have been substantial losses. I therefore appeal to him to act expeditiously and to restore some confidence to the low morale in the apple and pear industry at present. As I said, to Mr Nixon's credit he has undertaken in late October or early November to look at the position in relation to orchardists. I hope that, in conjunction with the Tasmanian Government, some sort of scheme can be worked out which will give a degree of equity to growers. The $2,800,000 loss is about equivalent to the revaluation of the Australian dollar. People who are exporting in good faith suddenly find that because of matters beyond their control in traditional and not new markets, this loss has been forced upon them they believe as a result of the effective revaluation of the Australian dollar.

I believe that something must be done to overcome this problem. One plan that was put forward to growers was that TAMA should undertake responsibility not only for the marketing of export fruit but also for fruit sold on the domestic market and for fruit used in processing. The growers are not particularly happy about that proposition. I acknowledge that TAMA is doing a good job in very difficult and extenuating circumstances. I quote from an article in the Agribusiness Executive of September 1981. The author was interviewing John Elliott of Henry Jones Ltd in relation to government-run bodies, and he stated:

. . . he does not believe that government run bodies can market agribusiness products efficiently throughout the world. This is because they do not have the incentive and they are also subject to the political infighting of various people on boards.
Mr Elliott said:
My experience is that commodity boards are certainly not maximising income to growers.
The article went on:
For example, the Australian apple industry slipped back badly because we allowed the quality of marketing to decline.
John Elliott says that from his experience of sitting on the board of the Apple and Pear Corporation and the Canned Fruits Board.

There we have a top Australian executive, the head of Henry Jones, coming out against government-run apple and other marketing authority boards. It is all very well to say: 'All right, engage in tree pull schemes and change the variety of apples to meet new markets', but it is not quite as easy as that. A sheep farmer can possibly sell his sheep and move into wheat or go from wheat back into sheep without too much dislocation. But when one considers that it takes something like six years to bring a tree into production and something like 18 years before a tree pays for itself, when an orchardist moves into or out of fruit growing it represents a pretty dramatic change in his lifestyle. The acreage an orchardist has is generally insufficient to enable a living income to be derived if he goes to an alternative such as sheep, goats, beef or even dairy cattle. He is in something of a dilemma.

Let us look at my own district of West Tamar and at the estuary there. One leading grower, Don Wright, is grubbing out some orchard this year. Inquiries show that six of the 60 northern growers will go out of business this year alone. That represents a decrease of 10 per cent in just one area, which has already seen a tremendous slide out of the apple industry. On a State-wide basis, more than 20 growers will lose their businesses. I think this is a rather sorry situation which does not reflect particularly well on either State or Federal governments.

More than 300 acres of orchards in Tasmania will be pulled up this year. Therefore, unless something is done the effect will be fairly dramatic. Unless taxpayers generally foot the $2.6 to $2.8m bill the apple industry will be in for major problems. I appeal to Mr Nixon to look at this underwriting scheme. I ask the Government to look at the effect that violent movements in exchange rates are having on this industry. Although there is new emphasis on resource booms we must bear in mind that some of the traditional industries are suffering. One of the principal sufferers is the fruit industry. We are told that if we move into resource based industries the nation will be better off and our living standards will rise. But in the interim some of the traditional industries such as the fruit industry are really going to suffer. People who have put a lifetime of effort into the fruit industry will not only leave the industry but lose their whole business because their losses are so substantial.

I further appeal to the Minister to review the legislation that was dealt with earlier this year in relation to the underwriting scheme, which is inadequate. If we persist with this scheme at least let us introduce some degree of indexation. We should at least acknowledge the problems that one sector of the Australian economy is having in resource development. I refer particularly to the plight of apple and pear producers. Unless something is done the situation in Tasmania will spread to other States. As I have mentioned, 67 per cent of exports which are at risk come from Tasmania. Tasmanian fruit that is not exported will be diverted to the mainland market. Earlier I mentioned the problems of the canning industry in Victoria. The State governments will face major problems in this area. The Federal Government has a responsibility to do something to assist these people because some of the problems are outside of their control and some, I believe, can be related to the resources boom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use the opportunity tonight in speaking on the first reading of a money Bill to make some remarks about the recent State elections in my State of New South Wales and in particular the campaign in the electorate of Manly-a campaign already referred to by one of my colleagues on 24 September. On 18 September 1980-that is over 12 months ago-I replied to an attack by an ex-senator on certain members of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales. I said this concerning the electorate of Manly:

SPEECH.PARA: He has won the preselection--
I was referring to Mr Meers, who had recently won preselection for Manly--

and I am just giving the Senate notice tonight that he is not going to win the State seat of Manly because he will be like the man that the Liberal Party imported once before, Mr Barton Higgs, who was the Mayor of North Sydney. Of course, Mr Douglas Darby, who was a legend in Manly, was able to defeat him. The people of Manly will not accept a second choice, and they will not accept a person who does not live in the Manly electorate.

When I said the people of Manly would not accept a second choice, I was referring to the fact that Mr Meers had already sought preselection for the State seat of Willoughby and had been defeated. My claim in that speech was proved to be correct as the final figures for the electorate of Manly are: Stewart, ALP 14,600; Meers, Liberal, 13,891. That is a majority of 709 for the Labor candidate after the distribution of preferences.

In passing I must refer briefly to the result in Willoughby. In 1978 the Labor Party candidate in Willoughby received 37 per cent of the vote. A former Liberal Minister, who had lost his preselection for the seat, stood as an independent and polled 15 per cent of the vote, and directed his preferences to the Labor Party, with the result that the Labor Party won the seat of Willoughby by approximately 400 votes. As honourable senators can see by those figures, Willoughby was considered a blue ribbon seat. However, the winning of the seat by the Labor Party was one of the great upsets in New South Wales political history.

It is very interesting to look at the 1981 result in Willoughby. There was a boundary redistribution between 1978 and 1981 and as a result the Labor party proportion of the vote was expected to drop by 3 per cent. In the 1981 election, Mr Eddie Britt, the Labor Party member for Willoughby, received 46.5 per cent of the vote. This was a remarkable achievement when one realises that he not only held all of the Labor vote from 1978 but also held practically all of the Independent Liberal vote recorded by the former Liberal Minister in 1978. This result is a tribute to the dedication and hard work that was put in by Eddie Britt in his three years as the ALP member for a blue ribbon Liberal seat. I believe that this achievement deserves to be put on record. In fact, I believe that if the election for that seat had been held on the 1978 boundaries the result would have been a cliff hanger.

I now want to refer to the scurrilous campaign that was waged by the Liberal Party in the Manly electorate. The Liberal candidate said in May of this year in an interview reported in the Sydney Morning Herald that his campaign would cost $45,000. The Labor Party campaign in 1978, when we won the seat, cost $3,449. Because of public funding a considerable amount was spent this time-much more than what we spent in 1978. However, when one considers how much was spent by the Liberal Party we can see that this was probably the most unequal campaign in terms of spending in any electorate in New South Wales. There have been estimates that the Liberal Party and the Liberal Party candidate spent in excess of $100,000. If one takes into account the fact that they had two permanent offices in two shopping centres, that they had permanent staff and that they had the use of a number of trucks and cars and even a plane on election day, one would realise that that sort of campaign does not come cheaply and that perhaps somewhere between $45,000, as was claimed, and $100,000 was the cost of the Liberal Party campaign in that seat. It was certainly the most expensive campaign that I have ever seen at a State level in my experience as a party official or as a member of parliament.

One of the interesting things about this campaign is, of course, that the Liberal Party refused to accept public funding, which was introduced for the first time by the New South Wales Labor Government. I suppose if one is spending $45,000 as a minimum one does not have to worry too much about public funding. However, later in the campaign, obviously when the Liberal candidate was worried about the likely outcome of the result, every household in the electorate, and at least one person on the roll in every house in the electorate, received a letter from the Honourable Michael MacKellar, the Minister for Health, who happens to be the Federal member for the electorate of Warringah, which includes the State seat of Manly. Of course, that letter was sent out on his official stationery and in parliamentary envelopes. Of course he was asking the electors of Manly to support the candidature of Mr Meers. Really, is this not just public funding? I do not object to public funding but it is a good example of hypocrisy when one campaigns openly against public funding and one takes it in another form through the back door. One can only imagine how much this exercise cost the taxpayers. The letter was quite obviously a mistake. Unfortunately for the Liberal Party the Minister for Health at the time was in the process of presiding over the demise of Medibank and was seen by many people as being responsible for the increase in the costs of health care. I think this fact was not missed by a large number of electors in Manly who received the letter.

Another smear used in the campaign was when the Liberal candidate who was under attack because of tactics of campaign workers, said in an article in the Manly Daily that there was a slogan 'vote early and often' used by the Labor Party which he wanted to stop. In fact, he was saying that there was going to be double voting in the Manly electorate and this was going to be carried out by the Labor Party. The article was entitled 'Liberal doorknock sparks complaints: Campaign workers'. The article states:
Questions asked by Liberal campaign workers in the Manly electorate are an invasion of privacy, irate residents claim.
Several residents contacted Warringah Shire Council and the Manly Daily to complain about the electoral roll being checked by door-knockers.
'They wanted to know if I was dead or alive-and who I was going to vote for', one man said.

'The man, who said he was a Liberal voter but would not give his name, claimed the doorknocker was 'about 14-years-old' and asked questions about his occupation and voting habits, and those of his neighbours.
'As far is I am concerned updating the electoral roll is the job of the Commonwealth Electoral Office and who I vote for is my business,' he said.
Later on in the article the Liberal candidate is quoted as saying:
It is important that we know who is entitled to vote. There is a slogan, 'vote early and often', used by the Labor Party and we want to stop this.
Scrutineers need to know who is entitled to vote.
It is very important that he said that. I will refer to that again later on in my speech. I seek leave to have this article incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
LIBERAL DOORKNOCK SPARKS COMPLAINTS CAMPAIGN WORKERS
Questions asked by Liberal campaign workers in the Manly electorate are an invasion of privacy, irate residents claim.
Several residents contacted Warringah Shire Council and the Manly Daily to complain about the electoral roll being checked by door-knockers.
'They wanted to know if I was dead or alive-and who I was going to vote for,' one man said.

The man, who said he was a Liberal voter but would not give his name, claimed the doorknocker was 'about 14-years-old' and asked questions about his occupation and voting habits, and those of his neighbours.
'As far as I am concerned updating the electoral roll is the job of the Commonwealth Electoral Office and who I vote for is my business,' he said.
Vote often
Another resident said 'school-age' children had asked her questions along similar lines.
A spokesman for Warringah Shire Council said 'a fair few' complaints had been received.
Mr Nelson Meers, Liberal candidate for Manly, confirmed yesterday that his campaign workers were checking the rolls, but denied they were under voting age.
'It is important that we know who is entitled to vote,' he said.
'There is a slogan, ''vote early and often,'' used by the Labour Party and we want to stop this.
'Scrutineers need to know who is entitled to vote.
'Anybody who complains about a roll update would be a Labour voter.'
Mr Meers said the Commonwealth Electoral Office had covered only one-sthird of the electorate in the last roll-check.
He said all his campaign workers were 'attractive and effective young people of voting age.'
'The only one involved in my campaign who is younger is my daughter and she is not doing this type of work,' he said.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact it was the Liberal Party which constantly breached the Electoral Act. On the Wednesday prior to the election, campaign posters on behalf of the Liberal candidate were posted illegally through the electorate. Again this was reported in the Manly Daily under the heading 'Candidate ordered to pull down poll bills'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Candidate for Manly, Mr Nelson Meers, has been asked to remove campaign posters allegedly posted illegally throughout the electorate.
Later on the article states:
The Minister for Police, Mr Crabtree, has sent a telegram to the Mayor of Manly, Alderman Joan Thorburn . . . asking the Council to 'ensure the law is observed.'
Mr Crabtree said the posters contravened Section 151D of the Parliamentary Electorate and Elections Act.
'Mr Meers, as a former Lord Mayor of Sydney, should appreciate the value of preventing pollution of an area in such a manner,' Mr Crabtree said.
Again so that the full article may be printed, I seek its incorporation in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
Candidate ordered to pull down poll bills
The Liberal Candidate for Manly, Mr Nelson Meers, has been asked to remove campaign posters allegedly posted illegally throughout the electorate.
The posters, saying 'Vote 1 Meers,' were posted up on Wednesday night.
Mr Meers said yesterday he had nothing to do with sticking up the posters and claimed the work was done by his 'enthusiastic supporters.'
The Minister for Police, Mr Crabtree, has sent a telegram to the Mayor of Manly, Alderman Joan Thorburn (Independent Group) asking the council to 'ensure the law is observed.'
Mr Crabtree said the posters contravened Section 151D of the Parliamentary Electorate and Elections Act.
He instructed the police in Manly to take action in accordance with the Act to ensure the posters were removed.
'Mr Meers, as a former Lord Mayor of Sydney, should appreciate the value of preventing pollution of an area in such a manner,' Mr Crabtree said.
'I have issued instructions to the police and requested the electoral commissioner to take all possible action to remove the offensive material.'
Mr Crabtree said he had also instructed the police to take all action necessary to prevent a reoccurrence of the incident.
Mr Meers said yesterday he did not agree that his campaigners had broken the law by sticking up the posters.
He said he would take them down if he was instructed to, but added: 'I would be very happy to dispute this in court.
'The posters have not been placed illegally though, I can assure you of that,' he said.
When Mr Meers was asked if he knew how many of the posters had been stuck up through the electorate he said, 'How would I know that?'
'Why don't you go out and count them?'
The President of the Manly Chamber of Commerce, Mr Andrew Kalajzich, said the posters were 'in poor taste.'
Mr A. G. Stewart, State MP (Lab, Manly) said he had lodged a formal complaint with the electoral officer in Manly.
Mr Stewart said he was contacted by Manly Council yesterday and asked to give an assurance that his campaigners would not use telegraph poles for election posters.
Manly Alderman G. Ashton (ALP) said yesterday he understood all candidates had been asked to give this assurance, just hours before the posters appeared.
Manly Council would not say whether or not it had sought or been given such an assurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another breach of the Electoral Act was the use of a plane on election day towing a banner supporting the Liberal candidate. Again the police were needed. They had to intervene to stop this blatant breach of the Act. But I think the worst breach which occurred was on polling day itself when Liberal Party scrutineers inside the polling booth approached and spoke to voters, which I regard as a serious breach of the Electoral Act. This occurred repeatedly during the day, despite the efforts of the State electoral officer in Manly who attempted to stop them. What was happening was that Liberal Party scrutineers were standing close to where people were coming up to vote. If they found out that those people were voting outside their subdivision, they then offered-I said spoke to them which was a clear breach of the Act-to drive them to their correct polling booth where in fact they could vote. If some honourable senators opposite think that this is something which has been passed on to me by Labor Party campaign workers I point out that in fact I was informed of this by a State electoral officer in another neighboring electorate as I was doing my rounds on the day.

SPEECH.PARA: Another section of the scurrilious campaign which certainly deserves comment was the campaign organised by the so-called pro-life candidate who directed her second preference votes to the Liberal candidate, Mr Meers. The candidate, Miss Langworthy, was sponsored by Right to Life Australia, whose chairman is Mrs Tighe, of Victoria. It is interesting to note that the New South Wales Right to Life group had nothing to do with the campaign and did not endorse this candidate. I would be interested to know who talked her into running and whether in fact the Labor candidate, Mr Stewart, was even asked by the organisation for his comments on the right to life issue.
The tactics used by the pro-life group completely backfired, as is shown by two articles in the Manly Daily. The first article was entitled 'Pro-life votes to favor Meers'. The article states:
The Independent Pro-life candidate for the State seat of Manly, Miss Patti Langworthy, will direct her second preference votes to the Liberal candidate, Mr Nelson Meers.
Later on the article states:
Miss Langworthy's decision could alter the balance in what has become one of the most fiercely contested electorates in the State.
Mrs Tighe is reported as saying:
'In Manly, Mr Nelson Meers is to receive the all-important second preferences, and Mr Stewart has been put last.
'We want to emphasise that Right to Life Australia is absolutely non-political-we have campaigned for and against candidates of all parties.
'We make no apology for the fact that some candidates fit into the category of unwanted politicians.
That is a good statement, and it came back to haunt her. Within a week another article appeared in the Manly Daily headed ' ''Disgusted'' Meers slams Independent'. The article states:
The Liberal candidate for Manly, Mr Nelson Meers, has threatened to take legal action against Miss Patty Langworthy the Independent candidate over a 'disgusting' election brochure.
The brochure, urging people to vote for Miss Langworthy, the Manly Pro-life candidate, shows graphic colour photographs of aborted babies.
She has already announced she will urge voters to give their second preferences to Mr Meers, and the brochure repeats the plea.
Mr Meers goes on to say:

I do not, in any way, support Miss Langworthy's methods in this campaign, and I have informed her that if she continues to distribute these brochures using my name by way of implication, I will take legal action.
Again I seek leave to have the two articles incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The articles read as follows-
PRO-LIFE VOTES TO FAVOR MEERS
By Spencer Ratcliff
The Independent Pro-Life candidate for the State seat of Manly, Miss Patti Langworthy, will direct her second preference votes to the Liberal candidate, Mr Nelson Meers.
That was the pledge yesterday from the chairman of the Right to Life Australia anti-abortion group, Mrs Margaret Tighe.
Miss Langworthy is sponsored by Right to Life Australia.
Just a week ago Manly's other Independent candidate, Mr Michael Darby, opted out of the contest, having previously stated he was trying to block Mr Meer's candidacy.
This would have benefited the sitting Labor MP, Mr A. G. Stewart.
Miss Langworthy's decision could alter the balance in what has become one of the most fiercely contested electorates in the State.
Miss Langworthy's manifesto is confined solely to the issue of anti-abortion.
This is an objective which could well appeal to a large section of the Manly electorate.
A swing of about 3.9 per cent is required to unseat Mr Stewart.
Miss Langworthy will outline her aims at a news conference today in the Wentworth Hotel.
A spokesman for Right to Life Australia said yesterday: 'Patti Langworthy aims to make her candidacy decisive for the result in the most watched and commented-on seat in NSW.'
Right to Life Australia's chairman, Mrs Tighe, said: 'Miss Langworthy deplores the total failure of any of the major political parties to protect the tiniest humans-the unborn babies.
'Right to Life Australia is supporting her in a determined effort to mobilise the pro-life vote in Manly, and then direct preferences to other candidates according to their pro-life rating.
'In Manly, Mr Nelson Meers is to receive the all-important second preferences, and Mr Stewart has been put last.
'We want to emphasise that Right to Life Australia is absolutely non-political-we have campaigned for and against candidates of all parties.
'In Manly, Mr Stewart has not given pro-life commitments.
'Electors must receive definite commitments before they will vote for a candidate.'
Mrs Tighe added: 'We do not like any baby being labelled an unwanted child.'
'We make no apology for the fact that some candidates fit into the category of unwanted politicians.'
Mr Michael Darby has already stated that he will encourage his supporters to vote for Miss Langworthy.
'DISGUSTED' MEERS SLAMS INDEPENDENT
By Spencer Ratcliff
The Liberal candidate for Manly, Mr Nelson Meers, has threatened to take legal action against Miss Patty Langworthy, the Independent candidate over a ''disgusting'' election brochure.
The brochure, urging people to vote for Miss Langworthy, the Manly Pro-Life candidate, shows graphic color photographs of aborted babies.
Miss Langworthy, 22, is backed by the anti-abortion group, Right To Life Australia.
She has already announced she will urge voters to give their second preferences to Mr Meers and the brochure repeats the plea.
'The brochure is disgusting, sickening and in extremely bad taste,' Mr Meers said yesterday.
'I have received many complaints from people who have been utterly offended by the brochure.

'I do not, in any way, support Miss Langworthy's methods in this campaign, and I have informed her that if she continues to distribute these brochures using my name by way of implication, I will take legal action.'
The brochure has also brought an angry response from many parents who have either telephoned or written to The Manly Daily to register their protest.
One of the calls came from a trained midwife, Mrs Helen Kyle of Gordon Street, Manly Vale.
'The brochure makes me feel sick, it's absolutely disgusting,' Mrs Kyle said.
'I just cannot believe they would print something like this and deliver it through the front door.
'What about the thousands of women who have had to have abortions for medical reasons?'
Mr Phil Hatch of La Perouse Street, Fairlight, said: 'I have an open mind on abortion, but I cannot stand this type of campaign.
'I am shocked and appalled at the photographic detail shown in the brochure. It is a ruthless, morbid piece of literature.
'Miss Langworthy is relying on shock tactics and sensationalism to force her views down our throats.'
Mr Hatch added: 'I am particularly upset because the brochure could easily have been taken out of the mailbox by my two young children.'
Mrs P. M. Smith of Crown Road, Queenscliff said her children had found the brochure in her letterbox.
'Doesn't Miss Langworthy realise that children nearly always retrieve the mail, or maybe she doesn't care?' Mrs Smith said.
'I'm disgusted and I'm sure a lot of other people agree with me that this sort of sick literature should not be allowed to be put in our mail boxes.'
Another objection came from Mrs Juliette Spork, of Addison Road, Manly.
'On opening this leaflet I was horrified to find graphically displayed, color photographs of the left-overs of somebody's abortion, in a plastic bag,' Mrs Spork said.
'After my stomach had settled down, I became angry.

'If, as the leaflet claims, the Langworthy campaign is concerned for the protection of human life and social justice, why then have they resorted to filling mail boxes and young children's minds with injustice?'
Mrs Spork added: 'I would not give a fig, let alone a vote for the Langworthy campaign.'
Miss Langworthy said yesterday: 'I think you will find the people who object to the brochure are in favor of abortion.
'People are shocked because they are being confronted with the reality of abortion.'
Miss Langworthy admitted the photographs in the brochures were 'shocking,' and that they were 'meant to shock'.
She said: 'I've got 10 nieces and nephews aged between three months and 12 years.
'They have all seen the photographs and not one of them has had any nightmares.
'I can understand parents' concern, but I don't think it hurts the children'.
Miss Langworthy said it would have been pointless putting the brochures inside a sealed envelope, because 'they would have gone straight into the garbage bin without being looked at.'
She said she hoped to pick up 'at least five per cent' of the vote-which would be about 1600 votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The end result of that campaign was that the Labor candidate received more preferences from the Pro-Life candidate than did the Liberals. In fact, when the preferences of the Pro-life candidate were distributed, the Labor Party gained 24 votes on the overall total, and she had a total of in excess of 1,100, so even the people who supported the Pro-Life candidate saw through the campaign that the Liberals were running.

SPEECH.PARA: Another scare tactic which was used by the Liberals was a quite deliberate and carefully set up fear campaign associated with public housing. The Liberal Party candidate said that slum type housing developments would take place in Manly if the Labor Government was returned to office. My colleague, Senator Gietzelt, spoke at length on this matter earlier and in detail on 24 September. I will not repeat the number of points that he made, except to say that I think this campaing definitely influenced some voters in particular sections of the electorate.

The present situation is that there has been a rather abortive court case over whether ticks or crosses should be counted as a valid vote. As honourable senators would realise, optional preferential voting was introduced into New South Wales by the Labor Government and appropriate alterations were made to the Electoral Act. They were made to ensure that the votes of electors who were making a clear voting intention would be counted. That is surely a more democratic situation than having votes declared informal on a technicality. The judge who heard the case ruled that it was not within his jurisdiction and that any further complaints should go to the Court of Disputed Returns. But it is rather strange, when one looks at the tactics of the State Liberal Party, to know why it even took this court case. It took it in only three seats, Bligh, Manly and North Shore. Apparently the reason why it took the court case was that it believed the Labor candidates had more ticks and crosses than numerals, giving them the primary vote. In fact it was thought that if there was a recount and the ticks and crosses were ruled not to be valid the Labor Party would suffer.

One thing that the scrutineers of both the Labor Party and the Liberal Party agreed upon was that regardless of the outcome of the court case it would not make any difference in the two seats of Bligh and Manly. Certainly it would reduce the Labor majority, but it would not give the seats to the Liberals. If we follow the same line of reasoning, in the third seat of North Shore, where the Liberal candidate and the Liberal leader, Mr Bruce McDonald, has now lost his seat, the only thing that could possibly have happened was that the labor vote would have dropped. If that had happened, of course, it would have guaranteed that the Labor Party candidate went out, as that candidate did, and ensured that the independent beat Mr McDonald in the seat. It is no wonder that the Liberals in New South Wales are in disarray. The court case cost them thousands, and I just wonder who will be paying the costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nelson Meers.
—I would not think so, after what has happened to him. The Press comment by the Liberal candidate for Wakehurst, the neighbouring electorate, is very interesting. He is reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Labor Party voters were more likely to cast informal votes under the system of nominating preferences.

What he was really saying was that the Liberal Party wants a system that deliberately discriminates against the aged, the infirm, the migrants, Aborigines, or people who it thinks are more likely to make mistakes when they fill out the ballot paper. They want a complicated system. That is what he said in a Press statement. I can see some honourable senators opposite shaking their heads. I think the statement was a disgrace. It appeared in the Manly Daily of 3 October, and I seek leave to have that article incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
COURT STOPS TICKS AND CROSSES VOTE COUNT
By Anne Flahvin
The Liberal Party has obtained a Supreme Court order to stop the counting of votes in the State election in Manly.
Counting will not resume until after a court challenge by the Liberal Party, on the validity of votes marked with ticks and crosses rather than the number 1.
Counting has also been stopped in Bligh and North Shore for the same reason.
The Liberal Party will present its case in court on Tuesday.
The party believes it might be able to pick up a net five per cent of the vote if ticks and crosses are ruled invalid.
Before the election, the State Electoral Office issued a handbook to all returning officers telling them to accept ballot papers marked with ticks or crosses as valid.

The unsuccessful Liberal candidate for Wakehurst, Mr Phillip Wearne, said yesterday the Liberal Party believed Labor Party voters were more likely to cast informal votes under the system of nominating preferences.
He said Labor research had shown this, and it prompted the electoral reform which included optional preferential voting.
The sitting Labor MP for Manly, Mr A. G. Stewart, dismissed as 'nonsense' the suggestion that Labor voters were more likely to use ticks and crosses.
'Two weeks ago voters made their choice by a clear margin of hundreds of votes', he said.

Mr Stewart said the recount of votes on Thursday, which was demanded by the Liberal candidate for Manly, Mr Nelson Meers, put the Liberal candidate even further behind than he was on the original count.
Mr Meers, who is holidaying after the election, could not be contacted for a comment yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Liberal candidate for Wakehurst was really saying was that he would like to maintain a system such as we already have for the Senate, a system which in New South Wales made one in every 10 votes informal. Now, of course, with the introduction of optional preferential voting in New South Wales, I believe the number of informal votes in the upper House, the equivalent of voting in the Senate where there are a lot of candidates, this time is under 4 per cent, as opposed to the 10 per cent who voted informally at the last Senate election. The campaign that was run in the seat of Manly by the Liberals was a disgrace and the people who organised it should now pack up their carpet-bags and go back to where they came from. The seat of Manly is still a Liberal voting electorate. One only has to look at the Federal figures to realise that. However, I believe Alan Stewart will continue to hold the seat while the Liberals run this sort of campaign on behalf of imported candidates. History has shown that the electors of Manly will always vote for a local man who looks after the problems of the electorate. History has shown it to be a unique seat which rewards the genuine, honest local member.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion I should mention the campaign in the electorate of Wakehurst, the neighbouring electorate in which I live. I was involved in the campaign in that electorate. I must say that at least in this electorate the Liberals ran a clean, hard-fought, above-board campaign. In the seat of Wakehurst the sitting Labor member, Mr Tom Webster, achieved a remarkable victory. In 1978 he received the second largest swing in New South Wales, the largest swing being achieved by the Premier, Neville Wran. The swing that gave him the seat was approximately 15 per cent and there were many people in the Labor Party and in the community, including myself, who considered that it would be impossible to hold a swing of that order; that is, 15 per cent. Not only was the vote maintained but it was increased by approximately one per cent. The Labor vote in the electorate of Wakehurst is now just in excess of 57 per cent. Tom Webster won all but three of the polling booths in the seat of Wakehurst, including winning some for the first time ever. I compare that situation with the 1972 and 1974 Federal figures and the 1978 State figures. The final results in this electorate where I live were: Tom Webster ALP, 14,887; Australian Democrats, 837; Liberals, 11,191. The Labor Party received 56 per cent of the effective Australian Democrats preferences, that is, the preferences recorded by people completing the ballot paper from one to three.

The scene is now set for what I once considered to be impossible: The State seats of Manly and Wakehurst look like being held by the Labor Party for the third time in a row. In respect of the seat of Wakehurst, it is not now even listed in the marginal seat category. I believe it will remain a Labor seat as long as New South Wales has a Labor government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make use of this first reading motion on a money Bill to raise an issue which is important in many towns and cities throughout the country today, and that is the national day of protest on education. I wish to raise a series of matters dealing particularly with university education in Australia and I wish in particular to make reference to the University of Queensland. It is one of the major universities in this country and therefore can act as a representative university. I wish to detail the types of problems that the University of Queensland is facing and to show that those problems are the problems that all universities in this country are either facing now or will face in the very near future. I will run through a series of problems that university administration, staff and student unions find as their major problems at the present time and I will go on to give some detail in relation to the University of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: The first issue obviously deals with the level of funding available to universities in this country. Here the problem is not only one of magnitude but also one of how this Budget has sought real changes in the way that the grants in the future will be administered. The major problem of course is the problem of supplementation. The Government now intends to estimate prospectively that a certain supplementation will be necessary for increases. Up to this time universities have been able to rely on the fact that any real increase that took place was covered by an increase in funds by way of supplementation. That guarantee has now been lost. Although almost all of the increases are beyond the control of universities themselves they will not now be covered by supplementation grants. If that is not enough, this Government has continued the absurdity of one-year funding. There must be no other multi-million dollar enterprise in any country such as ours which has to rely on one-year funding or even one-year planning. How any government, let alone a government committed to some notion of private enterprise, could continue with the absurdity of one-year funding and the costs that are thereby involved is beyond the understanding of anybody who knows anything about keeping a major enterprise alive and functioning efficiently.

The level of funding is in a parlous state. The 1980-81 capital funding was less than one-quarter of the 1974-75 funding and in this Budget it has been dropped yet again. The 1979 report of the Universities Council reported that at that time 12 per cent of all university buildings were in need of major renovation, that 5 per cent had become unsuitable for further use and that every university was able to submit to its appropriate organisation lists of essential capital developments. Those claims have not been taken up by the Government; they have not been met in this Budget. We are now confronted with what is rapidly becoming the norm in all universities: Overcrowded libraries, dangerous antiquated laboratories, draughty offices and fire traps for lecture halls-that in a country as wealthy as ours.

In terms of equipment the situation is very much the same. Although the equipment grant was increased this year the situation is that the amount provided allows for less than 7 per cent of the equipment to be replaced each year. In other words, it allows an average depreciation life of 15 years for equipment in universities. The average life of such equipment in universities in countries comparable to our own is 10 years and the taxation laws for private enterprises in this country allow 7 1/2 years. So what the Government is expecting the universities to do is in fact to eke out from their meagre handout from the Government in terms of the equipment grant twice the life that is allowed under the taxation laws for everybody else in this country. There has not been any massive increase in equipment grants since 1974-75. Yet if one looks at the type of research base that is necessary one finds that obviously massive injections of funds for sophisticated equipment are necessary and are overdue by something like six years.

Of course, in terms of general funding the 1980-81 funding was reduced by 10 per cent over the 1977-78 level. This year's Budget slices another 5 per cent off that. Therefore we are in for further staff cuts. Indeed, most universities have frozen all unadvertised positions. In other words, we are saying that when a staff position falls vacant in a university, at no matter what level, it will not be filled at the current time.

In addition to that the staff situation has grown increasingly difficult over the last couple of years, to such an extent that we now have set in train one of the most difficult staff situations that any enterprise could face; that is, having an increasingly aging staff with no younger replacements. In the long term this will be disastrous. Of course, in the short term it adds to university costs because one of the elements within a university's funding, which very few people realise, is what is called by the unfelicitious phrase of incremental creep. In other words, each staff member gets a raise each additional year that he is in the university. If staff is not replaced and staff does not move from one university to another then total staff costs are much higher than would normally be expected. Incremental creep in universities indeed is one of the headaches that all vice chancellors and administrations have had to face in recent times. The prospect of that becoming greater each year is a terrifying element within any university budget because of the extremely large percentage in any university budget going to pay staff salaries.

Probably the situation is now that the Government is seeking in some form or another to suggest to universities some type of steady state. The only steady state we are getting in universities is a steady decline. I do not know whether that falls under the heading of a steady state. There are steady declines in all the major areas that I have mentioned. But the situation goes much further than that. The squeeze currently under way affects technicians and research assistants. These people are absolutely vital to the promotion and the continuity of any genuine research effort in our universities. Because many of these people, particularly the research assistants, are non-tenured staff they are the people who necessarily are being laid off as the first staff to go. Why I say 'necessarily' is that the universities would find it excessively difficult to face the problem of getting rid of tenured staff. Whether we like it or not and whether it is necessarily the correct move, those research assistants are the first people to go. Therefore, the research effort is affected in the work place which those people sustain from the inside.

I have already mentioned the lack of sophisticated equipment. The other major problem which is affecting more and more departments and one which is felt particularly acutely in the major universities is the problem of computer time. Anybody who has tried to operate on a university computer would know the type of log jam that people time and again run into. No matter how heavily the people in the university work on keeping the computer operating, users constantly have the computer crashing in the middle of working through a whole variety of problems. Indeed, in many universities the problem now is so acute that people would rather pay out of their own pockets to use outside computers simply to be able to get the job done and to get on with the task. Yet we all know that the computer is a vital element in any sophisticated research which is done in almost any department of any university in Australia. We do not have the elementary backing. It is as though in times gone past we failed to provide classrooms with blackboard and chalk. To fail to provide universities with adequate and sophisticated computers and adequate computer time is in fact to approach the whole notion of research in universities in a juvenile and almost criminal way. I will come to that element shortly.

The libraries are also feeling a terrible pinch. Indeed, the libraries are feeling the pinch in a number of ways, one of which I hope is currently under review in the House of Representatives; that is, the sales tax on books. Although libraries in universities are exempt from paying that sales tax the cost of books will necessarily rise because the sales tax affects other elements apart from simply the element of purchase. So the total cost to libraries will be greater although they do not have to pay that extra sales tax impost on top of the extra charges for books. Libraries have not been able to get the grant increases that are necessary to enable them to stay anywhere near the level of the increases in costs of books and, in particular, the increase in the cost of periodicals. The periodical element is one which people who do not make use of university libraries are probably unaware of. The vast bulk of costs in university libraries now goes on buying periodicals simply because the only way to remain current is with periodicals. One does not remain current in books any longer, generally because the publication of a book has a time lag of anywhere between four and six years. A periodical would have a time lag of between only six months and one and a half years. Anyone who wants to remain current remains current with periodicals.

For libraries to remain research libraries-presumably what we are attempting to provide in universities are research libraries-we have to spend heavily on periodicals. Most universities can no longer do that. They are now cutting back on a whole range of periodicals so those libraries are increasingly becoming inadequate. This is not only a short term problem; it is also a long term problem. It will not be possible at any time in the future to regain the position. I presume the Government is well aware of that. At no stage in the future will it be possible to resurrect a library which has become derelict in research material. The costs are so astronomical as to be totally impossible to meet. In fact there we are faced with the first long term slide that is setting in; that is in research efforts that can be made in libraries.

Post-graduate students will be affected and are currently being affected. A debate in this House within the next few weeks will be on fees. I do not intend to go into that at this point. There are two other elements of research other than that involving post-graduate students who are an excessively important element within the support of any research program within universities. One point concerns the Tertiary Education Commission grants which are falling every year as a percentage of total grants available to universities. The second concerns the Australian Research Grants Scheme. This has not kept pace in any way with the number of research workers. From 1966 to 1978 the staff in universities has doubled whereas the ARGS funds and also the funds available from the National Health and Medical Research Council scheme have not risen appreciably in that time-certainly not anywhere near in keeping with inflation. So we have had a rapid increase in staff, yet not a rapid increase in research funds to provide that staff with useful back-up facilities. It is all very well to gain highly qualified people in universities, but if it is not possible to provide them with backing it is not possible for them to work effectively and efficiently.

Increasing amounts of funds are now coming to universities from outside bodies. In most cases they are welcomed by universities, but the universities are keeping a very strict eye on them. I raise here the point that it is not possible to any large extent to replace the public funding of research by private funding, beyond that percentage to which it is already kept, without raising serious ethical and major research problems for universities. I raise only one element here to show the type of problem that overseas universities have run into and that our universities will run into if governments wind down, as they have in the last few years, the money that is devoted to research. Imagine a uranium mining company, for example, being at all interested in funding a scholarly work on Middle English epic poetry, funding a Marxist interpretation of Australian history or, what would be unthinkable, actually funding and furthering work on the lethal nature of low dose radiation. I do not imagine that uranium companies would be very interested in funding that type of research, which obviously is vital and necessary and must be covered by public funding.

In regard to student numbers, the Government has admitted in the Budget Papers that there will be no real growth in the next few years. Indeed, it has suggested a real drop in university student numbers next year and that level remaining steady for the next few years. What an absurdity for a country such as ours, which is seeking to move into high technology, even to contemplate a drop in university numbers.

TALK.START.PARA: —There might be fewer people.
—Perhaps the honourable senator comes from a State in which the numbers are declining. I come from one to which 3,000 more people move each month.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance, of course, is very interesting in relation to this subject. It has always been below the current poverty line. Currently it is 59.5 per cent of the Henderson poverty line figure. By next September, given the Government's own inflation predictions, it will be below 50 per cent of the poverty line figure. In other words, we expect those who are engaged in university studies-whom the Australian Democrats see as engaging in a worthwhile occupation for the country-to live on less than 50 per cent of the poverty line figure. Also, the number of those who receive TEAS allowances has been dropping since 1977. In that year there were 99,153, in 1978, 98,220, in 1979, 93,559, and in 1980, 91,356. In real terms, expenditure also has dropped every year since 1977. Presumably the Government says: 'We will cut out this fund. It is good for scholars to remain in the poverty to which they have traditionally become accustomed. It is better for their minds.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Good discipline.

—Yes, probably it bespeaks a philosophy towards education that comes from the last century. The post-graduate, if we may single him out, is expected to live on a measly $4,620 in a time of rising inflation and extra sales taxes. Such a student, if he is typical, will be working between 60 and 80 hours a week-I would certainly have expected my post-graduate students to work that length of time-with very little recreational leave, because that is necessary if he is to get through his studies. He receives no sick leave, loadings, incremental salaries or additional support in regard to health costs. Let us not forget that the typical post-graduate student has some type of dependant. Such a situation means, of course, that currently we have, and increasingly will have, a shortage of doctoral degree students. That has led this year to a crisis for research; and to turn a crisis into an absolute catastrophe we have had the imposition of fees.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to discuss other elements in relation to universities before passing on to the question of Queensland University in particular. I refer first to the closure of the engineering school at Deakin University which, from our point of view, is the first direct and open infringement of university autonomy in this country. It means that the Government is testing the water. It means that if the Government moves easily with this one and does not find terribly much backlash in the community it will be in a position to attack any other university course. That is the real point of the closure of the engineering school at Deakin. Any course which the Government does not like it can then move to close down. I would imagine that many university courses must be anathema to this particular conservative Government. It will probably be looking at them in years to come-in other words, suggesting to universities that it might be very well if they pulled money out of here and popped it into there. The universities will have to buckle on those demands if they buckle on this one.

I was very glad today to see the universities taking a stand on this matter and drawing an appropriate historical analogy. That analogy, of course, is the move that Hitler made. Those who might want to go back and re-read the history books will realise that the first moves made in Nazi Germany were against the universities-much earlier than Hitler showed his hand anywhere else-and the universities buckled. The universities were the first to go. Luckily, I believe, Australian universities may be a little grittier than that and will hold on. I do not think it is an exaggerated claim, and it is one which was raised today by the vice-chancellor of that university.

My next point concerns the centres of excellence. During the 1980 election campaign we found the Government taking up a comment made in the sixth report of the Tertiary Education Commission, which talked about centres of research concentration. We had a subtle renaming to centres of excellence, 'excellence' being a nice word. So we then had the Government dedicating itself to centres of research excellence. That indeed is a laudable proposition. Unfortunately, we then discovered who was going to be paying for them. They were to be paid for from reduced current and capital grants, so all higher education institutions had to foot the bill. Additional funds to set up these worthwhile initiatives did not go to the universities.

Although the shifting of funds to transition education may seem to be a long way from university education, I would like to show how I believe that it is linked directly to it. The guidelines of the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) in June 1981 spelt out the Government's aims in this fashion:

. . . the Government wishes to accelerate the development of appropriate transition courses in secondary schools, with emphasis on basic changes in curricula relevant particularly to the needs of low achievers.

In other words, the Government is setting about a unilateral attempt to change the direction of Australian public education and, in its own words, bring about 'a substantial shift of emphasis within schools'. So we see that little sleight of hand whereby $27m suddenly disappeared from the amounts that the States had and suddenly reappeared in the transition education area. The States have been confronted with receiving $27m less for their ordinary school expenditures. In other words, these programs were to be reduced in quality, at least in the public schools. The private schools have not been interfered with in the same way and are receiving increasingly generous financial support. Of course the private schools will continue and will be able to continue to do what all schools ought to be able to do-that is, provide preparation for those people who are able and who wish to undertake tertiary studies. I foresee that these current trends will continue and that we will have an elite entering universities. It will be a privileged elite, and an ever diminishing elite, given the figures that I have already cited.

Between 1974 and 1980 the proportion of school leavers proceeding straight to higher education dropped by nearly 20 per cent. The increase in numbers coming from private schools was dramatic. That is the state which exists in universities around the country. I approached the various departments at Queensland University for a comment about their research position. I wish briefly to summarise some of the replies because I think they give the flavour of what is going on in one university which is typical of all universities. The replies were from heads of departments. The reply which I received from the Chemistry Department was that it will not be able to keep abreast of new technology with other countries. The Classics Department will lose most of its promising post-graduate students and the Computer Science Department has lost one very good man and will lose another top man to overseas, where they can get money to pursue their research interests. A major project developing a micro-computer system is being scrapped. An amount of $550,000-that is a pittance in terms of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting-spread over six years would have allowed the Department to become self-sufficient in terms of research and would have enabled it to make money. This is an utter absurdity. A free enterprise operation of the University has been knocked on the head.

The Education Department has had to abandon its classroom management project-an incredibly important research project involving a large number of the staff of that department. According to the head of the Civil Engineering Department, the research capacity of that department has been severely affected because of high teaching loads. The Electrical Engineering Department has lost three top class post-graduate students to industry, which is able to pay two and a half times what the doctoral students are getting on their pittance. In the Mining and Metallurgical Department there is again a lack of post-graduate students for the same reason. In the English Department the research effort is being severely hampered by the harsh cutbacks in the library. The French Department is experiencing extensive delays in processing its research. The Geology and Minerology Department has experienced the destruction of a project supporting the only silicate oxygen extraction line operating in Australia. The Department's allocation went from $14,000 last year to nil this year.

In the Japanese Department, the Ph. D. and masters students have been severely affected. The Department believes that within two years there will be no students enrolled in post-graduate Asian studies. The Japanese Department of the Queensland University, in fact, is the leader in this country in Japanese studies and languages. In other words, we are supposed to be getting into Asia so let us stop learning about it! The same situation applies in the Occupational Therapy Department. All independent research projects have been scrapped and clinical training is also being threatened. The Philosophy Department's development of computer aided learning in formal logic is threatened. The Physics Department is not able to keep up and it will have to scrap some worthwhile projects. That is what the Department is looking at at the moment because, it says, 'something has to go'. In the Regional and Town Planning Department, research into the causes of decline in country towns is going. If ever we wanted a particular project, that is one. Planners are being trained by the Regional and Town Planning Department of the University of Queenland for the Third World. I would imagine that is something dear to the heart of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser).

I now turn to the Social Work Department. The role of voluntary organisations in meeting social needs is to go. In the Veterinary Medicine Department the training of veterinarians is being affected. That is an incredibly important matter for our primary industry. What an extraordinary situation we have in this country when that type of quality research is being affected. As the Senate has some other business to attend to, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning, in response to a question asked by Senator Missen, I said that I would give consideration to his question and request within the question and respond at a later hour this day. I have done so. I must say that I believe the question is not in order because it does not fall within the terms of Standing Order 98A, which governs the putting of questions to chairmen of committees. That Standing Order provides that questions must relate to activities of the committees. Standing committees of the Senate may inquire only into such matters as are referred to them by the Senate. A question to such a committee must, therefore, relate to the activities of the committee in relation to some matter which the Senate has referred to that committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: The honourable senator's question purported to ask the chairman whether the Committee would inquire into a certain matter. The chairman cannot answer in relation to the activities of his committee in respect of a matter which the Senate has not referred to the committee. If Senator Missen wishes the Senate to refer to a particular committee a matter into which it is not at present empowered to inquire, the proper course is for him to give notice of a motion for that purpose. He cannot ask the chairman for his knowledge of a matter or whether the committee will inquire into a matter when the Senate has not yet referred that matter to the committee. Therefore, as I said earlier, I believe the question is out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to raise a matter which is of great importance in far north Queensland. I speak of the television service in that area. Those people in the capital cities and the provincial cities often take television services for granted. In fact, in some of our capital cities we have five channels; in other capital cities we have four channels. In Canberra, our national capital, we have two channels, but that is far better than one being available in many parts of Queensland and far better than none in other parts of Queensland. I speak specifically of the television service for Thursday Island which, I understand, is scheduled for completion in December. I certainly hope that it will be completed in December. I have in mind the translator promised for the Airlie Beach area in 1975. The local residents are still waiting for the translator in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal matter of concern in relation to Thursday Island is that I have had some information passed on to me from Mr Robert Scott, normally known as Bob Scott, who is the member for the State seat of Cook in far north Queensland. Cook is the northernmost seat in Queensland and takes in Thursday Island and other islands in Torres Strait, as well as some areas on the mainland. Mr Scott has informed me that he had heard that the Thursday Island service will have an effective range of reception of only about 10 kilometres. This would mean that Thursday Island would enjoy a long overdue television service. But if a 10 kilometre radius is, in fact, the effective range of the service, the reception will be limited to Thursday Island and islands which are very close to Thursday Island. More importantly, several communities in the Torres Strait area will not have a television service. As well, the community of Bamaga on the very tip of mainland Australia will be beyond the range of Thursday Island television facilities. Bamaga residents and other residents in the Torres Strait area rightly expected that they would benefit from the Thursday Island television translator. They and Mr Scott are concerned about suggestions that they will miss out on a facility that many Australians take for granted.

At this stage I am not sure whether this information is correct and that is the reason I am bringing it before the Senate tonight. I would like to pose certain questions about this service. The first question is: Will the television service be limited to Thursday Island and nearby surroundings? Secondly, if it is not available to many Torres Strait communities and Bamaga, when will it be likely to become available to those communities? Thirdly, can anything be done at this stage to boost the power of the television signal; that is, if the original information given to me is correct, namely that there will be only a 10 kilometre effective reception range? If nothing can be done to boost the power of the television signal, what are the technical reasons for the inability to do so? I trust that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) will be able to provide me with some advice I can pass on to Mr Scott and the community leaders in this area of far north Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I appreciate Senator Colston's interest in this quite magnificent area of Australia. Like him I find Bamaga a magnificent community to visit and its people interesting to talk to. I do not know his colleague, Mr Robert Scott. I do know the person whom Robert Scott defeated, and that is Evelyn Scott who was our candidate in that election and who, in fact, is one of our officers in Aboriginal Hostels Ltd. She is an Aboriginal officer who is one of the best people with whom I have had the privilege of working. I take it that the Queensland Parliament's loss was my gain owing to the fact that she remains with Aboriginal Hostels Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: I have some information on the three questions raised by Senator Colston. The first question asked: Will television services be limited to Thursday Island and nearby surroundings? I am advised that the answer to that question is yes, they will be so limited. The Thursday Island television service which is expected to commence operation in December is part of the remote area television program. The RATV program is designed to provide low power and thus low coverage service to isolated towns and limited surrounding areas. In this way the overall population coverage throughout Australia will be maximised within the funds available. It is a matter of how much coverage we can get with the amount of money we have to spend.

Senator Colston's second question was: If a television service will not be available to a number of Torres Strait communities and the community of Bamaga on the tip of Cape York Peninsula, when is it likely that those communities will have a television service? I am advised that extension of the service to other Torres Strait communities, including the top of Cape York Peninsula, is not planned at this stage due to the limited availability of funds and resources. It may well prove that the Australian national satellite to be operational by the mid-1980s will be the most appropriate way for the Government to provide television services to communities in this area. Local communities may, however, prefer to fund privately installations of their own.

Senator Colston's third question asked whether anything could be done at this stage to boost the power of the television signal and, if that could not be done, what technical reasons there were for the inability so to do. I am advised that any practicable increase in power of the Thursday Island RATV transmitter would not provide a service to established communities on Cape York Peninsula due to the distance involved. I take it that there is a technical difficulty in boosting across the distances, even between those communities. That is all the information I have been able to obtain. I am not sure whether it completely resolves Senator Colston's concerns. If not, if he is able to make known to me any other questions I will pass those to the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) and see whether I can obtain further information for the honourable senator.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
